snippet: APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the resu...
lead_paragraph: APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the results, which topped Wall Street estimates by a wide margin. Apple shares climbed as much as 6 percent in after-hours trading. [Page C1]
abstract: APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the results, which topped Wall Street estimates by a wide margin. Apple shares climbed as much as 6 percent in after-hours trading. [Page C1]    VIRTUAL WORLD ADVERTISING -- Companies including Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Sun Microsystems and Nissan are testing the next frontier in Internet advertising: placing ads into online virtual worlds like Second Life and Virtual Laguna Beach. Some online users worry that the corporate intrusion will spoil their virtual paradises. [C1]    MICROSOFT LOOKS AT CHIP DESIGN -- After wedding its software to Intel's processors for decades, Microsoft is looking to its own research labs for as a new source in future chip design. One goal of the project is to give Microsoft more control over hardware and software and the way the interact in new devices. [C3]    CONSUMER PRICES FALL -- Falling energy prices helped push consumer prices down sharply last month, but the decline did not entirely dispel inflation worries because the measure of retail prices that excludes food and energy costs held steady at a level still above the Federal Reserve's comfort zone. [C3]    NEW AD AGENCY NETWORK -- Three longtime advertising executives are joining forces to start an agency network with an entrepreneurial bent. The agency network, called the Partners Group, aims to grow by encouraging more entrepreneurs to affiliate with the three founders. Advertising [C13]    MUSIC INDUSTRY AND YOUTUBE -- Universal Music Group, Sony BMG Music Entertainment and Warner Music each acquired small stakes in YouTube as part of licensing deals just prior to the sale of the company to Google for $1.65 billion. The three companies now stand to receive as much as $50 million collectively, people involved in the deal said. [C1]    A TORRENT OF IMMIGRANT MONEY -- The flow of money from immigrants working in the United States to Latin America has become a torrent, increasing by 51 percent from two years ago to over $45 billion, according to a new study. Where 20 years ago such remittances came from four or five states, today they come nearly every state in the country, the study said. [A24]    ELI LILLY CRITICIZED -- Three doctors at the National Institutes of Health have sharply criticized Eli Lilly for its efforts to promote the use of Xigris, an expensive treatment for patients with sepsis, an often deadly blood infection. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the doctors wrote that Lilly had manipulated treatment guidelines to promote Xigris at the expense of older, cheaper and equally effective treatments. [C12]    TIME WARNER CABLE SHARES -- Time Warner Cable said that it would sell shares publicly for the first time, giving investors a chance to own a piece of the country's second-largest cable provider after Comcast. The shares would amount to 16 percent of the company's equity. [C5]    EARNINGS RISE AT A.M.D. -- Advanced Micro Devices, which makes computer processors, posted a higher quarterly profit but profit margins fell sharply, hurt by a price war with the rival chipmaker Intel. Advanced Micro said it expected fourth-quarter sales to rise from the previous quarter but did not elaborate. [C4]    NBC PLANS CUTBACKS -- NBC will announce a series of cost-cutting measures including some employee layoffs, executives said. The plans will include a relocation of MSNBC, the all-news cable channel owned by NBC from its current home in Secaucus N.J. [C13]    VIACOM SEVERANCE -- Viacom plans to pay its former chief executive, Tom Freston, $84.8 million after ousting him last month after less than a year in the top job. Mr. Freston will receive $58.9 million in severance. The remainder will be in deferred compensation, retirement funds and common stock, the company said in a regulatory filing. [C15]    BLOOMBERG NEWS NOT FOR SALE -- Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has rejected bids for Bloomberg LP, the financial information company that he founded in 1981, and has no immediate intention to sell the business, the company said. The statement came amid speculation that the company might be sold to free up Mr. Bloomberg's vast personal wealth for philanthropic causes. [C1]    DOW MOVES BRIEFLY PAST 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average briefly swept past the 12,000 mark for the first time as investors showed optimism about corporate earnings and the economy. Then the blue-chip index pulled back, closing at another record high but short of 12,000. [C15]    ONLINE    DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    A SPECIAL REPORT -- For mutual fund investors, jubilance over gains in the stock market has been tempered by the realization that many fund managers were caught flat-footed and did not keep pace. A report is at nytimes.com/business.    TAXES AND FAITH -- A number of communities around the country are debating whether or not religious organizations should receive property tax breaks. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business.

snippet: To the Editor: Having visited Helsinki a few years ago, I was extremely interested in ''Helsinki's Shining Season'' by R .W. Apple Jr. (July 16). Mr. Apple states that ''Helsinki is a feast for the architecture and design buff,'' but omits any men...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Having visited Helsinki a few years ago, I was extremely interested in "Helsinki's Shining Season" by R .W. Apple Jr. (July 16). Mr. Apple states that "Helsinki is a feast for the architecture and design buff," but omits any mention of one of Helsinki's most outstanding sculptures, the Sibelius Monument, which was designed by Eila Hiltunen and is in Sibelius Park. The sculpture comprises 600 stainless-steel tubes welded into an organ-type structure that creates echoes and sounds.
abstract: To the Editor: Having visited Helsinki a few years ago, I was extremely interested in ''Helsinki's Shining Season'' by R .W. Apple Jr. (July 16). lead_paragraph: IT was like a TV Land rerun marathon this week, with Boston Scientific topping Johnson & Johnson's bid for Guidant, the Dow eclipsing 11,000, General Motors scrambling to regain market share and Apple Computer being hailed as a blisteringly hot tech stock. There was even another sex-discrimination suit on Wall Street.
abstract: IT was like a TV Land rerun marathon this week, with Boston Scientific topping Johnson & Johnson's bid for Guidant, the Dow eclipsing 11,000, General Motors scrambling to regain market share and Apple Computer being hailed as a blisteringly hot tech stock. There was even another sex-discrimination suit on Wall Street.     Some things were new, however. China surpassed some Western industrial powerhouses with the size of its economy, and its global trade surplus set a record.    FIGHT TO THE START -- It is a strange kind of bidding war when a last-minute offer from the underdog is about the same as the opening bid made by the heavily favored industry giant. But that is the case in the battle for Guidant, a maker of implantable heart devices.

snippet: This issue is largely an idiosyncratic selection, chosen by our editors and writers, who are often following their own passions and curiosities.
lead_paragraph: This is our 13th annual Lives They Lived issue. Many notable people died over the last 12 months, among them Coretta Scott King, Robert Altman, Ann Richards, William Styron, Caspar Weinberger, Jeane Kirkpatrick, Red Buttons and Augusto Pinochet. This year has again brought the deaths of many men and women in the American military; more than 800 American troops were killed in Iraq and Afghanistan in 2006. In addition, countless Iraqis have died. This year also saw three deaths closer to home. The New York Times lost R. W. Apple Jr., a marvelous writer and an editor at the paper for 40 years; Gerald Boyd, the first African-American managing editor at The Times, who was known for his tenacious reporting and demanding editing; and A. M. Rosenthal, who reimagined and reinvigorated the newspaper during his 17 years at its helm.

snippet: Fall salads include heavier ingredients along with fresh lettuces to make them more substantial and draw attention to autumn's bounty; photo; recipes (M)
lead_paragraph: LIKE everything else in my life, salads grow more complicated in the fall. In June and July, I like lettuce plain, with olive oil and vinegar splashed on straight from the bottle, plus salt and pepper. It is one of the skills I am secretly exceptionally proud of, this ability to dress a salad in the bowl without mixing up the dressing on the side first. I am convinced that salad tastes better this way, though I can't figure out why. And I enjoy doing it -- I feel more in tune with the greens, and also more picturesque (which, by the way, is a vast and unexplored category of human satisfaction).
abstract: Fall salads include heavier ingredients along with fresh lettuces to make them more substantial and draw attention to autumn's bounty; photo; recipes (M)

snippet: Digital music service eMusic has produced 10-minute video segment to be broadcast on Independent Film Channel, featuring independent artists and directing viewers to eMusic's Web site; move comes as service, which sells digital music that will pla...
lead_paragraph: eMusic, a digital music service that has won the ears of indie-rock fans and other customers with a subscription service built on songs from independent labels, is now pursuing eyeballs. The service has produced, with the Independent Film Channel, a 10-minute video segment to be broadcast on IFC featuring independent artists and directing viewers to eMusic's Web site (emusic.com). The move comes as the service -- which, unlike Apple's iTunes, sells music files that can be played on any portable music player -- is trying to raise its profile ahead of the holiday shopping season, the music industry's biggest sales period. The first installment of the video segment -- featuring acts like Bjork, above, and the Hold Steady -- is to be broadcast tomorrow at 12:45 a.m., with repeats and a second installment scheduled to run sporadically through Christmas. The creation of the segment is part of a deal in which eMusic will also advertise on the channel and distribute cards -- branded by both partners -- offering 25 free downloads from the service. JEFF LEEDS

lead_paragraph: In December, Jacob Alexander, the chief executive of Comverse Technology, a New York-based communications software company, stepped before a crowd of politicians and diplomats at the New York Hilton to accept an award from the America-Israel Friendship League.
abstract: In December, Jacob Alexander, the chief executive of Comverse Technology, a New York-based communications software company, stepped before a crowd of politicians and diplomats at the New York Hilton to accept an award from the America-Israel Friendship League.      The award highlighted Mr. Alexander's achievement in transforming Comverse over two decades from a teetering penny stock to a market leader with more than $1 billion in annual revenue. In recent months, however, the accolades have turned into accusations as an investigation into how the company granted stock options accelerates.

snippet: Portland, Ore., established itself as a capital of the organic-food movement years ago. This season it's reached a peak, with new restaurants putting an even more creative spin on local ingredients. At Vindalho (2038 Southeast Clinton Street; 503-...
lead_paragraph: Portland, Ore., established itself as a capital of the organic-food movement years ago. This season it's reached a peak, with new restaurants putting an even more creative spin on local ingredients. At Vindalho (2038 Southeast Clinton Street; 503-467-4550; entrees $13 to $16), David Machado does an Oregonian take on Indian dishes -- those are Willamette Valley pears in your chutney. At Nostrana (1401 Southeast Morrison Street; 503-234-2427; entrees $15 to $25), Cathy Whims and Deb Accuardi serve regional food by way of Italy, with the likes of rabbit squazet on fuzi pasta and squab and bread soup (a traditional Veneto dish). The menu changes daily at Le Pigeon (738 East Burnside Street; 503-546-8796; entrees $16 to $20), where Gabriel Rucker glazes squab with red wine and serves fried pork skin with sauce gribiche. At Portland's latest supper club, Simpatica Dining Hall (828 Southeast Ash Street; 503-235-1600; www.simpaticacatering.com; prix fixe $30 to $45), right, meals are served family style -- and only on weekends. The menu, e-mailed to subscribers weekly, features dishes like celery root and apple soup and chicory salad with sautéed chicken livers. HANNAH WALLACE

snippet: Tribute at Museum of Television and Radio will honor photographer Jerome Liebling, with focus on how his pictures have been used in numerous documentaries; will be conducted by several filmmakers that have been taught by Liebling starting in early...
lead_paragraph: For much of a half-century of taking quiet, subtly powerful pictures that demand and reward long looking, Jerome Liebling has been known as a photographer's photographer. The label is both a high compliment and an acknowledgment that Mr. Liebling, now 82, has not enjoyed the acclaim accorded to many of his contemporaries who first took their cameras to the streets of New York after World War II.
abstract: Tribute at Museum of Television and Radio will honor photographer Jerome Liebling, with focus on how his pictures have been used in numerous documentaries; will be conducted by several filmmakers that have been taught by Liebling starting in early 1970's at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass, including directors Ken Burns, Karen Goodman and Amy Stechler and cinematographer Buddy Squires; photos (M)

snippet: Deal on a Constitution For Iraq Is Teetering  An agreement struck 11 months ago by Shiite and Kurdish leaders to win Sunni Arab support for a new constitution is fraying, causing concern among some political leaders that it could jeopardize Iraq's...
lead_paragraph: Deal on a Constitution For Iraq Is Teetering An agreement struck 11 months ago by Shiite and Kurdish leaders to win Sunni Arab support for a new constitution is fraying, causing concern among some political leaders that it could jeopardize Iraq's fragile governing coalition. The dispute peaked as a large Shiite faction continued to fight for quick approval of legislation giving provinces the authority to create autonomous states, which Sunnis oppose. PAGE A8
abstract: Deal on a Constitution For Iraq Is Teetering  An agreement struck 11 months ago by Shiite and Kurdish leaders to win Sunni Arab support for a new constitution is fraying, causing concern among some political leaders that it could jeopardize Iraq's fragile governing coalition. The dispute peaked as a large Shiite faction continued to fight for quick approval of legislation giving provinces the authority to create autonomous states, which Sunnis oppose.   PAGE A8    A 'Wild' Primary in Arizona  Lying and spying are among the charges in a Republican primary for an Arizona House seat that has been called wild by veteran watchers. It is also among the most expensive House races in the country.PAGE A10    Fashion Week Opens  Spring fashions come to the big top in Bryant Park in Manhattan with commercial dazzle, but some designers who shun conventional wisdom steal the show in the opening days of the spring 2007 ready-to-wear season. Left, a design by Karen Walker, showing in New York for the first time.   PAGE A16    What's Apple's Next Trick?  Apple Computer seems poised to unveil something big at an event on Tuesday, possibly its strategy for marrying the computer to the television.   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1    An Industry Based on Fraud  A controversy at Hewlett-Packard has shined light on the practice of pretexting, or trying to gain access to a person's records by posing as that person. Far from being unusual, pretexting has turned into a small industry.   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1    Not Perfect, but Not Bad  Roger Federer, right, beat Andy Roddick in four sets to win the United States Open for the third straight year. Federer won 27 of 28 matches in the four Grand Slam events this season, winning the Australian Open, Wimbledon and the United States Open.   SPORTSMONDAY, PAGE D1    N.F.L. Kicks Off in Full  In the N.F.L.'s first game with two brothers starting at quarterback, Peyton Manning and the Indianapolis Colts beat Eli Manning and the Giants on the season's opening weekend. The Jets, the Saints and the Patriots also won.   SPORTSMONDAY

lead_paragraph: Some glow at the touch. Others hum softly into the night. All, with sensuous curves and luminescent faces, beg to be beheld. These are PCs meant to be seen as much as they are to be used.

snippet: Melissa Clark describes her experience picking grapes in Clos Roche Blanche vineyards in Loire Valley, France; recipes for hearty lunches served to workers who eat in communal style; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: MAREUIL-SUR-CHER, France - IT was a harvest day like any other at Clos Roche Blanche vineyards in the Loire Valley. The weather was mild, the sky by turns bright and cloud-dimmed, the grapes dusky and ripe. Flanking the leafy vines, experienced pickers squatted, knees splayed, on moist soil, clipping bunches of gamay into large plastic buckets. Some sang, some complained, some joked, but all moved agilely, clearing row after sticky, grueling row.
abstract: Melissa Clark describes her experience picking grapes in Clos Roche Blanche vineyards in Loire Valley, France; recipes for hearty lunches served to workers who eat in communal style; photos (M)

snippet: Small Business Fighting Big Spam    Q. Do you have any suggestions for individuals and small businesses to combat spam?    A. Small businesses can have just as much unsolicited junk mail clogging their mail servers as do larger corporations, but o...
lead_paragraph: Small Business Fighting Big Spam
abstract: Small Business Fighting Big Spam    Q. Do you have any suggestions for individuals and small businesses to combat spam?    A. Small businesses can have just as much unsolicited junk mail clogging their mail servers as do larger corporations, but often lack the human and software resources of the bigger companies to fight it as effectively. But there are some options for fighting back.     Many Internet service providers or companies like Yahoo that host small-business Web sites and mail servers offer spam filtering at the server level, so you may want to check with your I.S.P. to see what's available. Providers like America Online and EarthLink already filter spam for individual e-mail accounts. If you are still getting a lot of junk in your mailbox, you might try adjusting the filter settings; check your service's Help guide for instructions.

headline.main: Small Business Fighting Big Spam

snippet: In the New Solar System, Pluto Is a 'Dwarf Planet'  In what many scientists described as a triumph of science over sentiment, Pluto has been demoted to the status of a ''dwarf planet.''     Astronomers, after years of wrangling, voted on a reclass...
lead_paragraph: In the New Solar System, Pluto Is a 'Dwarf Planet' In what many scientists described as a triumph of science over sentiment, Pluto has been demoted to the status of a "dwarf planet."
abstract: In the New Solar System, Pluto Is a 'Dwarf Planet'  In what many scientists described as a triumph of science over sentiment, Pluto has been demoted to the status of a ''dwarf planet.''     Astronomers, after years of wrangling, voted on a reclassification of the solar system. In the new system there are eight planets, at least three dwarf planets, and tens of thousands of so-called smaller solar system bodies, like comets and asteroids.      The outcome completed a stunning turnaround from a week ago, when the assembled astronomers were presented a proposal that would have increased the number of planets in the solar system to 12, including Pluto. PAGE A8    Maynard Ferguson Dies  A hard-working jazz bandleader and a trumpeter who made his name by hitting the highest of high notes, he was 78.   PAGE C10    Apple Recalls Batteries  Apple Computer said it was recalling 1.8 million battery packs from some models of its laptop computers because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire.   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1    Let Us Now Enlarge Famous Images  Digitally produced prints of classic photographs by Walker Evans, among them ''Roadside Stand Near Birmingham'' (1936), are now on display at the UBS Art Gallery in New York, raising some basic issues about the nature of photography. A review by Michael Kimmelman.   WEEKEND, PAGE E27    New Lures for Home Sales  Home sales are falling and inventory is building, but prices are rising as sellers come up with new sales incentives. lead_paragraph: Can Microsoft's new music player, Zune, knock the iPod off its perch as the must-have gadget of the new millennium? The early reviews have been negative: David Pogue of The New York Times, while admiring the portable music player's cool looks, effectively called it a me-too product, an effort by Microsoft to cash in on the market that its arch-rival, Apple, created with the iPod and still dominates. Zune's appearance and functionality will inevitably be compared with the iPod and, since the bar is set so high, will no doubt be found wanting. But product cycles turn fast, and thanks to the fragility of the iPod - and the unwillingness of Apple to invest much in repair service - there is a generation of consumers out there who now treat a $300 gadget as disposable. Then there is the junkyard littered with companies that underestimated the marketing power of Microsoft. This race may not be close yet, but it's still too young to call.

snippet: New CD by Rod Stewart is No 1 on Billboard chart with 184,000 copies sold; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Rod Stewart is on a roll. His four "Great American Songbook" albums, released one a year beginning in 2002, have sold a total of 8.4 million copies in the United States, and Vol. 3 of that series gave Mr. Stewart his first No. 1 in 26 years. His new album, "Still the Same Great American Rock Classics of Our Time" (J), with interpretations of songs by the Eagles, the Pretenders, Creedence Clearwater Revival and 10 others, opened at No. 1 with 184,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Evanescence's "Open Door" (Wind-Up), last week's chart-topper, fell to No. 2 with a 63 percent sales decline to 164,000. Lloyd Banks's "Rotten Apples" (G-Unit/Interscope) opened at No. 3 with 143,000 sales, and Jimmy Buffett's new "Take the Weather With You" (RCA) reached No. 4 with 121,000. Tony Bennett's "Duets: An American Classic" (RPM/Columbia) dropped one spot to No. 5 in its third week out, while the Killers dropped four to No. 6 with "Sam's Town" (Island/Def Jam) in its second. BEN SISARIO

snippet: Donald Hall, the new poet laureate, has lived for 30 years in the house where he was born in rural New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of poets: the ones who tell the stories, and the ones about whom the stories get told. Donald Hall — poet, critic, anthologist, poetry editor of The Paris Review during its early years, editor of "The Oxford Book of American Literary Anecdotes" and, as of last month, this country's poet laureate — is of the first group: warm chronicler or eager gossip, depending on the precise ratio of tribute to malice in any given tale. Anecdote-compilers like Hall often seem to want badly to cross over to the other group. But will John Ashbery write a poem in which Donald Hall shells pistachios in the offices of The Harvard Advocate, as a poem by Hall shows an undergraduate Ashbery to be doing? It's not likely, for reasons that tell us a lot about how much poetry has changed (in large part because of Ashbery's influence) since Hall came up through the ranks.
abstract: Donald Hall, the new poet laureate, has lived for 30 years in the house where he was born in rural New Hampshire.

snippet: The broadest government measure of house prices is calculated by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, the agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The idea at the heart of the index is a good one. It tries to do the same sor...
lead_paragraph: The broadest government measure of house prices is calculated by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, the agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The idea at the heart of the index is a good one. It tries to do the same sort of apples-to-apples analysis I described in this week's column [link to column], tracking individual houses over time to see how much their price has changed.
abstract: The broadest government measure of house prices is calculated by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, the agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The idea at the heart of the index is a good one. It tries to do the same sort of apples-to-apples analysis I described in this week's column [link to column], tracking individual houses over time to see how much their price has changed.     But it has three big weaknesses that end up making it much less useful than it could be. First, it excludes any mortgage over $417,000, because Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- the two big mortgage buyers -- don't own loans so large. Obviously, many mortgages on the coasts are bigger than that.

snippet: To the Editor: After reading ''Singapore: A Repressed City-State? Not in Its Kitchens'' (Next Stop, Oct. 1) by R. W. Apple Jr., I recalled that one of my most entertaining culinary experiences in Singapore took place at the city's zoo. It offered ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: After reading "Singapore: A Repressed City-State? Not in Its Kitchens" (Next Stop, Oct. 1) by R. W. Apple Jr., I recalled that one of my most entertaining culinary experiences in Singapore took place at the city's zoo. It offered breakfast with an orangutan. We sat at tables, eating bacon, eggs, etc., and then this beautiful animal lumbered down an aisle holding hands with her young offspring. Ah Meng, the mother orangutan, was seated on a small stage and given a huge bowl of fruit. She ate while taking care of Junior, who, like a human 2-year-old, was restless and wanted to leave. Periodically the mother would, with her long arm, reach out and pull the child back.
abstract: To the Editor: After reading ''Singapore: A Repressed City-State? Not in Its Kitchens'' (Next Stop, Oct. 1) by R. W. Apple Jr., I recalled that one of my most entertaining culinary experiences in Singapore took place at the city's zoo. It offered breakfast with an orangutan. We sat at tables, eating bacon, eggs, etc., and then this beautiful animal lumbered down an aisle holding hands with her young offspring. Ah Meng, the mother orangutan, was seated on a small stage and given a huge bowl of fruit. She ate while taking care of Junior, who, like a human 2-year-old, was restless and wanted to leave. Periodically the mother would, with her long arm, reach out and pull the child back.      The best part was going up to Ah Meng, one person at a time, and sitting next to her -- actually touching her -- and having a picture taken. She was so calm and well trained, even with Junior on her lap. The photograph of me, Ah Meng and Junior at the zoo is perhaps my most treasured souvenir.    Camille Terracciano  Long Branch, N.J.

The owners are no doubt referring to the yearlong construction project that transformed CoCo's, a watering hole for a young crowd, into this spectacular palace. snippet: Philadelphia Orchestra announces that it has become first major United States orchestra to open its own downloadable music store online; will offer more than dozen recent and archival performances with additions throughout coming season (S)
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Orchestra plans to announce today that it has become the first major United States orchestra to open its own downloadable music store online. While many orchestras sell downloads through third parties like Apple's iTunes service, the Philadelphia Orchestra intends to open its own store at www.thephiladelphiaorchestra.com featuring a free download of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony as performed last September with Christoph Eschenbach conducting. The site also intends to offer more than a dozen other recent and archival performances, with additions throughout the coming season. Full symphonies will generally cost about $5 in MP3 format and $6 in a higher-quality format called FLAC. To create the site, the orchestra has worked with nugs.net, an online music company best known for creating music download sites for rock acts. SETH SCHIESEL
abstract: Philadelphia Orchestra announces that it has become first major United States orchestra to open its own downloadable music store online; will offer more than dozen recent and archival performances with additions throughout coming season (S)

lead_paragraph: The parking lot is jammed at the Mall at Short Hills, and so is the counter at 40 Carrots on the third floor of Bloomingdale’s. There shoppers join the other regulars on the 20 stools. “It’s so addictive,” said Joyce Russo of Far Hills, talking about the coffee frozen yogurt, which is the big draw, with or without a splash of tangy plain yogurt ($3.75 small; $4.50 large). You can get it with a side of the fresh fruit of the day or with goodies like wildflower honey, walnuts, wheat germ, coconut, granola, melba (raspberry) sauce or sprinkles (fruit, $1.75; other sides, 95 cents).

snippet: Photos of Thai cooking tools that combine simplicity with beauty
lead_paragraph: 1. Sticky Rice Steamer Basket and Pot Sticky rice is the main starch of northern Thailand and the basis for many of Thailand's most popular desserts. To use, fill the pot with just enough water to steam. Place presoaked rice in the basket, cover with a saucepan lid and set over the pot. snippet: After a flurry of initial public offerings, blank-check firms seem to be slowing down.
lead_paragraph: In the first half of the year, investors seemed to have an insatiable appetite for special purpose acquisition companies, or SPAC’s. Also known as blank-check companies, these investment vehicles raise money for acquisitions, with no specific company — or sometimes even industry — in mind. Instead, maintaining a minimal staff, these firms look for deals, and if they find none, they promise to return most of their capital back to investors.
abstract: After a flurry of initial public offerings, blank-check firms seem to be slowing down.

headline.main: Blank-Check Offerings See a Slowdown

snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-11    Saddam Hussein Executed by Hanging  Saddam Hussein, the dictator who led Iraq through 24 years of brutality, war and bombast before American forces chased him from his capital city and captured him in a filthy pit near his h...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11
abstract: INTERNATIONAL A3-11    Saddam Hussein Executed by Hanging  Saddam Hussein, the dictator who led Iraq through 24 years of brutality, war and bombast before American forces chased him from his capital city and captured him in a filthy pit near his hometown, was hanged just before dawn during the morning call to prayer.  A1    The hanging ended the life of one of the most brutal tyrants in recent history. An obituary.  A10    Under heavy American pressure, the Iraqi government ordered two Iranians who had been detained in an American military raid to leave the country, Iraqi officials said, ending a bitter, nine-day political standoff.  A9    Young Africans Pack Schools  After two decades of sluggish growth in enrollment rates, sub-Saharan Africa's 45 countries find themselves with nearly 22 million more students who flooded their classrooms between 1999 and 2004. A1    Anti-Ethiopia Riots in Somalia  Anti-Ethiopia riots erupted in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, while masked gunmen emerged for the first time on the streets, a day after Ethiopian-backed troops captured the city from Islamist forces.  A4    Anorexia Debate in Brazil  In less than two months, four young women have died in widely publicized cases of anorexia in Brazil, causing a national debate about body image and eating disorders in a country where eliminating hunger among the millions of poor has traditionally been an important cause. A4    Belarus Challenges Its Big Ally  For Gazprom, the Russian energy monopoly, 2006 is ending as it began: in a dispute over prices and control of a pipeline in a neighboring country that is threatening the flow of natural gas to Europe. But this time, the price increase was levied on a Russian ally, Belarus.  A5    NATIONAL A12-16    Plan to Bolster Security In Harbors Falls Short  A Coast Guard plan to combat terrorism by creating the equivalent of an air traffic control system in the coastal waters off Miami, a test for a nationwide effort, has fallen far short of expectations.   A14    For Families, Costly Care  Families have always looked after their elderly loved ones. But never before in history has old age lasted so long or been so costly, compromising the retirement of baby boomers who were expecting inheritances rather than the shock of depleted savings.   A1    A Ray of Hope for Diabetics  There are at least 21 million diabetics in the United States, and health officials have begun to despair of combating the disease. But amid this gloom, a public health experiment in Asheville, N.C., is something of a ray of hope, an example of the battle that can win results and save lives in the face of a disease that has resisted quick-fix solutions.  A1    Private Service for the Fords  The first day of public mourning for former President Gerald R. Ford began in Palm Desert, Calif., much the way his post-White House life did here 30 years ago -- privately, absent of pomp, a small-town affair writ large by history more than family intent.   A13    Second Storm Hits Colorado  With the second of two snowstorms in back-to-back weeks swirling through Colorado, city officials and holiday travelers were finding coping with the second one incrementally easier.   A12    Pentagon Seeks More Money  The Pentagon is seeking nearly $100 billion for operations in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere, a request that would set an annual record for war-related spending.   A14    NEW YORK/REGION B1-7    Expensive and Unused, Security Doors Written Off  Nineteen technologically advanced security doors that New York City bought for nearly $1 million have spent five years inside a Rikers Island warehouse and will soon be headed for secret destinations in countries that are American allies in the war on terror. The doors are being given away after three failed attempts to auction them off. B1    Debit Card Helps Immigrants  New Labor, a nonprofit workers center in New Brunswick, N.J., is giving special debit cards to hundreds of immigrants who do not have checking accounts or credit cards and often face high check-cashing fees and frustrating obstacles in paying bills. B1    Religion Journal  B7    Neediest Cases  B2    SPORTSSATURDAY D1-8    Weiss Denies Link to Giants  Notre Dame's football coach Charlie Weis called his connection to a possible opening with the New York Giants ''ridiculous'' during a news conference in New Orleans. His strong language does not keep Weis from topping lists of potential replacements for Giants Coach Tom Coughlin, whose job is in jeopardy.  D1    OBITUARIES A17    Fernand Nault  One of Canada's foremost dance figures, who followed up a 21-year career at American Ballet Theater with artistic leadership of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens and with prolific choreography that ranged from ''The Nutcracker'' to ''Tommy,'' his 1970 hit rock ballet, he was 85, one day short of his 86th birthday.  A17    BUSINESS DAY C1-9    Apple Board Clears C.E.O.  Apple Computer said a committee had found that its chief executive was not responsible for the improper dating of stock options.  C1    AT&T Deal Approved  Federal regulators approved AT&T's $86 billion acquisition of BellSouth.  C1    Business Digest C2    EDITORIAL A18-19    Editorials: Sex offenders in exile; obstacles in Turkey's path; dealing with Congressman Inc.; Eleanor Randolph on the wild legacy of Bob Marshall. snippet: Canada’s Laurentian Mountains are the northern Francophone cousins of our own Adirondacks.
lead_paragraph: CANADA’S Laurentian Mountains are the northern Francophone cousins of our own Adirondacks. They’re not high (most top out around 2,500 feet), but come autumn, they are dramatic: Weeks before the colors in New England peak, these rounded mountains are quilted in blazing yellows and reds, the tops of the maples looking as though they’ve been dipped in paint, the deeper greens of evergreens providing a soothing counterpoint.

snippet: Not all holiday fruitcakes are dense, syrupy and destined for regifting. Consider the house-made panettone at Leonetti Pastry Shop in Greenvale. This traditional Italian confection, more of a sweet bread than a cake, is fragrant with candied orang...
lead_paragraph: Not all holiday fruitcakes are dense, syrupy and destined for regifting. Consider the house-made panettone at Leonetti Pastry Shop in Greenvale. This traditional Italian confection, more of a sweet bread than a cake, is fragrant with candied orange peel and studded with tiny raisins and toasted almonds; it has the airy texture and sweetness of soft challah. Delicate enough to toast for breakfast, the panettone comes plain ($16.50) or filled with Grand Marnier cream and covered with chocolate ganache ($24) for a decadent dessert.

snippet: CANADA'S Laurentian Mountains are the northern Francophone cousins of our own Adirondacks. They're not high (most top out around 2,500 feet), but come autumn, they are dramatic: Weeks before the colors in New England peak, these rounded mountains ...
lead_paragraph: CANADA'S Laurentian Mountains are the northern Francophone cousins of our own Adirondacks. They're not high (most top out around 2,500 feet), but come autumn, they are dramatic: Weeks before the colors in New England peak, these rounded mountains are quilted in blazing yellows and reds, the tops of the maples looking as though they've been dipped in paint, the deeper greens of evergreens providing a soothing counterpoint.
abstract: CANADA'S Laurentian Mountains are the northern Francophone cousins of our own Adirondacks. They're not high (most top out around 2,500 feet), but come autumn, they are dramatic: Weeks before the colors in New England peak, these rounded mountains are quilted in blazing yellows and reds, the tops of the maples looking as though they've been dipped in paint, the deeper greens of evergreens providing a soothing counterpoint.      And there's plenty for a family to do in these woods -- from a luge ride down the face of Mont Tremblant (the area's highest peak) to a quiet paddle on a Laurentian lac to apple picking with the Québécois. Don't forget to pack a pique-nique.    PICK YOUR OWN       In the southern Laurentian area, near St.-Joseph-du-Lac, there are dozens of orchards offering pick-your-own Spartans, Cortlands and even good old McIntoshes. But apples are just the beginning: On a weekend afternoon, traffic can back up along Autoroute 640 as cars stream toward the orchards. Guys with flags jockey to wave you into one of the competing establishments, and growers offer a circus of tractor rides, bouncy castles, petting zoos and pony rides (not to mention the ovens turning out pies).

snippet: Apples to Apples     For years, suspicion has been growing in the orchards of the Wenatchee Valley in Washington State and in the food industry at large that fruit, nature's original hand-held convenience food, is simply too poorly designed for to...
lead_paragraph: Apples to Apples
abstract: Apples to Apples     For years, suspicion has been growing in the orchards of the Wenatchee Valley in Washington State and in the food industry at large that fruit, nature's original hand-held convenience food, is simply too poorly designed for today's busy eater. The apple, for instance: whatever it has meant to Americans over the years -- from mom's pie to the little red schoolhouse -- getting our mouths around one has also apparently meant some unspoken aggravation. Next to a banana or a grape, it's a daunting strongbox of a fruit, prohibitively so for anyone with braces or dentures; and even if you can break in, there's no guarantee a given apple will eat as sweet as it looks.

snippet: APPELBAUM--Gertrude Helen. passed away on July 17. She was born February 20, 1908 to Celia Cohen and David Appelbaum and is survived by her sister Sylvia and brother Burton. As casting director in the Broadway theater, where Gertrude was known as ...
lead_paragraph: APPELBAUM--Gertrude Helen. passed away on July 17. She was born February 20, 1908 to Celia Cohen and David Appelbaum and is survived by her sister Sylvia and brother Burton. As casting director in the Broadway theater, where Gertrude was known as Apple, she had an eye for young, untried talent, many of whom obtained their first acting Jobs through her. Her major discovery was the late Walter Matthau. Messages of condolence may be sent to 55 Central Park West (5G), New York, N.Y. 10023.
abstract: APPELBAUM--Gertrude Helen. passed away on July 17. She was born February 20, 1908 to Celia Cohen and David Appelbaum and is survived by her sister Sylvia and brother Burton. Her major discovery was the late Walter Matthau. Messages of condolence may be sent to 55 Central Park West (5G), New York, N.Y. 10023.

snippet: NOON (AMC) MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET (1947). This colorized version of the Macy's Santa comedy, starring Maureen O'Hara, Edmund Gwenn and Natalie Wood (above, with Gwenn), will be shown every two hours until 4 a.m. tomorrow morning -- just in time fo...
lead_paragraph: NOON (AMC) MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET (1947). This colorized version of the Macy's Santa comedy, starring Maureen O'Hara, Edmund Gwenn and Natalie Wood (above, with Gwenn), will be shown every two hours until 4 a.m. tomorrow morning -- just in time for deliveries to true believers.
abstract: NOON (AMC) MIRACLE ON 34TH STREET (1947). This colorized version of the Macy's Santa comedy, starring Maureen O'Hara, Edmund Gwenn and Natalie Wood (above, with Gwenn), will be shown every two hours until 4 a.m. tomorrow morning -- just in time for deliveries to true believers.    4 P.M. (NBC) HILTON FAMILY SKATING AND GYMNASTICS SPECTACULAR -- Parallel bars and a balance beam on the ice? This hybrid sporting event, taped in October at the Rose Quarter in Portland, Ore., combines skating and gymnastic routines in the same rink. Gymnasts include Paul and Morgan Hamm, Shannon Miller and Dominique Moceanu. Rudy Gallindo, Brian Orser, Michael Weiss and Rory Flack Burghart are among the skaters. Carly Patterson, who earned an all-around Olympic gold in 2004 before going on to sing on ''Celebrity Duets,'' performs during the show.    7 P.M. (SportsNet New York) SCARLET NIGHTS ON SNY -- Relive winning moments from the 2006 Rutgers football season in four specials on four consecutive nights, starting this evening. Gary Apple is host.    8 P.M. (ABC Family) SANTA CLAUS IS COMIN' TO TOWN -- It's Christmas all night long, starting with this animated classic featuring the voice of Fred Astaire as a very wise mailman. At 9, Mickey Rooney and Shirley Booth star in ''The Year Without a Santa Claus,'' about a dejected Santa who takes off the day before Christmas, followed at 10 by ''Rudolph's Shiny New Year,'' with Red Skelton and Frank Gorshin, in which the rednosed reindeer journeys through a midnight fog to find Happy, the New Year baby.    8 P.M. (Showtime) LIFE AFTER TOMORROW -- For some, it's a hard knock life. For others, the sun came out -- and stayed out. Gil Cates Jr. and Julie Stevens track down actresses who have played orphans in the musical ''Annie'' and find out what happened to their dreams.    8 P.M. (TBS) A CHRISTMAS STORY (1983). Bring out the popcorn and hunker down under your blanket for this 24-hour marathon of the tale of Ralphie, who only wants a Red Ryder air rifle for Christmas.    9 P.M. (13) THE NUTCRACKER WITH MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV -- This holiday bonbon, performed in 1977 by the American Ballet Theater with Mr. Baryshnikov in the title role, Gelsey Kirkland as Clara and Alexander Minz as Drosselmeyer, couldn't get much sweeter. And nearly 30 years later, it's still timeless.    12:15 A.M. (Turner Classic Movies) SWING TIME (1936). Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers do it in the snow (and high above Manhattan, left). Listen for ''A Fine Romance'' and ''The Way You Look Tonight.''   KATHRYN SHATTUCK

lead_paragraph: HOME, sweet home is becoming, finally, home, smart home. The family group is becoming the family network: computers and appliances and services are shared and distributed through the house. Nesting has gone digital as Americans bring the world home to work and play.

snippet: A front-page article yesterday about Apple Computer's introduction of software enabling some Macintosh models to run the Microsoft Windows operating system referred incorrectly in some copies to the typical retail price of Windows XP. It is $199 o...
lead_paragraph: A front-page article yesterday about Apple Computer's introduction of software enabling some Macintosh models to run the Microsoft Windows operating system referred incorrectly in some copies to the typical retail price of Windows XP. It is $199 or more, not $99. The article also misstated the extent of Apple's promotional efforts. The new software, Boot Camp, was indeed promoted on the front page of Apple's Web site, in one of several alternating headlines at the bottom of the screen.

snippet: To the Editor: I hope Heather Timmons, who wrote ''Going to Cornwall'' (July 30), will be able to go to Cornwall again and have a genuine Cornish pasty made by a Cornish farmer's wife or a member of the Women's Institute there. It is made with a c...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I hope Heather Timmons, who wrote "Going to Cornwall" (July 30), will be able to go to Cornwall again and have a genuine Cornish pasty made by a Cornish farmer's wife or a member of the Women's Institute there. It is made with a circle of firm pastry wrapped over and crimped together, and inside there is a mix of good-quality steak, potatoes and finely chopped onions. It does not take long to cook, but it is very hot inside the crust, and it is juicy and delicious. It travels well down the mine or across the fields or on a picnic.

snippet: Crispy Green in West Orange, NJ, packages freeze-dried fruits in single-serving bags; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: An apple a day -- or a peach or a couple of apricots for that matter -- is easy to eat when it comes in the form of freeze-dried, nibble-size slices made by Crispy Green in West Orange, N.J. Single-serving bags contain fruit with all the moisture removed, but the flavor intact. They're terrific for hikers, to add to morning cereal, and for camp and school lunchboxes. Each bag provides 35 to 40 calories and some vitamins and fiber. They are sold for around $1.75 a package at many stores, including the Amish Market stores and Really Cool Foods in Manhattan, Garden of Eden in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and Old Town Pharmacy on Staten Island. A six-pack is $7.99 at crispygreen.com. FOOD STUFF

(13) A TRIBUTE TO JAMES TAYLOR Last Feb. 6, at the Los Angeles Convention Center, Mr. Taylor was honored by MusiCares, the philanthropic foundation of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, as person of the year. This "Great Performances" special includes renditions of Mr. Taylor's hits by David Crosby, Sheryl Crow, Carole King, Alison Krauss, Bonnie Raitt, Sting, Keith Urban, the Dixie Chicks and Bruce Springsteen. "It's strange to be at an event like this and still be alive," Mr. Taylor says before closing the evening with his own variation on "How Sweet It Is."

snippet: Editorial on Iowa race for secretary of agriculture between Bill Northey and Denise O'Brien says sharpest difference between two candidates is ability of counties and towns to restrict feedlots and farm operations that hold huge numbers of animals...
lead_paragraph: There is a governor's race going on in Iowa -- Culver vs. Nussle, a tossup -- but the race to watch is the one for secretary of agriculture. Both candidates support ethanol production, and who wouldn't when ethanol has given Iowa the lowest fuel prices in the nation? But otherwise they are about as different as it is possible to be and still be an Iowan for agriculture. Bill Northey, a Republican, farms corn and soybeans and has been endorsed by the Farm Bureau. His Democratic opponent is Denise O'Brien, who raises poultry, apples and strawberries. She and her husband farm organically, and her campaign vehicle is a green biodiesel school bus.
abstract: Editorial on Iowa race for secretary of agriculture between Bill Northey and Denise O'Brien says sharpest difference between two candidates is ability of counties and towns to restrict feedlots and farm operations that hold huge numbers of animals; supports O'Brien's argument that there should be state regulation but that communities should have voice too

headline.print_headline: A Farm Race in Iowa

snippet: CRUNCH TIME AT ABC -- On Wednesday, the ''Today'' show on NBC -- the ratings leader in morning TV -- will introduce a new co-host, Meredith Vieira, who is succeeding Katie Couric. At ABC's ''Good Morning America'' the senior executive producer, Ji...
lead_paragraph: CRUNCH TIME AT ABC -- On Wednesday, the "Today" show on NBC -- the ratings leader in morning TV -- will introduce a new co-host, Meredith Vieira, who is succeeding Katie Couric. At ABC's "Good Morning America" the senior executive producer, Jim Murphy, will use the transition at "Today" to try wooing enough people over to ABC to erase what was a nearly 900,000-viewer advantage. Mr. Murphy is also trying to make sure that loyal viewers do not abandon "Good Morning America" as it goes through a major transition of its own: the departure of Charles Gibson. [Page C1.]
abstract: CRUNCH TIME AT ABC -- On Wednesday, the ''Today'' show on NBC -- the ratings leader in morning TV -- will introduce a new co-host, Meredith Vieira, who is succeeding Katie Couric. At ABC's ''Good Morning America'' the senior executive producer, Jim Murphy, will use the transition at ''Today'' to try wooing enough people over to ABC to erase what was a nearly 900,000-viewer advantage. Mr. Murphy is also trying to make sure that loyal viewers do not abandon ''Good Morning America'' as it goes through a major transition of its own: the departure of Charles Gibson. [Page C1.]    CARTOONS ON THE CELLPHONE -- ''Lil' Bush,'' a cartoon show about the adventures of a grade-school version of President Bush and his pals made its debut on Amp'd cellphones on Sept. 1. Six five-minute episodes are to be released every week for six weeks, and each is to be available on demand afterward. The series is another example of cellphone service companies looking to attract subscribers -- and draw more money out of existing ones -- with original content, especially video. [C5.]    SHOWTIME AT APPLE -- On Tuesday, Apple will hold another of Steven P. Jobs's marketing events to unveil what is expected to be his next campaign: to transform the distribution of movies as thoroughly as he has revolutionized the recording industry with iTunes. [C1.]    GAMES FOR CASUAL PLAYERS -- Video game makers are starting to go after the casual or coffee-break gamer, who indulges in short-term play and not necessarily of the action-packed genre. [C7.]    THE MARKETING OF 9/11 -- Marketers and the news media, acutely aware of the sensitivities surrounding Sept. 11, 2001, are still trying to determine where the fine line lies between commemoration and exploitation. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    SHOPPING AND SOCIALIZING -- Several sites on the Internet -- like ThisNext.com, Kaboodle.com, Wists.com and StyleHive.com -- are spearheading a new category of e-commerce called social shopping that tries to combine two favorite online activities: shopping and social networking. Like MySpace, the sites are designed for browsing and blogging, with some shopping-related technology twists included. ''Online shopping is more accurately described as purchasing, because it's so directed and goal-specific,'' said Gordon Gould, ThisNext's chief executive, left. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.]    THE PRETEXT MASQUERADE -- At the heart of the controversy swirling around Hewlett-Packard is the technique known as pretexting -- obtaining the calling records of people under a pretext, like masquerading as a customer. The shady subculture of pretexting has been getting renewed attention since it came to light last week that a subcontractor for an investigative firm working for H.P. used pretexting to obtain the call records of company directors and reporters. [C1.]    FOR OPEC, PRICE CONCERNS -- What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet today, the major question on delegates' minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but just how far they might drop. Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the last month, driving down the retail price of gasoline and providing some relief for consumers. [C1.]    REGIONAL NEWS AND LAYOFFS -- On Thursday, The Dallas Morning News is expected to announce that more than 100 newsroom staffers have accepted buyout packages, shrinking the size of the staff by slightly less than 20 percent. As a result, what was once a newspaper with national reach will focus mainly on local and regional news. [C4.]    RESTRUCTURING IN ITALY -- Telecom Italia, the telecommunications company, said yesterday that its board would discuss the restructuring of its mobile and fixed-line phone operations today, a move that may presage the sale of all or part of its mobile arm, TIM. [C4.]

President Bush also has dodged the full force of public outrage because the victims were foreigners, mostly Muslims, captured in what he has painted as a war against Islamic terrorists bent on destroying America.

snippet: Apples to Apples     For years, suspicion has been growing in the orchards of the Wenatchee Valley in Washington State and in the food industry at large that fruit, nature's original hand-held convenience food, is simply too poorly designed for to...
lead_paragraph: Apples to Apples
abstract: Apples to Apples     For years, suspicion has been growing in the orchards of the Wenatchee Valley in Washington State and in the food industry at large that fruit, nature's original hand-held convenience food, is simply too poorly designed for today's busy eater. The apple, for instance: whatever it has meant to Americans over the years -- from mom's pie to the little red schoolhouse -- getting our mouths around one has also apparently meant some unspoken aggravation. Next to a banana or a grape, it's a daunting strongbox of a fruit, prohibitively so for anyone with braces or dentures; and even if you can break in, there's no guarantee a given apple will eat as sweet as it looks.

snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Peace in Darfur at Risk, As New Conflict Looms  Negotiations over a proposed United Nations force to shore up the shaky peace in Darfur have limped along with no sign of compromise. The opposing sides in the conflict now s...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14
abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Peace in Darfur at Risk, As New Conflict Looms  Negotiations over a proposed United Nations force to shore up the shaky peace in Darfur have limped along with no sign of compromise. The opposing sides in the conflict now seem headed toward a large-scale military confrontation.    A1    Allies Ready Sanctions for Iran  With Iran defying the deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council that would begin by restricting imports of nuclear material.    A1    52 Die in Iraq Sectarian Attacks  Shootings and hidden bombs at an Iraqi market, a gas station and an army recruiting center killed at least 52 people, continuing a wave of sectarian violence that has claimed roughly 200 lives this week. Despite the spike in violence, the top United States general in Iraq said Iraqi forces could take over security as early as next year.    A10    Israel Spurns U.N. Request  Israel's prime minister, Ehud Olmert, rebuffed a request from the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, for even a partial lifting of the seven-week-old blockade of Lebanon to allow Beirut's airport to resume normal operations.    A12    A continuing Israeli offensive in the Gaza Strip killed nine people, including four civilians, one of them a 14-year-old. Israelis announced the discovery of a 150-yard tunnel stretching from a house toward the Karni cargo crossing, which Israel had closed due to security alerts, between Gaza and Israel.    A14    Sri Lanka Blamed in Aid Killings  Swedish-led cease-fire monitors accused the Sri Lankan government security forces of killing 17 aid workers in the town of Mutur in one of the worst attacks against humanitarian workers worldwide in recent years. The monitors cited several reasons, including confidential conversations with ''highly reliable sources'' that they said pointed to the culpability of the security forces.    A12    ARTS   E1-10    Fake Letter in Poet's Biography  A. N. Wilson, one of London's most visible literary figures, was duped into printing a made-up love letter in ''Betjeman,'' his book about the British poet laureate John Betjeman. In the fake document, the first letters of each sentence, except the first, spell out an insulting sentence that starts with Mr. Wilson's name and ends with a vulgarity.    E1    Chicago Critic Criticized  Hedy Weiss, a theater critic for The Chicago Sun-Times for more than 20 years, is facing criticism herself after publishing scathing comments about a weekend-long festival of musicals in progress, called Stages. Edward Albee and Tony Kushner are among those who have voiced their objections.    E3    NATIONAL   A16-22    California Announces Deal To Curb Greenhouse Gases  California's political leaders announced an agreement that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change.    A1    Some Colleges Ignoring SAT's  For many small liberal arts colleges the SAT may have outlived its usefulness. More than a quarter of the U.S. News and World Report's Top 100 liberal arts colleges have made college admissions exams optional.    A1    Destruction of Ballots Delayed  With paper ballots from the 2004 presidential election in Ohio scheduled to be destroyed, the Ohio secretary of state said that he would move to delay the destruction. Since the election, questions have been raised about how votes were tallied.    A16    Los Angeles School Overhaul  Los Angeles passed the reins of its troubled public schools to the mayor in measure passed by the State Legislature. But the legislation gives little real power to the mayor, and, school governance experts said, lacks accountability.    A16    Conservation Policy Adopted  The National Park Service will adopt a policy emphasizing conservation of natural resources over recreation when they are in conflict.    A16    NEW YORK/REGION   B1-8    Plan for Accused Priests: Be Monitored, or Resign  Cardinal Edward M. Egan, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has a new plan for dealing with priests who, although credibly accused of sexually abusing children, cannot be defrocked for various reasons. They can spend the rest of their lives in closely supervised housing, or they can leave the priesthood.    B1    Challenge to Housing Goals  The Bloomberg administration's aim to preserve much of the city's moderate-income housing amid skyrocketing prices is facing serious challenges, as illustrated by the possible sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village along the East River, long a bastion of middle-class residents.    B1    Lawyer Charged in Killing  A lawyer in Fairfield, Conn., has been charged with murder after the police say he climbed through his neighbor's window and stabbed him to death shortly after hearing that the neighbor had molested the lawyer's 2-year-old daughter.    B1    OBITUARIES   A22-23    Glenn Ford  A laconic, soft-spoken actor with an easy smile who played leading roles in many westerns, melodramas and romantic films from the early 1940's through the 60's, he was 90.    A22    BUSINESS DAY   C1-14    Apple's Boardroom Move  When Eric E. Schmidt, Google's chief executive, was named to Apple Computer's board, it touched off speculation about the motives of Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs.    A1    Economy Grows Stronger  The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported.    C1    Business Digest   C2    EDITORIAL   A24-25    Editorials: Stars in their eyes; raising nicotine doses, on the sly; homestretch for a hack; Andrew Rosenthal on the silence in the streets.    Column: David Brooks.    Bridge   E6  TV Listings   E9  Crossword   E4  Weather   B9

snippet: 8 P.M. (13) A TRIBUTE TO JAMES TAYLOR  Last Feb. 6, at the Los Angeles Convention Center, Mr. Taylor was honored by MusiCares, the Philanthropic foundation of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, as person of the year. This ''Great...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) A TRIBUTE TO JAMES TAYLOR Last Feb. 6, at the Los Angeles Convention Center, Mr. Taylor was honored by MusiCares, the Philanthropic foundation of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, as person of the year. This "Great Performances" special includes renditions of Mr. Taylor's hits by David Crosby, Sheryl Crow, Carole King, Alison Krauss, Bonnie Raitt, Sting, Keith Urban, the Dixie Chicks and Bruce Springsteen. "It's strange to be at an event like this and still be alive," Mr. Taylor (above) says before closing the evening with his own variation on "How Sweet It Is."
abstract: 8 P.M. (13) A TRIBUTE TO JAMES TAYLOR  Last Feb. 6, at the Los Angeles Convention Center, Mr. Taylor was honored by MusiCares, the Philanthropic foundation of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, as person of the year. This ''Great Performances'' special includes renditions of Mr. Taylor's hits by David Crosby, Sheryl Crow, Carole King, Alison Krauss, Bonnie Raitt, Sting, Keith Urban, the Dixie Chicks and Bruce Springsteen. ''It's strange to be at an event like this and still be alive,'' Mr. Taylor (above) says before closing the evening with his own variation on ''How Sweet It Is.''    8 P.M. (11) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL  The slender models' nerves wear thinner still in Barcelona, where one breaks down after her flamenco dancing is found to be less than provocative, or at least not provocative in the right way. Later, Tyra Banks directs a photo shoot in which the women must float in a pool of ice water.    8 P.M. (History) MODERN MARVELS  Forget those apples: it's a daily glass of wine that is now said to keep the doctor away. And these days, more wine is consumed than ever before. This episode travels to France, to the Moët vineyards and the Tour d'Argent restaurant, to trace the history of wine while examining the technological advances -- like aerial imaging and infrared photography -- that enable the country's vineyards to be fruitful and multiply.    8 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER  Al Roker and Ann Curry help flip the switch at this 74th annual treelighting celebration (right, shown last year) in the heart of Manhattan. Christina Aguilera, Sting, Enya, Taylor Hicks, John Legend, Martina McBride, Sarah McLachlan and Lionel Richie perform current hits and holiday favorites.    9 P.M. (CBS) CRIMINAL MINDS  Gideon (Mandy Patinkin) and his team investigate murdered prostitutes in Washington. If only that congresswoman would get out of their way.    9 P.M. (Discovery) MYTHBUSTERS  Jamie and Adam test three myths about guns.    9 P.M. (ABC) DAY BREAK  And the day goes on, and on. Hopper (Taye Diggs) begins to figure out what his partner, Andrea (Victoria Pratt), did to get into hot water with Internal Affairs.    9 P.M. (NBC) THE BIGGEST LOSER  The contestants learn about cooking low-cal holiday dinners. The evening's challenge requires competitors (right) to race around a track carrying their original body weights.   KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Mr. Jeffs, 50, is wanted in Utah and Arizona on charges of arranging marriages between underage girls and older men. He has been on the F.B.I.'s 10 most wanted list for four months.    PAGE A12    Longer SAT, Lower Scores  The average score on the reading and math parts of the newly expanded SAT showed the largest decline in 31 years, the College Board reported. The average reading score fell 5 points, to 503 out of 800, and the average math score fell 2 points, to 518.    PAGE A12    The Comfort Appetizer  Pigs in a blanket are being welcomed at the most elegant affairs these days. Also: R.W. snippet: A new album does some unfamiliar things to some very familiar songs.
lead_paragraph: THE latest Beatles collection, “Love” (Capitol), isn’t a retrospective: it’s a recombination. After the innumerable reissues, archival gleanings and rescued live recordings that have made the Beatles catalog an endlessly milked cash cow for EMI Records and the Beatles’ own Apple Corps, the “Love” CD and its surround-sound DVD mix, both due for release on Tuesday, are different. Instead of simply collecting Beatles tracks, “Love” actively manipulates them.
abstract: A new album does some unfamiliar things to some very familiar songs.

snippet: M H Reed reviews Jackie's Bistro restaurant in Eastchester, NY; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH I know of no bistro in France that would be tricked out like Jackie's, its serendipitous clutter has some charm. It definitely works for me -- and would have worked even better had the food and service been more like what I remember from 1998, when Jackie's was still jubilant over France's winning the World Cup and bright soccer jerseys and flags fluttered on the walls. But the afterglow dimmed, and the symbols of victory were put away. With their removal, it seems, this restaurant, owned by Jacqueline and Joel Huchet, also lost some of the enthusiasm it once exhibited in service and at the stove.

snippet: There were always two narratives offered about the change in American torture policy after 9/11. The first story — told by the Bush administration — was that the Geneva Conventions mandating humane treatment of war prisoners could be unilaterally ...
lead_paragraph: There were always two narratives offered about the change in American torture policy after 9/11. The first story — told by the Bush administration — was that the Geneva Conventions mandating humane treatment of war prisoners could be unilaterally suspended by the president for the duration of the war on terror. But, this story continued, our prisoners were nevertheless well treated, as required by honor if not by law; only a few renegade bad apples abused detainees.

snippet: AOL is about to introduce a vastly expanded online video area, an important part of its effort to attract a new audience to replace that of its rapidly declining subscription service.     AOL has long been a leader in producing video programming, ...
lead_paragraph: AOL is about to introduce a vastly expanded online video area, an important part of its effort to attract a new audience to replace that of its rapidly declining subscription service.
abstract: AOL is about to introduce a vastly expanded online video area, an important part of its effort to attract a new audience to replace that of its rapidly declining subscription service.     AOL has long been a leader in producing video programming, and video has been a prominent feature of its AOL.com portal. The new service, which will begin public testing on Friday, adds a range of new free programs. For the first time it will also sell commercial-free downloads, competing with Apple's iTunes Music Store and Google Video.

snippet: WARNING FROM DELL -- Dell warned that its quarterly earnings would be lower than expected, a result of price cutting aimed at stemming the decline in its market share for personal computers. [C1.]    REACTION TO WACHOVIA DEAL -- After Wachovia ann...
lead_paragraph: WARNING FROM DELL -- Dell warned that its quarterly earnings would be lower than expected, a result of price cutting aimed at stemming the decline in its market share for personal computers. [C1.]
abstract: WARNING FROM DELL -- Dell warned that its quarterly earnings would be lower than expected, a result of price cutting aimed at stemming the decline in its market share for personal computers. [C1.]    REACTION TO WACHOVIA DEAL -- After Wachovia announced that it would acquire Golden West Financial Corporation of California in a deal valued at $25.5 billion, Wachovia's stock fell 6.7 percent. Investors are concerned that California's red-hot housing market is poised to cool. [C1.]    COMEDOWN FOR HOME SELLERS -- As higher interest rates crimp housing demand in cities that only a year ago saw fierce bidding wars among numerous buyers, sellers are begrudgingly lowering their prices to drum up interest. [C1.]    WARNER'S WEB DEAL -- Warner Brothers plans to announce that it will make hundreds of movies and television shows available for purchase over the Internet using BitTorrent software, which is widely used to illegally download movies and other copyrighted material. [C1.]    OIL DRILLING DEBATE -- A growing number of lawmakers and business leaders in the United States are complaining that the decades-old ban against drilling in coastal waters is driving up domestic energy costs and giving two of America's chief economic competitors -- China and India -- access to energy in Cuba at the United States' expense. [A1.]    STATES AND IMMIGRATION -- Lawmakers in dozens of state legislatures, have proposed hundreds of measures on the issue this year, most aimed at restricting illegal immigrants' access to public benefits and drivers' licenses. But few bills have made it into law, meeting determined resistance from unlikely alliances. [A24.]    ANOTHER MINING BID -- Inco's faltering effort to acquire its Canadian nickel mining rival Falconbridge became further clouded when Inco attracted an unsolicited offer from Teck Cominco. [C9.]    APPLE DECISION -- Apple Computer won the right to keep its logo on its iTunes digital music store when a British judge rejected the claims of Apple Corps, the guardian of the Beatles' musical interests, over the use of the apple logo. [C3.]    WEB MONITORS IN CHINA -- The Chinese government is mobilizing university students to help it manage the task of censoring the Web. [A3.]    GLOBAL RATE INCREASES -- The Federal Reserve will almost certainly increase interest rates by another quarter-point this week, and investors will search for clues about a pause in further rate increases. But a growing number of economists wonder if changes in the global economy could keep pushing up long-term interest rates long after the Fed stops raising its benchmark rate. [C1.]    THE ONES WHO DIDN'T SPEAK -- Some of the most important witnesses in the Enron case may well be some high-level managers who never appeared before the jury. [C1.]    TOYOTA EXECUTIVE LEAVES POST -- A Toyota executive accused of sexual harassment by his former assistant has left his job and will not take a new post until the situation is resolved, Toyota said Monday night. The executive, Hideaki Otaka, president and chief of Toyota Motor North America had planned to leave next month for a job in Japan. [C7.]    NO MALPRACTICE LIMIT -- The Senate again rebuffed a Republican attempt to limit jury awards in medical malpractice cases, taking the issue off the agenda for this year. [A25.]    STOCKS ARE MUTED -- The Dow Jones industrial average gained 4.56 points, to close at 11,582.30. The S.& P. 500 lost 1.04 points, to close at 1,324.72. The Nasdaq composite index added 2.39 points, to 2,344.96. [C11.]    WORRIES OVER WINE -- Winemakers in Germany are among those who are concerned that a recent agreement between the European Union and the United States gives too many advantages to American methods of large-scale wine production. [A4.]

snippet: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend...
lead_paragraph: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July “catastrophic.” Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.

snippet: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the week...
lead_paragraph: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July "catastrophic." Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.
abstract: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July ''catastrophic.'' Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.    TOWARD A BETTER CANAL -- Panamanians will vote in a referendum over whether to add a third set of locks to the Panama Canal (Sunday). The country took over the canal from the United States in 1999, and although there seems to be broad agreement that the project would help bring the outdated canal up to modern standards -- making room for larger ships, for instance, and cutting wait times for vessels lingering offshore -- many Panamanians are skeptical. There is concern, among other things, that the government's $5.2 billion price tag for the seven-year project is a low estimate. Meanwhile, Nicaragua's president has proposed spending $18 billion to build a wider alternative to the Panama Canal.    INDICATORS DU JOUR -- For economic indicators, the focus this week will be on inflation, with the release of the Producer Price Index for September (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for September (Wednesday). Other reports scheduled for release this week are industrial production and capacity utilization for September (Tuesday); housing starts for September (Wednesday); and leading economic indicators (Thursday).    A MONSTER EARNINGS WEEK -- Earnings season gets into full swing with some big names in the Dow. Highlights will include: Intel, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, McClatchy, Merrill Lynch, Motorola and Yahoo (Tuesday); AMR, Apple, Boston Scientific, eBay, General Dynamics and J. P. Morgan Chase (Wednesday); Bank of America, Citigroup, Coca-Cola, Dow Jones, Google, Honeywell, Eli Lilly, McDonald's, Nokia, Southwest Airlines, the Tribune Company and Wyeth (Thursday); and 3M and Merck (Friday).
