snippet: 8 P.M. (TLC) ASHLEY JUDD AND YOUTHAIDS: CONFRONTING THE PANDEMIC -- In 2002 Ms. Judd (above right) became the goodwill ambassador for YouthAIDS, an organization that promotes AIDS prevention and treatment. In this special she travels through Centr...
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TLC) ASHLEY JUDD AND YOUTHAIDS: CONFRONTING THE PANDEMIC -- In 2002 Ms. Judd (above right) became the goodwill ambassador for YouthAIDS, an organization that promotes AIDS prevention and treatment. In this special she travels through Central America with her friend Salma Hayek, where they try to get out the message that young people can change their future by changing the behavior that puts them at risk of infection. Juanes, the Latin rock star and a YouthAIDS ambassador to his region, follows along.
abstract: 8 P.M. (TLC) ASHLEY JUDD AND YOUTHAIDS: CONFRONTING THE PANDEMIC -- In 2002 Ms. Judd (above right) became the goodwill ambassador for YouthAIDS, an organization that promotes AIDS prevention and treatment. In this special she travels through Central America with her friend Salma Hayek, where they try to get out the message that young people can change their future by changing the behavior that puts them at risk of infection. Juanes, the Latin rock star and a YouthAIDS ambassador to his region, follows along.    7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) BAH-HUMDUCK! A LOONEY TUNES CHRISTMAS -- Daffy Duck, as a modern-day Scrooge, tries to find the spirit of giving. Gordon Goodwin and his Big Phat Band provide the jazzy backup.    7 P.M. (Cinemax) POSITIVELY NAKED -- For nearly a decade, Spencer Tunick has challenged beliefs about nudity, privacy, sexuality and body image in his photographs of naked men and women. In this documentary he assembles 85 H.I.V.-positive people in downtown Manhattan and puts a human face on an illness that is still misunderstood.    8 P.M. (CBS) ICE WARS 2006: U.S.A. VS. THE WORLD -- On our side, the skaters Brian Boitano, Michael Weiss, Rory Flack Burghart and Angela Nikodinov; on theirs, Alexei Yagudin, Kurt Browning, Oksana Baiul and Shizuka Arakawa.    8 P.M. (ABC) THE POLAR EXPRESS (2004). A train conductor guides a boy who doubts the existence of Santa Claus by locomotive to the North Pole in this noirish animated film, based on the children's book by Chris Van Allsburg. Tom Hanks (above) lends his voice to five characters; he also wore a hat during recording that transmitted his movements to create templates for the characters' actions.    9 P.M. (Fox) TRADING SPOUSES: MEET YOUR NEW MOMMY -- Tonight one mother must attend Bible class with her host family while the other tries to instill Christianity in a household of nonbelievers.    10 P.M. (Showtime) MASTERS OF HORROR -- Dario Argento directs ''Pelts,'' in which a fur trader, played by Meat Loaf, who wants to make the perfect raccoon coat uses some supernatural hides that get violent with those who want to wear animal skins.    11 P.M. (BBC America) HARDWARE -- Boys and bolts. Need we say more? Martin Freeman stars in this new comedy about four young men working in an English hardware store.    11 P.M. (SportsNet New York) SNY SPOTLIGHT -- Joe Namath, the Jets legend, talks with Gary Apple (near right, with Mr. Namath) about his famous Super Bowl guarantee, playing football at Alabama, his struggle with alcoholism and his life today.   KATHRYN SHATTUCK

snippet: AFTER we had driven just a few hours along the Hood River Fruit Loop in northwest Oregon, the inside of our car already showed telltale signs of a midsummer's cherry binge. The seats were awash in a crinkly sea of tiny brown paper bags that riffle...
lead_paragraph: AFTER we had driven just a few hours along the Hood River Fruit Loop in northwest Oregon, the inside of our car already showed telltale signs of a midsummer's cherry binge. The seats were awash in a crinkly sea of tiny brown paper bags that riffled in the mountain breeze. Mis-spit pits, once shiny and slick, fused themselves to the super-heated plastic dashboard.
abstract: AFTER we had driven just a few hours along the Hood River Fruit Loop in northwest Oregon, the inside of our car already showed telltale signs of a midsummer's cherry binge. The seats were awash in a crinkly sea of tiny brown paper bags that riffled in the mountain breeze. Mis-spit pits, once shiny and slick, fused themselves to the super-heated plastic dashboard.     ''Hand me the Lamberts, will you?'' John Heili, an architect who lives in Portland and our driver for the day, called out, asking for his favorite variety of cherry.

headline.main: In Oregon, a Cherry Jubilee
headline.print_headline: In Oregon, A Cherry Jubilee

snippet: THE TIME EVOLUTION -- For most of the 20th century, under the influence of its founder, Henry R. Luce, Time magazine spoke in a single authoritative voice that reflected the world back to its readers. Now Richard Stengel, the new managing editor o...
lead_paragraph: THE TIME EVOLUTION -- For most of the 20th century, under the influence of its founder, Henry R. Luce, Time magazine spoke in a single authoritative voice that reflected the world back to its readers. Now Richard Stengel, the new managing editor of Time, wants to change the metaphor. His plan is to fill the pages of Time with more essays and news analysis, give the magazine a sharper point of view and draw more brand-name journalists into the fold. If this sounds familiar, it may be that Mr. Stengel wants Time to be a little more like its chief rival, Newsweek. [Page C1.]
abstract: THE TIME EVOLUTION -- For most of the 20th century, under the influence of its founder, Henry R. Luce, Time magazine spoke in a single authoritative voice that reflected the world back to its readers. Now Richard Stengel, the new managing editor of Time, wants to change the metaphor. His plan is to fill the pages of Time with more essays and news analysis, give the magazine a sharper point of view and draw more brand-name journalists into the fold. If this sounds familiar, it may be that Mr. Stengel wants Time to be a little more like its chief rival, Newsweek. [Page C1.]    A WIKI WAVE -- Although Wikipedia is operated by a nonprofit foundation, ideas for advertising-based wiki sites are beginning to take their place alongside blogs and social networking sites as a staple of Silicon Valley business plans. [C1.]    GIRLS AS GAMERS -- The Frag Dolls, a group of stylish, fresh-faced girls, are one of the latest weapons in the gaming industry's effort to smash the stereotypical image of the gamer as a geeky teenage boy battling aliens. The French computer game giant Ubisoft is backing teams of girl game players while the girls help Ubisoft promote computer play. Other companies are also intensifying efforts to tap the feminine side of computers in a $29 billion industry that is trying to cope with declining sales as consumers await the arrival of a new generation of consoles. [C2.]    A REVIVAL OF SORTS -- Vonage went public in May at $17 and bottomed out at $6.30 in July, but since then the stock has stabilized and climbed slightly. It closed on Friday at $8.90. Today, the company plans to announce that it has attained 2 million subscribers, up from 1.6 million at the end of the first quarter. [C1.]    A MESSAGE IN LEBANON -- A billboard for Johnnie Walker whiskey stretches across the side of a multistory building north of Beruit and shows a drawing of a bridge with a chunk missing. In an allusion to the Israeli air strikes, the Johnnie Walker character, cane in hand, strides away from the gap and across the bridge on the poster, which urges the Lebanese to ''keep walking.'' The ad is notable because multinational companies usually go out of their way to insulate their marketing from any reference to sensitive international disputes. [C4.]    ASSESSING A PRODUCT -- Scores of Internet merchants have begun following Amazon's lead by posting customer reviews -- both flattering and flaming -- of products they sell, and directing shoppers to sources of the most highly rated items. At Petco, for example, the Web division has tested the service of a new technology that essentially polls retail customers. According to John Lazarchic, Petco's vice president for e-commerce, left, 30 days after the company placed links near products asking visitors to write reviews, more than 1,000 products attracted comments. Bob Tedeschi, E-Commerce Report [C5.]    BLOG SITE SHUTDOWN -- Lee Siegel, a senior editor for The New Republic and the author of the Lee Siegel on Culture blog, was suspended indefinitely from the magazine after a reader accused him of using a ''sock puppet,'' or Internet alias, to attack his critics in the comments section of his own blog. An editor's apology replaced the blog on the Web site. [C4.]    TAKING ON ITUNES -- So far, none of the companies that sell music online have emerged as serious competitors to Apple iTunes. But not one has an audience like MySpace, which announced plans to begin selling songs. For the industry, which worries about Apple's online dominance, a MySpace music store could present a difficult decision. News Analysis. [C3.]    THE LIFE OF CONRAD BLACK -- According to a Canadian newspaper report, a recent court order stipulates that Conrad M. Black and his wife, Barbara Amiel, can each spend up to $25,000 a month on ''reasonable'' expenses, which must be approved by the court. For Lord Black, that is budget living. In a financial disclosure, Lord Black said his monthly expenses ran more in the range of $200,000, and that was after selling his homes in London and New York. The asset freeze is yet another major obstacle for the former press tycoon, who is at the center of a web of corporate scandal and is preparing to defend himself against criminal fraud and racketeering charges. [C1.]    MARKETS CLOSED TODAY -- Financial markets and banks in the United States are closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day. They will reopen Tuesday.

snippet: PATENT--Samuel R. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague, ''Pat'', member of the Einstein Board of Overseers for 20 years. Pat's commitment to Einstein's medical re...
lead_paragraph: PATENT--Samuel R. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague, "Pat", member of the Einstein Board of Overseers for 20 years. Pat's commitment to Einstein's medical research and education spanned more than three decades. Pat and his wife Shirley were generous supporters of the College and established a laboratory for cardiovascular research. Their son Robert is a past Chairman of our Men's Division and a member of its Executive Committee. Robert's wife Patti is a member of our Women's Division National Board and a former President of its Westchester/Fairfield Chapter. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire Patent family, which has played such an important role in the College's development. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ira M. Millstein, Chairperson, Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D., The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. Poppa: You will always be our hero. Your strength, love, support, wisdom and affection have shaped our entire family. You loved to make us laugh and smile and forever will. Each of us was the apple of your eye and you will always be our star sapphire. We will miss you each and every day of our lives. All our love, Leslie, Michael, Ali, Barry, Lauren, Russell and Sydney $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. Age 91. Beloved and cherished husband of Shirley for nearly 65 years. Loving and devoted father of Susan, Robert and Patricia. Adored and adoring Poppa of Lauren and Russell, Alison and Barry, Leslie, Michael and great-granddaughter Sydney Alexandra. We will forever miss his love, his wisdom and his counsel. Services private. The family will be at home in White Plains, Tuesday and Wednesday, from 1-4 pm and 7-9 pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY; or The Morse Geriatric Center, West Palm Beach, FL. $(6$)PATENT--Samuel. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Samuel Patent. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Shirley, and their family. Allan Greenblatt, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary

lead_paragraph: Even as the Nasdaq Stock Market battles to acquire a recalcitrant London Stock Exchange, Nasdaq’s chief executive is in a trans-Atlantic feud of his own over a week of medieval revelry in Ireland. According to the New York Daily News, Robert Greifeld is in a legal dispute related to a $611,000 party that he threw two years ago at Luttrellstown Castle — a party that included a host of feudal festivities, such as a week-long wild-boar roast for 23.

lead_paragraph: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Jeff Hare 95 minutes
abstract: Opens today in Manhattan  Directed by Jeff Hare  95 minutes       Marinated in egg cream and garnished with lox and onions, ''Checking Out'' is more sitcom-ready Jewish than a weekend in the Catskills circa 1950. Based on a 1976 play by Allen Swift, the movie revolves around 90-year-old Morris Applebaum (Peter Falk), a retired Shakespearean actor for whom every moment, even his death, is a performance. In response to a letter he has sent advertising his imminent suicide, Morris's grown children converge on his luxurious New York apartment, dragging their emotional baggage and a repertory of corny one-liners with them.

headline.main: Family Drama at a Father's Final Curtain Call
headline.print_headline: Film in Review; Checking Out

snippet: Safely Removing Reluctant Hardware    Q. Why is it that my Windows computer sometimes will not let me unplug my U.S.B. flash drive? When I go to the Safely Remove Hardware icon and go through the steps to stop the device, I often get the message t...
lead_paragraph: Safely Removing Reluctant Hardware
abstract: Safely Removing Reluctant Hardware    Q. Why is it that my Windows computer sometimes will not let me unplug my U.S.B. flash drive? When I go to the Safely Remove Hardware icon and go through the steps to stop the device, I often get the message that ''the device cannot be stopped right now, try later.''    A. Portable U.S.B. drives are wonderfully convenient because they can hold many megabytes of data, are small enough for a pocket or purse, and plug right into the computer's U.S.B. port. Once plugged in, the drive shows up in the My Computer area of Windows, just like any other external hard drive or disk.

headline.main: Safely Removing Reluctant Hardware

snippet: Back in 1998, the federal government declared that its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation was not merely a matter of law enforcement, but a defense of innovation. The concern was that the company was wielding its market powe...
lead_paragraph: Back in 1998, the federal government declared that its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation was not merely a matter of law enforcement, but a defense of innovation. The concern was that the company was wielding its market power and its strategy of bundling more and more features into its dominant Windows desktop operating system to thwart competition and stifle innovation.
abstract: Back in 1998, the federal government declared that its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation was not merely a matter of law enforcement, but a defense of innovation. The concern was that the company was wielding its market power and its strategy of bundling more and more features into its dominant Windows desktop operating system to thwart competition and stifle innovation.     Eight years later, long after Microsoft lost and then settled the antitrust case, it turns out that Windows is indeed stifling innovation -- at Microsoft.

headline.main: Windows Is So Slow, but Why?
headline.print_headline: Windows Is So Slow, But Why?; Sheer Size Is Causing Delays for Microsoft

snippet: Instant Messages To a Cellphone    Q. How do you send an instant message with AOL Instant Messenger from a Windows computer to someone's mobile phone? Does the person need to have AIM installed on the phone?    A. Most instant message programs -- ...
lead_paragraph: Instant Messages To a Cellphone
abstract: Instant Messages To a Cellphone    Q. How do you send an instant message with AOL Instant Messenger from a Windows computer to someone's mobile phone? Does the person need to have AIM installed on the phone?    A. Most instant message programs -- including AOL Instant Messenger, MSN Messenger, iChat and Yahoo Messenger -- include the ability to send messages to wireless phones that are equipped to handle text messages. Your friend does not need to use AIM to get the message, but depending on his or her phone plan, there may be a small fee for receiving text messages.

headline.main: Sending Instant Messages to a Cellphone

snippet: SHAKE-UP AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- Hewlett-Packard shook up its board in an agreement that seemed to leave all the parties in its boardroom tussle satisfied, if not happy. Its chairwoman will step aside in January, its chief executive will succeed her...
lead_paragraph: SHAKE-UP AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- Hewlett-Packard shook up its board in an agreement that seemed to leave all the parties in its boardroom tussle satisfied, if not happy. Its chairwoman will step aside in January, its chief executive will succeed her, and its longest-serving director resigned. [Page A1.]
abstract: SHAKE-UP AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- Hewlett-Packard shook up its board in an agreement that seemed to leave all the parties in its boardroom tussle satisfied, if not happy. Its chairwoman will step aside in January, its chief executive will succeed her, and its longest-serving director resigned. [Page A1.]    BRISTOL CHIEF IS OUSTED -- Peter R. Dolan's troubled five-year term as chief executive of the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb ended as the board dismissed him over the botched handling of a patent dispute involving the company's blockbuster drug, Plavix. Mr. Dolan, 50, will be succeeded by an interim chief, James M. Cornelius, a Bristol-Myers director. [C1.]    MEDICARE PREMIUMS TO INCREASE -- The basic Medicare premium will rise next year to $93.50 a month, an increase of $5, the Bush administration announced. It said that more affluent beneficiaries would have to pay a new surcharge, ranging from $12.50 to $68.60 a month. [A20.]    VIOXX RISKS -- Vioxx, which is no longer on the market, may have posed heart risks that a similar drug, Celebrex, and other painkillers do not, according to two papers published by The Journal of the American Medical Association. [A18.]    LONELYGIRL UNMASKED -- A nearly four-month-old Internet mystery involving the cryptic video musings of a fresh-faced teenager known as Lonelygirl15 appears to be solved, with the girl identified as an actress who is part of a project to make a movie. [C1.]    TAX PROVISION AND ARTWORK -- Directors and trustees of the nation's top art museums are preparing a lobbying effort to reverse a federal tax provision that they say will significantly harm their ability to acquire new artworks. [E1.]    TAX RULING IN EUROPE -- Europe's highest court ruled that countries could not go after profits earned by company subsidiaries in other European countries as long as the businesses were not ''artificial'' arrangements to avoid paying taxes. [C4.]    TAKING AIM AT SALT -- The American Medical Association is going after the government and the food industry to reduce what it sees as a persistently high level of salt in many processed foods. [C1.]    STRONG EARNINGS AT GOLDMAN -- Despite a summer slump in trading up and down Wall Street, and expectations of a significant decline in investment banking, Goldman Sachs reported strong third-quarter earnings. Market Place. [C3.]    SHARES RISE -- Stocks rose the most in about a month, led by retail shares as investors bet that falling crude oil prices would propel consumer spending and lift corporate profits while easing inflation. [C10.]    TRADE DEFICIT HITS RECORD -- The United States trade deficit rose sharply in July to a record $68 billion, as oil import prices and demand for foreign goods and services rose to new highs. [C4.]    BIG LAW FIRMS LOOK AT MERGING -- Two prominent law firms on opposite coasts -- Dewey Ballantine of New York and Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe of San Francisco -- confirmed that they were discussing a possible merger that could create one of the nation's largest corporate legal advisers. [C4.]    REACHING OUT TO RUST BELT -- Labor-starved Wyoming, with its energy boom in coal, oil and natural gas, is vigorously courting the workers of the Rust Belt -- in particular, those in Michigan's auto industry. And the workers are responding. [A1.]    APPLE'S NEW PLANS -- Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple Computer, announced plans for a device that will plug into a television and wirelessly pull in video and music from a Macintosh computer in the den or from the Internet. Mr. Jobs also introduced new products including an ultrasmall version of the iPod Shuffle, above, that disappears in the palm of a hand and clips onto clothing. [C1.]    SOROS DONATES $50 MILLION -- The financier and philanthropist George Soros said that he was contributing $50 million to support a sprawling social experiment, organized and led by the economist Jeffrey D. Sachs, that aims to help villages in Africa escape grinding poverty. [A18.]    GATES FOUNDATION AND AFRICA -- The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation announced that it was working with the Rockefeller Foundation to increase agricultural productivity in Africa. [A18.]    PANEL TO EXAMINE SECURITIES LAWS -- A committee filled with business leaders and academics was created to consider changes in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act and other laws and regulations governing securities markets and companies, with the intention of improving competitiveness for American markets. [C3.]    ONLINE    SMALL BUSINESS -- The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies. A special report can be found at nytimes.com/business.    KATIE COURIC -- Bill Carter of The Times offers his take on Katie Couric's debut on the ''CBS Evening News'' at nytimes.com/television.    DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    Business Briefing  An article on this development are at nytimes.com/business.    COMVERSE TECHNOLOGY, A MAKER of voice-mail software, said second-quarter sales rose 38 percent, butthe company did not report full results because of an investigation into its stock option grants. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

snippet: Chateaurenard, town of 13,500--like dozens of other farming towns that were once bedrock of rural France--seems to have lost its soul; farmers are retiring and abandoning their unprofitable fields, and half working residents travel to jobs somewhe...
lead_paragraph: CHÂTEAURENARD, France - The neat rows of apple trees and grape vines that lined the road heading into this once archetypical French farming town disappeared long ago. In their place is a landscape of prefabricated warehouses, auto parts dealers, a chicken-processing plant and fields overrun with scrub.
abstract: Chateaurenard, town of 13,500--like dozens of other farming towns that were once bedrock of rural France--seems to have lost its soul; farmers are retiring and abandoning their unprofitable fields, and half working residents travel to jobs somewhere else; transformation of Chateaurenard suggests that more of France's regions will not escape same kind of upheaval; one change is seldom spoken of openly: up to 20 percent of town's residents are ethnic Arabs, many of them young, under-educated, unemployed and isolated; locals and experts say result is contagious fear that makes Chateaurenards of France fertile terrain for extreme right National Front in next spring's presidential election; map; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 18 about high-speed Internet service available through cellular carriers referred incorrectly to the hardware from one carrier, Verizon Wireless. Its 5740 card, used to receive the data signal, is available with support for Apple computers, not simply PC's. The article also referred imprecisely to an international plan offered by Cingular. While the $140-a-month plan is available on a limited basis to business customers, it will not be offered more widely until the summer.

snippet: 9 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS -- Eddie Vedder, the Pearl Jam frontman, and Laird Hamilton (above left, with Mr. Vedder), the extreme surfer, hit some waves in Maui to lead off a new season of the series in which big kahunas in different fields com...
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS -- Eddie Vedder, the Pearl Jam frontman, and Laird Hamilton (above left, with Mr. Vedder), the extreme surfer, hit some waves in Maui to lead off a new season of the series in which big kahunas in different fields come together to discuss their passions and processes. Filling out the six episodes: the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov and the chef Alice Waters; the filmmaker Quentin Tarantino and the singer-songwriter Fiona Apple; the actress Isabella Rossellini and the inventor Dean Kamen; the music man Paul Simon and the producer Lorne Michaels; and the comedian Dave Chappelle and the poet Maya Angelou. Robert Redford, who dreamed up this exercise in mutual admiration, is executive producer.
abstract: 9 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS -- Eddie Vedder, the Pearl Jam frontman, and Laird Hamilton (above left, with Mr. Vedder), the extreme surfer, hit some waves in Maui to lead off a new season of the series in which big kahunas in different fields come together to discuss their passions and processes. Filling out the six episodes: the dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov and the chef Alice Waters; the filmmaker Quentin Tarantino and the singer-songwriter Fiona Apple; the actress Isabella Rossellini and the inventor Dean Kamen; the music man Paul Simon and the producer Lorne Michaels; and the comedian Dave Chappelle and the poet Maya Angelou. Robert Redford, who dreamed up this exercise in mutual admiration, is executive producer.    8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY -- The horror! The horror! Betty (America Ferrera) shows up in full regalia for the Mode Halloween costume contest, only to discover there isn't one. And Wilhelmina (Vanessa Williams) discovers she can't fit into a designer gown.    8 P.M. (BET) ACCESS GRANTED -- John Legend unveils the video for his latest single, ''Heaven.''    8 P.M. (11) SMALLVILLE -- Turns out that Oliver Queen (Justin Hartley, right), a k a the Green Arrow, and his friends were the prep school bullies. Now Lex and Oliver are about to return for a reunion.    9 P.M. (11) SUPERNATURAL -- File it under ''. . . Who Needs Enemies?'': Sam and Dean meet a slacker (Gabriel Tigerman) who may be using his psychic powers to kill his friends.    9 P.M. (History) THE REAL DR. FRANKENSTEIN -- A look at Johann Konrad Dippel, an 18th-century German scientist who secretly experimented with formulas he believed could revive the dead -- and whose story inspired Mary Shelley's writing.    9 P.M. (Travel) JOAN CUSACK'S LOCAL FLAVOR -- Ms. Cusack samples organic olive oil, pastries and wine amid the architecture of Gaudí in Barcelona.    9:15 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) ADAM'S RIB -- (1949). TCM spends the evening with one of its favorite leading ladies, Katharine Hepburn, and a starry roster of leading men, starting with this George Cukor trifle about a couple of lawyers (Ms. Hepburn and Spencer Tracy, above) who find their marriage suddenly on the rocks when they represent opposing sides in an attempted-murder case (with an effervescent Judy Holliday as the culprit). At 12:15 a.m., Ms. Hepburn pairs up with Humphrey Bogart in ''African Queen,'' followed at 2:15 in ''Suddenly, Last Summer,'' as a maternal tarantula with Montgomery Clift, before heading to the Indian Nation with John Wayne in ''Rooster Cogburn'' at 4:15.   KATHRYN SHATTUCK

abstract: Dr. William W. McGuire, a medical entrepreneur who built the UnitedHealth Group into a colossus in its field, was forced to resign from the company yesterday and to give up a portion of the $1.1 billion he holds in harshly criticized stock options.      UnitedHealth, one of the nation's two largest health insurers, also dismissed its general counsel and a member of its board in what amounted to a sweeping overhaul of its governance practices and leadership ranks. The options that Dr. McGuire had been granted over the years have led to criminal and civil investigations and public disapproval.

snippet: UPROAR AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- The furor over news leaks on the board of Hewlett-Packard began unfolding when the venture capitalist Thomas J. Perkins, left, quit the board after an investigation pointed to a friend on the board as a source of the l...
lead_paragraph: UPROAR AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- The furor over news leaks on the board of Hewlett-Packard began unfolding when the venture capitalist Thomas J. Perkins, left, quit the board after an investigation pointed to a friend on the board as a source of the leaks. [Page A1.]
abstract: UPROAR AT HEWLETT-PACKARD -- The furor over news leaks on the board of Hewlett-Packard began unfolding when the venture capitalist Thomas J. Perkins, left, quit the board after an investigation pointed to a friend on the board as a source of the leaks. [Page A1.]    A BOARDROOM DRAMA -- Boardrooms have erupted in battles in the past, but the clashes at Hewlett-Packard over leaks and questionably obtained phone records have lawyers and corporate-governance experts aghast at the strange drama unfolding. [C1.]    BLOWBACK ON CALLING RECORDS -- Legislators, regulators and the phone industry are all considering ways to clamp down on unauthorized releases of records like those in the Hewlett-Packard case. [C9.]    NEW MAN IN CHARGE -- After 37 years at Boeing, Alan Mulally is among the leaders at Ford Motor, where he must quickly get up to speed in the midst of one of the company's most severe financial crises. [C1.]    CARMAKERS EXTEND WARRANTIES -- General Motors said it would extend warranty coverage of the engine and transmission on all 2007 vehicles to five years or 100,000 miles, whichever occurs first, two months after Ford extended warranties on its vehicles. [C4.]    INFLATION THREAT REMAINS -- A report from the Labor Department suggested that the threat of higher inflation had not diminished and that it might take more monetary restraint to keep prices in check. [C1.]    MERCK WRAPS UP INTERNAL INQUIRY -- The investigator hired by Merck's board to examine whether top management hid the risks of the painkiller Vioxx issued a report saying the company behaved ethically. [C1.]    AN AGING GENE -- Biologists have uncovered a link between life span and cancer in the form of a gene that switches off stem cells as a person ages. [A23.]    LEGAL TACTIC IS CRITICIZED -- A group of former top Justice Department officials have asked the United States attorney general to curtail the tactics of prosecutors that encourage companies to disclose legal communications to avoid indictment. [C4.]    SENATORS WANT ACTION -- With an eye on the midterm elections, two Senate committees asked top government officials whether there was more Congress could do to clean up the options backdating scandal and combat soaring executive pay. [C3.]    HEART DEVICE APPROVED -- The Food and Drug Administration approved the first implantable, self-sufficient artificial heart. Market Place. [C3.]    NASDAQ TO DEAL IN OPTIONS -- Nasdaq, the nation's second-largest stock market, will start an options exchange next year in an effort to capitalize on a growing market whose competitors and structure are rapidly changing. [C3.]    OPERA IN THEATERS -- The Metropolitan Opera said it would begin broadcasting live performances into movie theaters across the United States, Canada and Europe. [E1.]    DEMOTION OF DESIGNERS -- As another runway season begins with New York Fashion Week, a tide seems to have turned against designers. [G1.]    MAGAZINES REACH FOR STUDENTS -- A new digital initiative will give away thousands of magazine subscriptions to college students, but the magazines will be delivered via e-mail, not in print. Advertising. [C5.]    HOME DEPOT OPTIONS INQUIRY -- Home Depot said that federal prosecutors had requested information regarding its stock options practices. [C5.]    A NEW TWIST IN ENRON CASE -- The Justice Department says it is opposing the long-accepted practice of federal courts to throw out convictions of criminal defendants who die while an appeal is pending, in an attempt to recover more than $40 million from the estate of Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's founder. [C9.]    I.B.M. AWARDED CONTRACT -- The Department of Energy said it had awarded I.B.M. a contract to build a supercomputer capable of 1,000 trillion calculations a second. [C13.]    GREENBERG SUIT SCALED BACK -- New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, dropped several claims from a lawsuit that accused Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman of American International Group, of using accounting tricks to hide losses. While Mr. Spitzer's office characterized the changes as ''streamlining,'' Mr. Greenberg's lawyers said ''key claims'' had been removed. [C4.]    APPLE LOWERS PRICES -- Apple Computer is updating its most popular desktop computer, the iMac, with faster versions of Intel chips and the lowest-priced model yet. [C13.]    BERTELSMANN SELLS MUSIC UNIT -- The German media company Bertelsmann agreed to sell its music publishing business to a French rival, Vivendi, for $2.1 billion, but an association of competitors promised to challenge the deal. [C14.]    SHARES FALL ON INFLATION FEARS -- Stocks suffered their biggest loss since July after the government said second-quarter labor costs climbed, reviving concern that the Fed would limit growth by raising interest rates to curb inflation. [C14.]    ONLINE    FREQUENT FLIER -- Business travelers love their gadgets, perhaps too much. So when the gadgets don't love them back, things can get ugly. A report is at nytimes.com/technology. snippet: There's nothing like a good pie for making your point. Pies can be used to repay a favor or send a message of condolence. Pies tell a constituency that the politician digging into a slice at the local diner is a man of the people, a patriotic soul...
lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
abstract: There's nothing like a good pie for making your point. Pies can be used to repay a favor or send a message of condolence. Pies tell a constituency that the politician digging into a slice at the local diner is a man of the people, a patriotic soul. They also come in handy as weapons -- for public figures like Bill Gates and Ann Coulter, a pie in the face is all in a day's work. It's too bad then, Anne Dimock writes in ''Humble Pie,'' her lucid and thoughtful treatise on the round fruit-filled pastry, that ''the natural habitat for pies has changed, shrunk, disappeared.'' Where did John Kerry and John Edwards go for an important photo-op near the end of their campaign? Wendy's, not a diner. And not a pie in sight.

snippet: A graphic-design icon, Alan Aldridge relives his misadvantages with Jonathan Wingfield.
lead_paragraph: He designed posters for the Rolling Stones; was best friends with Jimi Hendrix; and served as the creative director for the the original Hard Rock Cafe and the House of Blues as well as for the opening of the Playboy Club in London; he even penned a best-seller. Yet despite his staggering résumé, the graphic design guru Alan Aldridge is little known today. If anything, you’re more likely to be au fait with his eldest son, Miles, a fashion photographer, or his daughter Saffron, a model turned writer. “Yeah, get that quite a lot: ‘Oh, you’re Miles’s dad, didn’t you do something in the 60’s?”’ admits the 63-year-old Aldridge, who follows the comment with his trademark “aww-shucks” snigger. His voice possesses the mid-Atlantic timbre of a man who left London in 1980 in search of Hollywood fame; his all-black attire, his handsome, compact features and his horn-rimmed specs give Aldridge the allure of Jack Nicholson playing an aging Beatle.
abstract: A graphic-design icon, Alan Aldridge relives his misadvantages with Jonathan Wingfield.

snippet: As Knight Ridder Papers Come Up for Sale, Potential Buyers Look to Solidify Markets  With the McClatchy newspaper company set to accept bids for the 12 Knight Ridder papers it is selling, some of the potential buyers are looking at the country as ...
lead_paragraph: As Knight Ridder Papers Come Up for Sale, Potential Buyers Look to Solidify Markets With the McClatchy newspaper company set to accept bids for the 12 Knight Ridder papers it is selling, some of the potential buyers are looking at the country as they would a giant chessboard. The goal is to become a leader in each regional market where potential buyers already own newspapers and can achieve economies of scale by buying pieces of Knight Ridder. [Page C1.]
abstract: As Knight Ridder Papers Come Up for Sale, Potential Buyers Look to Solidify Markets  With the McClatchy newspaper company set to accept bids for the 12 Knight Ridder papers it is selling, some of the potential buyers are looking at the country as they would a giant chessboard. The goal is to become a leader in each regional market where potential buyers already own newspapers and can achieve economies of scale by buying pieces of Knight Ridder. [Page C1.]    Sheer Size of Windows Causes Delays for Microsoft  As Microsoft repeatedly delays the new version of its desktop operating system, called Windows Vista, it appears that the company is a victim of its own popularity. [C1.]    Fed Appears Ready for Its 15th Rate Increase  Today, Ben S. Bernanke will convene his first meeting of the Fed's policy makers, joining the other Fed governors and the presidents of the Fed's regional banks in a two-day session that is all but certain to end tomorrow afternoon with another quarter-point rise in short-term interest rates, the 15th consecutive increase. [C1.]    A Computerized Courtroom for Nuclear Waste Case  In anticipation of a marathon hearing on the question of burying nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has built two linked, computerized courtrooms -- one on the second floor of its office complex in Maryland and one in Las Vegas. The system will permit lawyers and others who are involved in the hearing to search millions of pages of records almost instantly, calling them to their own screen or those of other participants. [C8.]    Online Retail Services Search for the Best Deal  Barry Diller's InterActiveCorp is among several companies offering comparison shopping software. The company recently rolled out Pronto, which silently monitors users' activity on a product page, then shows them prices from other merchants on similar items until it finds a better deal. Pronto is already showing up in links at the bottom of other InterActive sites, like Ticketmaster.com and CitySearch, and according to Pronto's chief executive, Dan Marriott, left, more substantial marketing initiatives with AskJeeves and other sister sites could follow. Pronto's software, which works on Windows machines, connects users to Pronto's database of 50,000 merchants, which it has built by scanning retailers' Web pages. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C9.]    HBO Explores 'Sex and the City' as Reality Show  HBO is in the process of commissioning a reality pilot that could tackle many of the themes of ''Sex and the City,'' the most popular comedy in the channel's history. The show is billed as a look at young urban women and their relationships with men and each other. [C11.]    Nielsen and Cable Company May Test On-Demand Service  Time Warner Cable has begun talks with CBS, ABC, Fox and NBC about testing a service that would give viewers access to top programs, as rated by Nielsen Media Research, soon after their broadcast. [C10.]    Church Aims to Spread Gospel Through Marketing  The United Church of Christ, which raised eyebrows with a provocative television commercial last spring, is resuming its advertising efforts with a campaign that seeks to emulate how the Gospel was spread: by word of mouth. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C10.]    Two Apples to Square Off in Court  Apple Computer will meet the Beatles' Apple Corps in court this week in London, where a judge will determine whether Apple Computer's iTunes online music service violates a 1991 agreement between the two companies that, the Beatles' Apple claims, blocked the computer maker from selling music. [C8.]    Company Aims to Challenge Traditional News Services  This week, Mochila, a service that calls itself a media marketplace, will be introduced at Nexpo, an annual newspaper industry conference. Mochila will be a place where newspapers, magazines, Web sites and broadcasters sell content to other publications. Initially, Mochila will only allow the exchange of text and photographs, but it plans to add audio and video content. [C11.]

snippet: Cathleen Schine enjoys the view from Unter den Linden in Riverside Park.
lead_paragraph: Yes, I worry about August in the city. Poor August, imprisoned in concrete. But then, I also worry about the city in August. Poor city, overheated and abandoned by much of its population. Because, you know, August, the month that Europeans take off, the month that shrinks take off, is, according to local prejudice, the worst month – the hottest and muggiest and dreariest.

[C13.]    JITTERS OVER HURRICANES All along the coasts, from Texas to New England, insurers suffering from hurricane jitters are raising rates and cutting back on coverage. But nowhere is the crisis more severe than in Florida, where storms in recent years have added billions to the insurers' losses. [C1.]    PESSIMISM AMONG WORKERS Three new opinion polls found deep pessimism among American workers, with most saying that wages were not keeping pace with inflation and that workers were worse off in many ways than a generation ago. [A21.]    ALCATEL DEFENDS LUCENT DEAL With a week to go before a crucial vote on a deal that would reshape the telecommunications equipment industry, Alcatel disputed criticism about its planned takeover of Lucent and insisted that the deal would benefit shareholders. DROPS 'SURVIVOR' ADS General Motors has decided not to advertise on the CBS reality show ''Survivor'' for the upcoming season, one that has attracted criticism because teams of contestants are being pitted against each other based on race. lead_paragraph: BUSH NUDGES CHINA -- The Bush administration is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power in the International Monetary Fund, in an effort to gain Chinese cooperation on international economic issues.[Page C1.]
abstract: BUSH NUDGES CHINA -- The Bush administration is pushing for China and other developing nations to get more power in the International Monetary Fund, in an effort to gain Chinese cooperation on international economic issues.[Page C1.]    CHINA AND THE W.T.O. -- China should throw its influence as a global trading giant behind efforts to revive talks aimed at lowering trade barriers, Susan C. Schwab, left, the United States trade representative, said in Beijing. She said that China was taking a back seat to more vocal members of the World Trade Organization, including India and Brazil, rather than playing a leadership role in breaking a deadlock in the talks, known as the Doha round. [C4.]    FED WAS ON THE FENCE -- Although the Federal Reserve's policy makers chose to keep interest rates unchanged, several thought that increases ''could well be needed'' in the future, according to minutes of the Fed's Aug. 8 meeting. [C1.]    SHARES ADVANCE -- Stocks rose for a second day after the Federal Reserve suggested it might put off interest-rate increases, outweighing the biggest drop in consumer confidence in almost a year. [C8.]    PAPER COUPONS SURVIVE -- An Internet assault on the paper-clipping coupon business is under way, but while the cool logic of efficiency suggests the traditional paper coupon is in imminent peril, the marketplace tells another story. [C1.]    HOUSEHOLD INCOME EDGES UP -- The nation's median household income rose slightly faster than inflation last year for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported. [A1.]    INQUIRY ON AGENCY HEAD -- State Department investigators have found that Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, the head of the agency that oversees most government broadcasts to foreign countries, used government employees to do his personal errands and that he billed the government for more days of work than the rules permit. [A1.]    VETO OF WINE BILL -- Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has vetoed a bill that would have declared zinfandel to be the ''historic wine'' of California. [A12.]    GOT FAME? -- Faced with declining milk consumption by teenagers, dairy companies are embarking on an ad campaign with sports and entertainment celebrities and interactive features that they hope will win young people over. Advertising. [C3.]    BOOKSELLER INQUIRY -- Barnes & Noble said that it had received a subpoena from a United States attorney requesting documents on its stock options practices. [C3.]    WORKERS BRIEFED ON FORD -- Local union leaders at the Ford Motor Company received an update on the struggling company's condition, but said they were not told about any specific steps the company planned to take. [C3.]    METALS DEAL MOVES FORWARD -- The nickel mining company Inco confirmed its support for a friendly offer from Phelps Dodge after it failed to persuade a Brazilian company to increase a hostile takeover bid of $18 billion. [C4.]    FREE AND LEGAL MUSIC -- A new online music company called SpiralFrog said that it would make a huge catalog of songs from the world's largest record company, the Universal Music Group, available for consumers to download free. [C5.]    GOOGLE CHIEF ON APPLE'S BOARD -- Apple Computer said that the chief executive of Google, Eric Schmidt, was joining its board. [C5.]    KRAFT WANTS INDEPENDENCE -- Kraft Foods, the packaged food company, has been itching to be independent of its parent, the Altria Group, and its tobacco units Philip Morris USA and Philip Morris International. Today's meeting of Altria's board may bring Kraft one step closer to its goal. [C1.]    NOVELL'S PROFIT UP -- The business software maker Novell posted a higher quarterly profit and said that it had begun an internal investigation into previous stock options grants. [C5.]    J.& J. WINS ANTITRUST SUIT -- Johnson & Johnson won an antitrust lawsuit that had accused the company of illegally using its sutures monopoly to increase sales of other surgical products. [C7.]    HOME DEPOT REVISES BYLAWS -- Home Depot took another step to repair its image with investors after an acrimonious annual meeting in May, announcing that it had revised company bylaws to require that each director be elected by majority vote. [C8.]    ONLINE    YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with a free weekly newsletter at nytimes.com/yourmoney.    DEALBOOK -- Daily news on mergers and acquisitions, I.P.O.'s, venture capital and more is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    THE WALK-THROUGH -- Writers for The New York Times look at residential real estate news, trends and tidbits at nytimes.com/walkthrough.    CHILD LABOR IN ZAMBIA -- Michael Wines discusses the increasing use of child labor in sub-Saharan Africa in a multimedia report at nytimes.com/world.    WATER WORRIES -- As travelers adjust to the new rules against carrying liquids onto planes, they are becoming more concerned about their access to the most essential liquid: water. A report is at nytimes.com/travel.

snippet: FED MEETS, AND STOCKS RISE The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the 17th time in a row, but kicked off a celebration in the stock market by lowering its alarms about inflation. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.2 percent -- its...
lead_paragraph: FED MEETS, AND STOCKS RISE The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the 17th time in a row, but kicked off a celebration in the stock market by lowering its alarms about inflation. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.2 percent -- its biggest one-day gain in almost three years. The other major benchmarks also rose 2 percent or more. [Pages A1 and C1.]
abstract: FED MEETS, AND STOCKS RISE The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the 17th time in a row, but kicked off a celebration in the stock market by lowering its alarms about inflation. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.2 percent -- its biggest one-day gain in almost three years. The other major benchmarks also rose 2 percent or more. [Pages A1 and C1.]    QUESTIONS ON APPLE OPTIONS Apple Computer said that it had uncovered irregularities related to stock options awarded from 1997 to 2001, raising questions about whether a large grant made to the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, was properly disclosed. [C1.]    SCRUSHY FOUND GUILTY After twice telling a judge they were deadlocked, a federal jury convicted Donald E. Siegelman, the former Alabama governor, and Richard M. Scrushy, left, the former head of the HealthSouth Corporation, on charges that they conspired in a bribery scheme seven years ago. Lawyers for both men said they would appeal, and both remained free on bond. A year ago, a Birmingham jury acquitted Mr. Scrushy on all charges that he participated in accounting fraud at HealthSouth. [A14.]    ANTI-EMISSIONs EXPERIMENT An experiment by Royal Dutch Shell in the Netherlands to limit emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas blamed for climate change, illustrates a fundamental shift in the oil industry that offers glimmers of hope for the future. [C1.]    U.S. AUTOMAKERS TRY NEW TACK Detroit auto companies, which have lagged behind their Japanese rivals in selling hybrid vehicles, are taking a new environmental direction, by focusing on flexible-fuel vehicles, which can run on gasoline and another type of fuel like ethanol. [C1.]    HOUSE APPROVES OIL DRILLING The House voted to approve oil and gas exploration in coastal waters that have been protected from drilling for 25 years. [A19.]    THE GRAYING OF CHINA By 2020 about a third of Shanghai's population, currently 13.6 million, will consist of people over the age of 59, remaking the city's social fabric and placing huge new strains on its economy and finances. Experts say the rapidly graying city is leading one of the greatest demographic changes in history, one with profound implications for all of China. [A1.]    CERVICAL CANCER VACCINE A federal advisory panel voted unanimously to recommend that all girls and women ages 11 to 26 receive a new vaccine, made by Merck, that prevents most cases of cervical cancer. [A12.]    SHIFT IN KPMG CASE Defendants in the government's mammoth tax-shelter case against 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG are quietly embracing separate defense strategies, a shift that could reshape the case. [C3.]    BOEING TO TAKE QUARTERLY CHARGE Boeing said that it would take second-quarter charges of up to $1.15 billion as a result of a settlement of ethics investigations with the federal government and delays in surveillance aircraft program for Australia and Turkey. [C3.]    WAL-MART STRIKE AVERTED Wal-Mart's British arm narrowly averted a costly strike after reaching an agreement with a union. [C3.]    TURKEY, EMERGING AND VOLATILE Turkey has suffered a plunge in its bonds and equities, a sign of how a star of emerging markets can quickly become a pariah as billions head for the door. Market Place. [C1.]    JAPAN BOND TRADING HALTS A computer error crippled trading in Japan's government bond market for more than two hours, just months after the Tokyo Stock Exchange suffered a run of similar flaws. [C8.]    TENET SETTLEMENT Tenet Healthcare has reached a $900 million settlement with federal officials to end investigations into accusations of overbilling of Medicare. The settlement -- valued at about one-fourth of Tenet's market value -- will be paid over four years and ends all investigations by the Department of Justice and several United States attorneys, the company said. The company also plans to sell about a dozen hospitals to regain its financial footing. [C3.]    OLD CHEVY ADS, RENEWED Chevrolet is reviving and updating a popular 1970's advertising campaign featuring the musical theme ''Baseball, hot dogs, apple pie and Chevrolet.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]    ONLINE    A SECURE IPOD IPods do not have a security slot, so the Mobile Security Lock for iPod makes use of the docking connector to help secure them. A report is at nytimes.com/technology.    ONLINE: DEALBOOK A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    COOL AT THE OFFICE: AVIATOR VOGUE  A slide show of shades by Oliver Peoples, Dior, Marc Jacobs, Cutler and Gross, and Mykita's can be found at nytimes.com/styles.    Business Briefing    Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    A FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY JUDGE, Allan Gropper, said that Northwest Airlines could throw out its union contract with flight attendants if two more weeks of talks did not produce a deal. (AP)    BAXTER INTERNATIONAL, the maker of blood-disease treatments, said federal regulators agreed to consider allowing the company to resume sales of medical pumps tied to two deaths. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    SHARES OF AVENTINE Renewable Energy Holdings, the large ethanol producer, fell 10.8 percent in their first day of trading after the company increased the sale price and sold more shares. snippet: Tammy La Gorce reviews Basic cafe in Jersey City, NJ (M)
lead_paragraph: Hard core perfectionists and anybody who subscribes to Cook's Illustrated will find a dozen things wrong with Basic, a corner cafe in Jersey City whose offerings are exactly that. But strictly speaking, you don't go to Basic for the food (which is really quite good), or the service (ditto). You go because it's as familiar and inviting as a rusty swing set.

snippet: America's 300 millionth person will be here any day now. The Census Bureau has combined birth, death and immigration rates and expects him or her to arrive in mid-October. No one knows where or how -- squalling in a birthing room in Los Angeles, m...
lead_paragraph: America's 300 millionth person will be here any day now. The Census Bureau has combined birth, death and immigration rates and expects him or her to arrive in mid-October. No one knows where or how -- squalling in a birthing room in Los Angeles, maybe, or darting out of the desert east of Phoenix.
abstract: America's 300 millionth person will be here any day now. The Census Bureau has combined birth, death and immigration rates and expects him or her to arrive in mid-October. No one knows where or how -- squalling in a birthing room in Los Angeles, maybe, or darting out of the desert east of Phoenix.      That's too bad, because whoever it is should get a bouquet and a thank-you card. It should be signed by President Bush on behalf of a grateful nation that is buzzing with a youthful energy for which the aging powers of Europe would gladly trade their pension obligations. If the newcomer is an immigrant, he or she should also get an apology from Mr. Bush for the scarcity of worker visas, and a promise to get right on that problem.

snippet: Clever hackers have figured out a way to switch between programs by swatting the side of a computer screen.
lead_paragraph: Inside every Apple laptop and IBM (Lenovo) Thinkpad is an accelerometer, a tiny sensor that detects sudden changes in laptop position in space. It's there for a good reason: if you drop these laptops, the hard drive's "needle" lifts and parks so that you don't lose data on impact.

snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-15    American Embassy in Syria Is Attacked by Gunmen  The American Embassy in Damascus was attacked by four gunmen who stormed the compound with grenades and automatic weapons before being repelled by Syrian security forces. Thre...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15
abstract: INTERNATIONAL A3-15    American Embassy in Syria Is Attacked by Gunmen  The American Embassy in Damascus was attacked by four gunmen who stormed the compound with grenades and automatic weapons before being repelled by Syrian security forces. Three of the gunmen were killed, and a fourth was wounded and captured, Syrian and American officials said.  A1    Pope Speaks on West and Islam  Pope Benedict XVI, left, weighed in on the sensitive issue of rapport between Islam and the West. He said violence, embodied in the Muslim idea of jihad, or holy war, was contrary to reason and God's plan, while the West was so beholden to reason that Islam could not understand it.  A6    Court Rules for Hamas Members  An Israeli military court ordered the release of 18 Palestinian lawmakers who are members of Hamas, including the speaker of parliament, a development that could help improve the climate for talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians.  A10    Iraqi Seeks Iran's Support  In his first state visit to Iran, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, left, discussed the security situation in Iraq with the Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and asked for support in quelling the violence that threatens to fracture Iraq.  A15    The senior Marine commander in Iraq said in a telephone interview that he had enough forces to carry out his mission but that his assignment did not include defeating the insurgency. The Marine general's 30,000 troops are charged with securing Anbar Province.  A15    NATIONAL A16-21    Wyoming Sells Itself To Michigan Laborers  Labor-starved Wyoming, with its energy boom in coal, oil and natural gas, is aggressively courting the workers of the Rust Belt, in particular those in Michigan's struggling auto industry.  A1    Chafee Wins in Rhode Island  Senator Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island won the Republican primary there, fending off a bid from a populist challenger that the national Republican Party had feared would cost it a seat it had held since 1976 in an overwhelmingly Democratic state.  A16    Costs of Homeland Security  Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff told a Senate committee that Congress and the American public must accept that the government cannot protect every possible target against attack if it wants to avoid fulfilling Al Qaeda's goal of bankrupting the nation.  A21    Medicare Premiums to Rise  The basic Medicare premium will rise next year to $93.50 a month, an increase of $5, the Bush administration announced. It said more affluent beneficiaries would have to pay a new surcharge, from $12.50 to $68.60 a month, depending on their incomes.  A20    Close to Compromise  The leading Senate Republicans in the negotiations on proposed legislation to bring terrorism suspects to trial said they were close to compromise in one of their key disputes with the White House: whether suspects have the right to see all the evidence used against them.  A20    Schools Debate Harvard Move  Officials at elite universities and colleges said they would think about how to respond to Harvard University's decision to eliminate early admissions, though none were ready to follow Harvard's lead.  A18    NEW YORK/REGION B1-8    Spitzer Wins Nomination For Governor in New York  Attorney General Eliot Spitzer won an overwhelming victory in the race for the Democratic nomination for governor of New York, with his party, in its strongest shape in 12 years, uniting politically in hopes of making history this November with a sweep of top statewide offices.  A1    Questions Over Astor Will  The propriety of the will of the socialite and philanthropist Brooke Astor, which redirected millions of dollars to her son and made him sole executor of her estate, is being challenged by Mrs. Astor's legal guardians. They they say that they intend to hire handwriting experts to determine if the signature on the documents is really Mrs. Astor's.  B1    ARTS E1-10    Museums Fear Tax Changes  Directors and trustees of the nation's top art museums are preparing a major lobbying effort to reverse a federal tax provision approved last month that they say will significantly harm their ability to acquire new artworks.  E1    'Maria' on Reality Television  Andrew Lloyd Webber has turned to a reality show to cast the lead role of Maria for his new production of ''The Sound of Music.'' The program, ''How Do You Solve a Problem Like Maria?'', has been drawing some six million viewers per installment for the BBC.  E1    OBITUARIES C13    Joachim Fest  A German journalist and author known internationally for his biographies and interpretations of Hitler, Albert Speer and the regime they embodied, he was 79.  C13    BUSINESS DAY C1-12    Hewlett-Packard Shake-Up  Hewlett-Packard shook up its board in an agreement that seemed to leave all the parties in its boardroom drama satisfied, if not happy. Its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, will step aside in January, the chief executive will succeed her, and the longest-serving director resigned.  A1    Apple Moves to TV Screen  Steven P. Jobs, Apple Computer's chief executive, announced a product due out early next year that will plug into a television and wirelessly pull in video and music from a Macintosh computer. snippet: Clever hackers have figured out a way to switch between programs by swatting the side of a computer screen.

snippet: Package tracking is a perfect marriage of high technology and consumer psychology.
lead_paragraph: Most of us know that the pleasure of shopping isn’t the actual owning. It’s the anticipation of owning. Case in point: Recently, I made an ordinary online purchase  lots of research, a Web-page receipt, and an e-mail confirmation. But then I noticed there was no package-tracking number in the e-mail, no 18-digit number that looks like someone’s idea of the perfect password. The package came on time  a day early, in fact. But I was sorry I didn’t get to watch it on its travels.
abstract: Package tracking is a perfect marriage of high technology and consumer psychology.

snippet: Christine Muhlke article on cooking techniques that entail risk of failure; recipes for souffle and brown-butter vinaigrette; photo; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: If you build it, they will eat it. But in the case of some of the most impressive -- and even basic -- dishes, the architecture is flimsy at best. Among the most feared kitchen failures are fallen soufflés, broken sauces, polarized vinaigrettes and molten baked Alaskas. All are items that require a solid foundation, a meticulously followed blueprint and dogged optimism -- or an unshakable ego. But do try them at home. The building blocks to the shakiest classics follow. The ego is up to you.

Case in point: Recently, I made an ordinary online purchase -- lots of research, a Web-page receipt, and an e-mail confirmation. abstract: Most of us know that the pleasure of shopping isn't the actual owning. It's the anticipation of owning. Case in point: Recently, I made an ordinary online purchase -- lots of research, a Web-page receipt, and an e-mail confirmation. But then I noticed there was no package-tracking number in the e-mail, no 18-digit number that looks like someone's idea of the perfect password. The package came on time -- a day early, in fact. But I was sorry I didn't get to watch it on its travels.     Package tracking is a perfect marriage of high technology and consumer psychology. There are probably still some shoppers for whom the pleasure of mail order is forgetting they've ordered anything until it arrives like an early Christmas. The rest of us click on the link that says, ''View Package Progress.''

snippet: "Since he'd released himself from the hospital in May, he hasn't left his house, these walls. He lives alone, except when Grace breaks in."
lead_paragraph: Grace Blackwater is downstairs, saving his life one small gesture at a time. He can hear her straight through the worn wood floor beneath his bed, going about her business as if she owns the place. She doesn't own the place. He hadn't called her, but she has come-up the long dirt driveway on her motorcycle at dawn and in through an open kitchen window, using her jackknife to slit the screen that has been repaired again and again with duct tape. Upstairs, in his bed, he has heard even this, the silver blade parting the length of fine mesh with the whir of a hummingbird. Every door in the house is unlocked. Grace likes to do things the hard way. He was glad she hadn't shot off the locks. She has some talents. He does, too. What are they? He doesn't know anymore. He sure can't dance, would make a lousy poker player, doesn't know any magic tricks, isn't much for meaningful conversation. He is a champion of deep sleep. He excels at the long rest.
abstract: "Since he'd released himself from the hospital in May, he hasn't left his house, these walls. He lives alone, except when Grace breaks in."

snippet: THE BRONX    The News -- The baseball season opened with the Yankees winning a big one: the New York City Council approved plans for a new $800 million stadium.    Behind the News -- The vote was the last real hurdle in a decades-long quest for a ...
lead_paragraph: THE BRONX
abstract: THE BRONX    The News -- The baseball season opened with the Yankees winning a big one: the New York City Council approved plans for a new $800 million stadium.    Behind the News -- The vote was the last real hurdle in a decades-long quest for a new stadium. The Yankees at one point threatened to move the team to New Jersey, and more recently Manhattan had been in the running. But in the end the team opted for a site next to the existing stadium in the South Bronx. The Council went along, over objections from neighborhood residents that the project would usurp parkland.    SILICON VALLEY    The News -- Apple Computer said it would introduce software to enable its Macintosh computers to run the Microsoft Windows operating system as well as its own.    Behind the News -- For Apple, which had long ignored and even mocked Microsoft's product, the decision was nothing short of revolutionary. But it was based on a simple business calculus: limiting its computers to a single operating system had limited the company's growth. If Macintoshes can run the vast array of Windows-only software, Apple may grab more than its current 5 percent share of the PC market.    WASHINGTON    The News -- Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice lobbied Congress to support the administration's effort to aid India's nuclear power program.    Behind the News -- Legislators had criticized the deal, citing concerns over India's nuclear weapons program. Ms. Rice sought to reassure the critics, saying she would push India to safeguard its civilian plants and block exports of weapons-making material. The calming words had an effect: several lawmakers offered qualified support for the agreement, leaving the White House optimistic that it would be approved.    ISRAEL    The News -- The Kadima Party, the winner in Israeli elections last month, said it would form a coalition with the Labor Party.    Behind the News -- The announcement does not quite settle the issue of what the new government will look like, as two or three smaller parties will be needed to form a parliamentary majority. But it goes a long way toward ensuring the continuation of the policies of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who is incapacitated by a coma. The parties agree on critical policy, including the removal of more Israeli settlements from the West Bank.    TV LAND    The News -- Katie Couric, a fixture on NBC's ''Today'' for 15 years, will join CBS, where she will anchor the evening newscast.    Behind the News -- For CBS, which courted Ms. Couric for a year, the move is an effort to attract new viewers to its newscast, a ratings also-ran in recent years. The hope is that some of her legions of fans who have made ''Today'' a ratings hit will start watching her at night. CBS may also be thinking that ''Today'' may stumble without her, creating an opening for the network's morning show, which is even more of a ratings laggard.

snippet: Mixing bowls add a stunning splash of color to kitchen counters, a cakemakers’ collaborative opens in Brooklyn and a well-edited selection of cheeses hit the shelves at Chelsea Market Baskets.
lead_paragraph: You can give your kitchen counter a stunning splash of color with this pair of mixing bowls, designed by Jan Hoekstra for the Museum of Modern Art’s gift shop. The small one holds a liter, about a quart, and the larger one takes two and one-half liters, indicated by graduated markings in metric measures and ounces on the inside. There’s a nonskid ring on the bottom and their streamlined shape and excellent balance make holding and lifting to pour batter or broth very easy. They are dishwasher-safe and sell for $30 a set at the museum’s shops, and at (800) 447-6662 or moma.org.

snippet: Apple to Offer Computers That Can Run Both Macintosh and Windows Systems  Two decades after the first Macintosh computer arrived, Apple said that it would offer users of its latest models a simple way to run both the Microsoft Windows operating sy...
lead_paragraph: Apple to Offer Computers That Can Run Both Macintosh and Windows Systems Two decades after the first Macintosh computer arrived, Apple said that it would offer users of its latest models a simple way to run both the Microsoft Windows operating system and its own. That means a single Apple computer will run the universe of programs written for either the Mac or Windows. Apple's stock jumped almost 10 percent on the news. [Page A1.]
abstract: Apple to Offer Computers That Can Run Both Macintosh and Windows Systems  Two decades after the first Macintosh computer arrived, Apple said that it would offer users of its latest models a simple way to run both the Microsoft Windows operating system and its own. That means a single Apple computer will run the universe of programs written for either the Mac or Windows. Apple's stock jumped almost 10 percent on the news. [Page A1.]    Apple's announcement helped lead the overall market higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 35.70 points, to 11,239.55. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.63 points, to finish at 1,311.56. The Nasdaq Composite index climbed 14.39 points, or 0.61 percent, to close at 2,359.75. [C11.]    Jury Orders Merck to Pay $4.5 Million in Damages  In a serious blow to Merck, a jury in New Jersey awarded $3 million to a man who had a heart attack after taking Vioxx for four years, and an additional $1.5 million to his wife. [C1.]    Coca-Cola Announces Unusual Pay Plan for Directors  The Coca-Cola Company announced an unusual plan for paying outside directors: If earnings per share do not rise fast enough over a three-year period, directors will get nothing. But they will get a raise from what they used to get if earnings do perform as expected. While many companies pay directors all or part of their pay in stock or stock options, Coca-Cola appears to be the first to have adopted a plan that will pay directors nothing if the company does not perform well. Market Place. [C1.]    Couric Confirms That She Will Move to CBS  Katie Couric announced that she would leave her job as co-host of NBC's ''Today'' show, a job she has held for 15 years, to take the riskier but historically significant step of becoming the anchor of the ''CBS Evening News.'' [A1.]    As Katie Couric prepares to ascend to anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' she will be moving into a world that for several years has emphasized softer features. Still, some people in the business agree that it will be her ability to direct and deliver so-called hard news that will determine whether she is able to move CBS from its longtime spot in last place among the three network newscasts and to attract younger viewers. [C1.]    Media buyers are asking: When Katie Couric jumps to the ''CBS Evening News,'' will advertising dollars follow? [C5.]    In Massachusetts, a Rare Consensus on Health Care  Massachusetts has more than its share of political egos per capita, so one of the most surprising things about this week's legislation creating near-universal health care coverage is that it involved the cooperation of virtually every political stakeholder in the state. News Analysis. [A16.]    Online Answer to High Drug Costs Runs Into Problems  Canadian online pharmacies -- hailed as an alternative to multinational drug giants -- have been swamped by problems that have cut into sales and forced some of them out of business. [C1.]    Criminal Charges in Britain Over Drug Prices  Five pharmaceutical companies and nine executives are facing criminal charges of conspiracy to defraud the British National Health Service, after an investigation into prices of antibiotics and blood-clotting drugs. [C13.]    Chinese Officials Plan to Show Buying Prowess in U.S.  Chinese leaders, eager to improve relations with the United States ahead of a visit by President Hu Jintao this month, have dispatched a large delegation of business and economic officials to display China's buying power and to cool protectionist sentiment in Congress. [A8.]    Thales of France to Acquire Alcatel Units  Thales, the French military contractor and electronics company, said that it had agreed to buy satellite and security businesses from Alcatel for cash and stock worth about 1.7 billion euros ($2.1 billion) to keep the operations in French hands. The deal comes days after Alcatel agreed to buy Lucent Technologies of New Jersey. [C6.]    Poland Reaches Deal With Italian Bank  Breaking an impasse that had stained its image and put it on a collision course with the European Union, the Polish government reached an agreement with the giant Italian bank UniCredito that allows two Polish banks to be combined under their Italian ownership. Under the deal, UniCredito agreed to sell 200 of the 480 branches of Bank BPH, the big Polish financial institution it acquired last year through its purchase of the HVB Group of Germany. UniCredito's chief executive, Alessandro Profumo, above, said selling the branches ''won't be easy, but the sale will be a clear and transparent process, held internationally.'' [C6.]    Lawmakers Seek Compromise on Immigration  With the prospect of a legislative failure looming, Senate Republicans and Democrats struggled to hammer out a compromise on an immigration bill that would affect the fate of the nation's 11 million illegal immigrants. [A21.]    Russian 'Wine Blockade' Ignites Trade Conflict  Popular wines from Georgia and Moldova have been banned from Russian shelves, spurring a trade dispute. [A12.]    Ford Chief Says Company Has Plenty of Cash  William Clay Ford Jr., the chief executive of Ford Motor, said that he was confident that the automaker could solve its financial problems and said that a bankruptcy filing was not an option. [C3.]

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 - A cryptic Web site that was set up by Microsoft but does not bear its name appears to hint that the company will reveal information about a new consumer product on Thursday. The site caused a flurry of speculation on Internet gadget gossip sites over the weekend.
abstract: A cryptic Web site that was set up by Microsoft but does not bear its name appears to hint that the company will reveal information about a new consumer product on Thursday. The site caused a flurry of speculation on Internet gadget gossip sites over the weekend.      The Web site, www.origamiproject.com, suggests that the introduction of a personalized mobile device that ''will change your life'' is in the offing, but gives no details. It promises an update on Thursday.
