snippet: PATENT--Samuel. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Sam ''Pat'' Patent. Our hearts are with Shirley, Bob, Patti, Susan and all their families. We will always cherish the memories. Allan and Mickey Greenblatt     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. ''Pat'' ...
lead_paragraph: PATENT--Samuel. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Sam "Pat" Patent. Our hearts are with Shirley, Bob, Patti, Susan and all their families. We will always cherish the memories. Allan and Mickey Greenblatt
abstract: PATENT--Samuel. We mourn the passing of our dear friend Sam ''Pat'' Patent. Our hearts are with Shirley, Bob, Patti, Susan and all their families. We will always cherish the memories. Allan and Mickey Greenblatt     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. ''Pat'' We sadly say goodbye to our dear ''Poppa Pat''. He embraced us as his family and we were proud and honored to return his love. We came to know this wonderful man who put love of family and loyalty to friends above all else. Pat lived his life in the same manner in which he left it...on his own terms. We are left with countless memories of celebrations together and many of his stories to remember, for he was a great raconteur. His presence at our table will be missed. To Shirley, Susan, Bob, Patti, Leslie, Michael, Lauren, Russell and Sydney, Ali and Barry, you know how deep our sympathies lie. Our arms are around you all. He loved you all with every inch of his enormous heart. Joanne, Richie, Jason and Jenny     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of Samuel Patent, a member of the club for 41 years. We extend our sincere condolences to his bereaved wife Shirley, his children Robert, Patricia and Susan and his entire family. Jeffrey I. Citron, President Lawrence Handelsman, Secretary     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. Poppa: You will always be our hero. Your strength, love, support, wisdom and affection have shaped our entire family. You loved to make us laugh and smile and forever will. Each of us was the apple of your eye and you will always be our star sapphire. We will miss you each and every day of our lives. All our love, Leslie, Michael, Ali, Barry, Lauren, Russell and Sydney     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. (Pat). Our dear friend Pat, your spirit will always be with us. Thanks for the memories. Our condolences to Shirley and your wonderful family. Vera and Stanley Miller     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel R. Age 91. Beloved and cherished husband of Shirley for nearly 65 years. Loving and devoted father of Susan, Robert and Patricia. Adored and adoring Poppa of Lauren and Russell, Alison and Barry, Leslie, Michael and great-granddaughter Sydney Alexandra. We will forever miss his love, his wisdom and his counsel. Services private. The family will be at home in White Plains, Tuesday and Wednesday, from 1-4 pm and 7-9 pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY; or The Morse Geriatric Center, West Palm Beach, FL.     $(6$)PATENT--Samuel. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Samuel Patent. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Shirley Patent, and their family. Allan Greenblatt, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary

lead_paragraph: When YouTube emerged as one of the Internet's most popular Web sites last year, many TV executives dismissed it as a flash in the pan -- and a largely illegal one at that. lead_paragraph: Tim Andree joined Dentsu America, New York, the new name for DCA Advertising, as its first American chief executive. He succeeds Toyo Shigeta, who becomes chief executive at Dentsu Holdings, part of the Japanese agency Dentsu, overseeing all Dentsu operations in Canada and the United States. Mr. Andree had been chief marketing and communications officer at the BASF Corporation, Florham Park, N.J., and before that was senior vice president in charge of the marketing communications functions at the National Basketball Association, New York. Also at Dentsu America, Doug Fidoten, executive vice president, was promoted to president.

snippet: PIPELINE LEAK SENDS OIL HIGHER -- BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already-high wor...
lead_paragraph: PIPELINE LEAK SENDS OIL HIGHER -- BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel. BP said it could not estimate how long the system would be down. [Page A1.]
abstract: PIPELINE LEAK SENDS OIL HIGHER -- BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel. BP said it could not estimate how long the system would be down. [Page A1.]    STOCKS FALL ON OIL WORRIES -- Stocks declined as crude oil surged after BP began shutting down its field in Alaska for emergency repairs. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.59 points, to 1275.77. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 20.97 points, to 11,219.38. The Nasdaq lost 12.55 points, to 2,072.50. [C12.]    SHORTCHANGING PUBLIC PENSIONS -- A number of states, counties and municipalities have engaged in maneuvers similar to the city worker pension fund in San Diego, which, after being underfunded, set off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments. [A1.]    TRADING IN CADAVERS -- ''Body Worlds,'' a show displaying preserved, skinless human corpses, has attracted 20 million people worldwide over the past decade and taken in over $200 million. But now with millions of people flocking to see that exhibition and others like it, a ghastly new underground cadaver industry has emerged in China. [A1.]    CELLPHONE BOOM IN IRAQ -- The State Department said there are 7.1 million cellphone subscribers in Iraq, up from 1.4 million two years ago. [A1.]    MARTHA STEWART SETTLEMENT -- Martha Stewart, the celebrated domestic tastemaker, reached a settlement with securities regulators over insider-trading accusations, agreeing to pay $195,000 to conclude a five-year legal battle that once put a dent in her brand name. [C1.]    GOOGLE IN DEAL WITH MYSPACE -- Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com, the social networking phenomenon, as well as other Web sites owned by the News Corporation. [C1.]    I.B.M. CLEARED IN RETIREMENT CASE -- A three-judge appellate panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age-discrimination suits. [C1.]    FORBES FAMILY SAGA -- The sale of 40 percent of the company that publishes Forbes magazine may resolve some growing tensions among Forbes family members, some of whom have been unhappy about the sale of nonpublishing family assets in the last six years. [C1.]    THE MAN BEHIND THE FORBES DEAL -- Wall Street bankers are abuzz about Roger McNamee, a force in Silicon Valley venture capital circles who founded Elevation Partners, a private equity firm that has invested an estimated $250 million in the Forbes publishing business. [C1.]    APPLE COMPLETES TRANSITION -- Apple Computer said it had completed its transition to computers based entirely on Intel processors. [C4.]    WAL-MART TO RAISE SALARIES -- Wal-Mart Stores said it would raise starting salaries at a third of its United States stores by about 6 percent after a company survey found that it needed to improve hourly pay to remain competitive. [C4.]    AOL REMOVES SEARCH DATA -- AOL removed a list of the Web search queries of 658,000 unnamed users from a public Web site over the weekend, after bloggers complained that the information was so detailed and personal that it could compromise the users' privacy. [C4.]    NEW TACTICS FOR MAGAZINES -- Condé Nast's Fashion Rocks extravaganza demonstrates what it takes for a publisher to stay relevant lately: staging outsize, razzle-dazzle productions that incorporate television, the Web and wireless communications, but have relatively little to do with a print product. Advertising. [C4.]    OUTREACH TO INDIA -- The Bush administration is organizing a business delegation to India this fall, potentially the largest such mission ever to a single country and one that underscores the economic potential of a nation of 1.1 billion. [C7.]    COLA CAMPAIGN IN INDIA -- PepsiCo and Coca-Cola intensified a long-running campaign in India to prove that their products are safe, as local governments imposed a partial ban on their soft drinks. [C7.]    ONLINE    MORTGAGES -- Bob Tedeschi's weekly column on mortgages and finances can be found at nytimes.com/realestate.    ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    ONE FOR BABY -- For years baby food changed little. Now there has been a growth spurt of alternatives, from single-ingredient purées to complete toddler meals in designer packages. A report is at nytimes.com/style.    TWO NEW G.M. PICKUPS -- Chevrolet and GMC introduce the 2007 Silverado and Sierra pickups -- delivering what G.M. says is the best power and fuel economy in the segment. A report is at nytimes.com/automobiles.

lead_paragraph: SONOMA, California — The California wine industry sometimes seems to exist in two parallel universes. In one, the air is heavy with a smug sense of self-congratulation. Billionaires buy pieces of Napa Valley, charge $150 a bottle for the first vintage and want you to understand, by the way, that they do it all for charity. Earnest ideologues natter on about the terroir in their 16 cuvées of pinot noir, but the wines all taste the same. Hot young consultants notch more 95-point wines than Paris Hilton has boyfriends. It's the gospel written by publicists.

snippet: Considering A Media Center PC    Q. I am thinking about buying a new computer in the next month, before I am forced to buy Windows Vista. I see lots of machines with ''Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005.'' What is the difference between this and...
lead_paragraph: Considering A Media Center PC
abstract: Considering A Media Center PC    Q. I am thinking about buying a new computer in the next month, before I am forced to buy Windows Vista. I see lots of machines with ''Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005.'' What is the difference between this and good old XP?    A. Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005 is a version of Windows XP that is geared more for home-entertainment purposes -- like playing or displaying music, photos and video -- than for just typical computing chores like spreadsheets and word processing. Since it can run programs written for Windows XP, a Media Center PC can also do spreadsheets and word processing, and it can connect to the Internet for Web surfing and e-mail.

snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-11    U.S. Opens an Inquiry Into Israeli Cluster Bombs  The State Department is investigating whether Israel's use of American-made cluster bombs in southern Lebanon violated secret agreements with the United States that restrict ...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11
abstract: INTERNATIONAL A3-11    U.S. Opens an Inquiry Into Israeli Cluster Bombs  The State Department is investigating whether Israel's use of American-made cluster bombs in southern Lebanon violated secret agreements with the United States that restrict when such weapons can be employed, two officials said.  A1    France pledged to send 2,000 troops to the United Nations multinational peacekeeping force for Lebanon, in a last-minute effort to salvage its flagging reputation and hold on to its leadership role in the face of Italian competition.  A11    Refugees returning to their neighborhoods in southern Lebanon have found an enormous tally of damage to their homes and to local infrastructure, including what they say was gratuitous destruction after the cease-fire began by Israeli soldiers still stationed nearby.  A10    Journalist Sentenced to 3 Years  A Beijing court unexpectedly dismissed a state secrets charge against a researcher for The New York Times but sentenced him to three years in prison on a lesser, unrelated charge of fraud.  A1    Iran Exhibits Anti-Jewish Art  An exhibit in Tehran featuring cartoons challenging accounts of the Holocaust opened this month as a response to the Danish newspaper cartoons that lampooned the Prophet Muhammad. But while Iranians say they are angry at Israel, they do not seem in a rush to see the show.  A8    Iraqi Cleric Presses Politicians  In a rare political statement, Iraq's most prominent Shiite religious leader has urged government ministers and members of Parliament to refrain from taking trips abroad and focus on improving the lives of ordinary citizens, a spokesman said.  A5    Charity Suspected in Plane Plot  The British Charity Commission said it was formally investigating the aid group Crescent Relief and has frozen its funds following allegations that the charity was linked to a thwarted terrorist plot to blow up trans-Atlantic flights.  A6    U.S. Envoy to Visit Sudan  President Bush dispatched his senior African affairs official to Sudan to try to persuade its government to accept a United Nations peacekeeping force in Darfur. At the United Nations, Sudan rebuffed a Security Council invitation to discuss the resolution creating the force.  A7    2nd Arrest in German Plot  The second suspect in a failed plot to bomb two German trains turned himself in to the police in Lebanon, encouraging German authorities in a case that has unnerved the country and prompted a debate over its antiterrorism policies.  A6    Dutch Clear 12 on India Flight  Dutch authorities said they were releasing all 12 passengers arrested after they aroused suspicion on a Northwest Airlines flight to India, which made an emergency landing in Amsterdam. The police said the men had been unruly but no evidence was found that they had planned any terrorist acts.  A6    NATIONAL A12-18    Next-Day Pill Is Approved For Over-the-Counter Sale  The Food and Drug Administration approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive pill to those 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's history.  A1    New Orleans Shops Struggle  Across New Orleans, a year after Hurricane Katrina, shoppers, store owners, economists, even government officials share the fear that the city's little restaurants, independent stores and small manufacturers will close for good.  A1    Already Campaigning for 2008  Potential presidential contenders are building the foundations of their 2008 campaigns in what officials in both parties describe as an urgent, unusually aggressive and amazingly early effort.  A1    Reordering the Solar System  Astronomers voted on a sweeping reclassification of the solar system, demoting Pluto to the status of a ''dwarf planet.'' In the new solar system there are eight planets, at least three dwarf planets, and a multitude of ''smaller solar system bodies.''  A13    NEW YORK/REGION B1-6    Corzine Nominates Adviser For New Attorney General  Gov. Jon S. Corzine nominated his chief counsel, Stuart J. Rabner, to become New Jersey's next attorney general. The announcement came nine days after Zulima V. Farber resigned as attorney general after an investigation found that she had violated state ethics rules by going to the aid of her companion during a traffic stop.  B1    Broadcast Leads to Arrest  A Staten Island man who ran a small startup company that provided satellite television services to households was arrested and his business raided by federal agents. He was charged with providing services that included satellite broadcasts of a television station controlled by the terrorist group Hezbollah -- a violation of federal law.  B1    OBITUARIES C10    Maynard Ferguson  A musician whose soaring trumpeting reached the instrument's highest ranges and propelled a musical career of more than 60 years, he was 78. C10    BUSINESS DAY C1-9    Apple Recalls Batteries  Apple Computer said that it was recalling 1.8 million battery packs from some models of its computers. C1    Business Digest C2    EDITORIAL A20-21    Editorials: Wanted: scarier intelligence; easier access to morning-after pills; and now there are eight; a (terror) fish story.    Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas Frank.    Crossword E2  Public Lives B2  TV Listings E25  Weather B7

lead_paragraph: THERE was such a fuss last year over a few thrifty individuals who auctioned their foreheads and pregnant bellies as advertising space, via a temporary tattoo, that one has to wonder if people realize they are voluntarily handing over their derrieres to the marketers of designer jeans on a daily basis.
abstract: THERE was such a fuss last year over a few thrifty individuals who auctioned their foreheads and pregnant bellies as advertising space, via a temporary tattoo, that one has to wonder if people realize they are voluntarily handing over their derrieres to the marketers of designer jeans on a daily basis.     The signature inverted peak stitched on a pair of Levi's is as recognizable to most Americans as the name itself, and discerning shoppers can easily identify the maker of the hottest denim labels simply by eyeing their embroideries. So in a sense, bottoms are billboards, too.

snippet: WIDER CONTRACEPTIVE SALES -- The Food and Drug Administration approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive called Plan B to those 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's history. Over-the-co...
lead_paragraph: WIDER CONTRACEPTIVE SALES -- The Food and Drug Administration approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive called Plan B to those 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's history. Over-the-counter sales will begin by the end of the year. [Page A1.]
abstract: WIDER CONTRACEPTIVE SALES -- The Food and Drug Administration approved over-the-counter sales of the morning-after contraceptive called Plan B to those 18 and older, resolving one of the most contentious issues in the agency's history. Over-the-counter sales will begin by the end of the year. [Page A1.]    FINANCIAL SIDE EFFECTS -- The long political debate over the Plan B emergency contraceptive pill may have helped raise the profile of its maker, Barr Pharmaceuticals, but over-the-counter sales of Plan B will barely register on the company's balance sheet. That is why Barr does not plan to advertise the drug on television or radio. [C1.]    APPLE RECALLS BATTERIES -- Apple Computer said it was recalling 1.8 million battery packs from some laptop computer models because of a risk that they could overheat and catch fire. The batteries were made by a unit of Sony, which also made the 4.1 million laptop batteries that Dell recalled last week. [C1.]    HOME SALE DISCOUNTS -- As home sales fall rapidly and the number of houses on the market continues to surge, many sellers are offering thousands of dollars in perks so they do not have to slice deeply into asking prices. As a result, home prices may now be falling, despite what the official numbers show, many economists say. [C1.]    HONG KONG AND THE LAW -- An assault on one of Hong Kong's best-known lawmakers and litigators could raise concerns about the potential for damage to Hong Kong's reputation for the fair settlement of disputes in court. [C1.]    AOL TO OFFER 4 STUDIOS' MOVIES -- AOL said it would offer movies from four major Hollywood studios for downloading on its Internet video service. [C7.]    SIGNS OF SLOWING GROWTH -- Sales of new homes and orders for durable goods both fell more than expected in July, providing further evidence of slowing economic growth. [C3.]    STOCKS EDGE HIGHER -- Wall Street managed a razor-thin gain as investors sifted through data that pointed to stable interest rates, but also suggested that the economy had moderated more than expected. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.56 points, to 11,304.46. [C7.]    FANNIE MAE CASE DROPPED -- Almost two years after it started investigating accounting improprieties at Fannie Mae, the mortgage giant, the Justice Department is no longer pursuing criminal charges, the company and federal officials said. [C3.]    RUSSIANS RETURN PHONES -- The Russian authorities returned 117,519 Motorola mobile phones worth $15 million that had been seized at a Moscow airport five months ago. [A7.]    LABOR DISPUTE GOES TO COURT -- The makings of an old-fashioned airline labor standoff involving Northwest Airlines, flight attendants and the federal government will come together today in federal court in New York. [C3.]    DRUGSTORE SALE ANNOUNCED -- The Jean Coutu Group of Canada confirmed it would sell its Eckerd and Brooks drugstore chains in the United States to Rite Aid for $2.55 billion in cash and stock. When the deal is completed, Coutu, founded by Jean Coutu, above, a pharmacist who wears a lab coat at work and occasionally dispenses pills at his stores, will own about 30 percent of Rite Aid. [C5.]    CHINESE BANK DEAL -- The China Construction Bank, one of China's four main state-controlled banks, agreed to buy the retail banking operations in Hong Kong and Macao of the Bank of America for $1.25 billion. [C5.]    LAWYER LEAVING EMBATTLED FIRM -- The embattled securities class-action law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, was dealt another blow after a prominent trial lawyer, Patricia M. Hynes, said she was leaving. [C3.]    MAKING A NAME FOR CW -- To help their new CW broadcast network gain traction in the proverbial 500-channel universe, CBS and Time Warner are sponsoring an ambitious campaign to create an identity for it. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C7.]    WAL-MART DROPS NEW YORK SITE -- Wal-Mart's plans to open its first New York City store in Staten Island have fallen through, company officials confirmed. [B6.]    ONLINE    SWEET, WEIRD OR FRAUD? Virginia Heffernan evaluates the competing claims for an online video star, lonelygirl15, in her blog at screens.blogs.nytimes.com.    THE POUR -- Eric Asimov, chief wine critic for The Times, discusses the pleasure, culture and business of wine, beer and spirits in his blog at thepour.blogs.nytimes.com.    HOUSING VIRGINS OF MANHATTAN -- The first apartment hunt is a rite of passage in the jungle that is Manhattan. For the newest New Yorkers, it is a crash course in street smarts. A report is at nytimes.com/realestate.    DRIVE TIMES -- A comprehensive source of auto reviews and car industry news from The Times and around the Web is available in newsletter form at nytimes.com/automobiles.    SMALL BUSINESSES ABROAD -- The language, legal and social barriers to starting an international small business may prove costly, but for those who are up for the challenge, the rewards can be great. A report is at nytimes.com/worldbusiness.    OUT OF SIBERIA -- In a shift from controversial and legally questionable practices in the 1990's, Russia's richest men are seeking legitimacy by investing abroad. A report is at nytimes.com/yourmoney.    YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with a free weekly newsletter available at nytimes.com/yourmoney.

lead_paragraph: With gas prices soaring, a number of hotel chains are rolling out gas-related discounts.
abstract: With gas prices soaring, a number of hotel chains are rolling out gas-related discounts.      Through Sept. 10, Gaylord Hotels, which has resorts in Dallas, Nashville and Kissimmee, Fla., is offering $25 a day to guests who stay a minimum of two nights. About a dozen Best Western hotels in California are giving gas credits. They include properties in Pacifica (www.bestwesternlighthouse.com), Half Moon Bay (www.halfmoonbaylodge.com) and San Diego (www.bestwestern-bluesea.com) offering $50 gas cards to guests who stay three or more nights by May 25 and use promotion code Gas50 when booking online.

snippet: Nikolaus Geyrhalter channeled his curiosity about modern meals into a documentary that depicts the mechanical monotony of industrialized food production.
lead_paragraph: THREE years ago the Austrian filmmaker Nikolaus Geyrhalter grew curious about what lay behind the sunny images of food in advertisements and packages. He had read that Europeans were spending 8 percent of their income on food. In the 1950s the figure was 30 percent, and Mr. Geyrhalter wondered what, apart from an increase in affluence, made modern meals so cheap.

snippet: Fresh-fruit fanatics hit the Hood River Fruit Loop, a loosely affiliated network of orchards, produce stands and berry farms in northwest Oregon.
lead_paragraph: AFTER we had driven just a few hours along the Hood River Fruit Loop in northwest Oregon, the inside of our car already showed telltale signs of a midsummer's cherry binge. The seats were awash in a crinkly sea of tiny brown paper bags that riffled in the mountain breeze. Mis-spit pits, once shiny and slick, fused themselves to the super-heated plastic dashboard.
abstract: Fresh-fruit fanatics hit the Hood River Fruit Loop, a loosely affiliated network of orchards, produce stands and berry farms in northwest Oregon.

snippet: Documentary Our Daily Bread by Austrian filmmaker Nikolaus Geyrhalter examines mechanical monotony of industrialized food production; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THREE years ago the Austrian filmmaker Nikolaus Geyrhalter grew curious about what lay behind the sunny images of food in advertisements and packages. He had read that Europeans were spending 8 percent of their income on food. In the 1950s the figure was 30 percent, and Mr. Geyrhalter wondered what, apart from an increase in affluence, made modern meals so cheap.
abstract: Documentary Our Daily Bread by Austrian filmmaker Nikolaus Geyrhalter examines mechanical monotony of industrialized food production; photo (M)

snippet: Childproof trigger locks on handguns should rank somewhere near mom and apple pie as a measure of the nation's wholesome dedication to life. But not in the House of Representatives, where the gun lobby cowed lawmakers into actually barring the use...
lead_paragraph: Childproof trigger locks on handguns should rank somewhere near mom and apple pie as a measure of the nation's wholesome dedication to life. But not in the House of Representatives, where the gun lobby cowed lawmakers into actually barring the use of federal funds to enforce an existing law that requires child trigger locks to be sold with all handguns. This late-night treachery just before the July 4 recess means that federal agents will not have the resources to confront one of the deadliest facts of American family life: 10 young people die each day in gun homicides, suicides and accidents.
abstract: Childproof trigger locks on handguns should rank somewhere near mom and apple pie as a measure of the nation's wholesome dedication to life. But not in the House of Representatives, where the gun lobby cowed lawmakers into actually barring the use of federal funds to enforce an existing law that requires child trigger locks to be sold with all handguns. This late-night treachery just before the July 4 recess means that federal agents will not have the resources to confront one of the deadliest facts of American family life: 10 young people die each day in gun homicides, suicides and accidents.      The rate of firearm death for children 14 years and under is almost 12 times higher in this country than in 25 other industrialized nations combined, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Yet there was the law-and-order majority caving in to the gun lobby.

headline.main: Eager Helpers for the Gun Lobby
headline.print_headline: Eager Helpers for the Gun Lobby

snippet: U.S. TO RENEW TIES WITH LIBYA -- The Bush administration announced that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya, which is led by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. While Libya is a major oil-producing state, a State Department official insiste...
lead_paragraph: U.S. TO RENEW TIES WITH LIBYA -- The Bush administration announced that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya, which is led by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. While Libya is a major oil-producing state, a State Department official insisted: "This decision is not undertaken because Libya has oil." [Page A1.]
abstract: U.S. TO RENEW TIES WITH LIBYA -- The Bush administration announced that it would re-establish full diplomatic ties with Libya, which is led by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. While Libya is a major oil-producing state, a State Department official insisted: ''This decision is not undertaken because Libya has oil.'' [Page A1.]    BAUSCH TO STOP PRODUCT'S SALE -- Bausch & Lomb said that it was halting sales of a soft-contact lens cleaner because tests showed that misuse could lead to an infection, and possibly blindness. [C1.]    HOSTILE TAKEOVERS -- Mike Matthews, a sound-effects designer and onetime promoter of Jimi Hendrix, bought a Russian factory making vacuum tubes for guitar amplifiers. But he has encountered a problem increasingly common in Russia: someone is trying to steal his company. [C1.]    BELLSOUTH DISPUTES REPORT -- BellSouth said that it had not shared customer calling records with the National Security Agency, denying a report last week that it was among three major telephone companies to have done so. [A18.]    HEART DEVICE SAFETY -- Two major producers of heart devices, Medtronic and St. Jude Medical, responding to a report critical of the industry's oversight of product safety, said they planned to broaden how they conduct such reviews. [C3.]    ENRON TRIAL -- During closing arguments at the Enron fraud trial in Houston, a prosecutor accused two former Enron chief executives of ''extraordinary arrogance'' and called them ''masters of the cover story'' who pushed the rules and crossed the line into illegality. [C1.]    YUAN GAINS -- China allowed its currency to strengthen past the symbolic level of eight yuan to the dollar, rattling Asian markets. [C1.]    WI-FI IN THE PARK -- New York officials set a July deadline for a city contractor to have a wireless network up and running in Central Park, in what would be a major expansion of free Internet access. [B3.]    STOCKS RISE -- Stocks advanced as a plunge in oil and metals prices eased concern that accelerating inflation would drive the Federal Reserve to keep raising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 47.78 points, or 0.4 percent, to 11,428.77. [C15.]    CARBON MARKET -- The European carbon trading market, hailed as a way to curb global warming, has suffered nose dives, missteps and misreadings that have led to a clamor for major change. Market Place. [C1.]    EBAY PATENT DISPUTE -- The Supreme Court sent the long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange back to the lower federal courts. [C1.]    RACING THE CLOCK -- After procrastinating for weeks, Medicare beneficiaries flocked to centers for the elderly around the country and made frantic telephone calls to insurers to beat the deadline for getting prescription drug coverage. [A19.]    BOEING SETTLEMENT -- Boeing, the nation's No. 2 military contractor, has agreed to pay $615 million under a tentative deal with federal prosecutors that will allow it to avoid criminal charges. The agreement would end a three-year investigation into wrongdoing by Boeing employees. [C3.]    ABC ADDS TO SCHEDULE -- ABC, which has some of television's biggest hits, and some misses, will announce a new prime-time schedule populated with a raft of new series. [E1.]    LOOKING BEYOND TV -- Eager to improve its ratings and advertising sales, NBC is counting on digital media as much as television for a comeback in the 2006-7 season. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C10.]    'CODE' UNDER WRAPS -- In contemporary Hollywood, to release a movie without first having it undergo test screenings is fairly rare. For one like Sony's ''Da Vinci Code,'' it is close to unprecedented. But to preserve a climate of mystery and excitement around the movie, that has been the studio's course. [E1.]    ONLINE    VIDEO: THE ENRON TRIAL -- Paula Dwyer, deputy business editor; Kurt Eichenwald, investigative reporter; and Joe Nocera, business columnist, discuss the trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling at nytimes.com/enron.    THE WALK-THROUGH BLOG -- A look at residential real estate news, trends and tidbits can be found at nytimes.com/walkthrough.    2006 FALL TV SCHEDULE -- Virginia Heffernan, the Times TV critic, blogs from this week's TV upfronts, where the networks reveal their schedules, and the reporter Bill Carter offers a video analysis at nytimes.com/tv.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    THYSSENKRUPP plans to close a Detroit plant that has built auto parts for 81 years, citing a lack of orders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC., which is controlled by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, said it had amassed a $1.13 billion stake in ConocoPhillips and had made smaller investments in General Electric and United Parcel Service. (REUTERS)    CREATIVE TECHNOLOGY LTD., a distant No. 2 to Apple Computer in the music player market, said yesterday that it had filed patent complaints against Apple in federal court and with a United States trade agency. Creative also said it had filed a lawsuit against Apple in the district court for the Northern District of California, alleging violation of the company's ''Zen'' patent. (REUTERS)

snippet: As is true with much about executive pay, details about exactly how peer groups are compiled have been kept under wraps.
lead_paragraph: LIKE Lake Wobegon, Garrison Keillor’s fictitious Minnesota town where all the children are above average, executive compensation practices often assume that corporate managers are equally superlative. When shareholders question lush pay, they are invariably met with a laundry list of reasons that businesses use to justify such packages. Among that data, no item is more crucial than the “peer group,” a collection of companies that corporations measure themselves against when calculating compensation.
abstract: As is true with much about executive pay, details about exactly how peer groups are compiled have been kept under wraps.

Philippe Krakowsky, executive vice president for strategy at Interpublic in New York, confirmed a report of the negotiations that appeared Friday on Adweek.com. A partnership with Facebook would help give Interpublic agencies and the advertisers working with them useful insights into the youth market, Mr. Krakowsky said.

abstract: IN the second act of Oscar Wilde's ''Importance of Being Earnest,'' Gwendolen Fairfax, the urbane social climber, and Cecily Cardew, the apple-cheeked country ingénue, realize they are both engaged to men they believe to be named Ernest Worthing.      ''This is no time for wearing the shallow mask of manners,'' Cecily declares. ''When I see a spade I call it a spade.'' To which Gwendolen replies: ''I am glad to say that I have never seen a spade. It is obvious that our social spheres have been widely different.''

abstract: Getting Online On the Go    Q. Is there a way to get online by connecting a cellphone to a laptop computer?    A. Many mobile phones can serve double duty as laptop modems these days. This can come in handy when you're nowhere near a wireless hotspot, an Ethernet network or even a telephone landline. If both the phone and the laptop can support Bluetooth connections, you can even link them wirelessly.

snippet: Memo Pad column; American Express Business Travel Monitor reports that costs for business travel, airfare, hotel rooms and rental cars rose in second quarter 2005; Bureau of Transportation Statistics figures show quarterly profit margin among larg...
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS TRAVEL COSTS RISE -- Reflecting robust demand in business travel, airfares, hotel rooms and rental cars all cost more in the second quarter of this year, compared with the second quarter of 2005, according to the American Express Business Travel Monitor, in a report to be released today. The report found that the average paid one-way coach fare jumped 13 percent, to $247, for 329 domestic city pairs tracked by American Express. On 160 international routes tracked, the average one-way coach fare increased 9 percent, to $1,150; one-way business-class fares were up 6 percent, to $4,088; and first-class fares were up 4 percent, at $6,000. Average paid domestic hotel rates, including all categories of hotels from budget to deluxe, rose 3 percent, to $139. Internationally, average hotel rates rose 11 percent, to $237. The average daily cost to rent a car domestically rose 4 percent, to $67.26. "Over the last year, fleet pricing has been rising at a double-digit pace," said Frank Schnur, a vice president at American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. Rising prices are "a trend we expect to continue," he said.
abstract: Memo Pad column; American Express Business Travel Monitor reports that costs for business travel, airfare, hotel rooms and rental cars rose in second quarter 2005; Bureau of Transportation Statistics figures show quarterly profit margin among largest network airlines, low-cost and discount carriers rose to highest average level since 2000; also reports that US airlines carried 369.5 million passengers in first six months of year; Eos adds second daily flight between New York and London; JetBlue begins three daily nonstop flights between Houston and Kennedy International Airport in New York; Westin New York at Times Square upgrades technology in its guest rooms (M)

snippet: Many of California's visionary wineries like Ridge Vineyards and Mount Eden Vineyards produce wines of subtlety and power that age well; difference between those and vineyards owned by celebrities climbing on wine-making bandwagon is modesty that ...
lead_paragraph: SONOMA, Calif. - THE California wine industry sometimes seems to exist in two parallel universes. In one, the air is heavy with a smug sense of self-congratulation. Billionaires buy pieces of Napa Valley, charge $150 a bottle for the first vintage and want you to understand, by the way, that they do it all for charity. Earnest ideologues natter on about the terroir in their 16 cuvées of pinot noir, but the wines all taste the same. Hot young consultants notch more 95-point wines than Paris Hilton has boyfriends. It's the gospel written by publicists.
abstract: Many of California's visionary wineries like Ridge Vineyards and Mount Eden Vineyards produce wines of subtlety and power that age well; difference between those and vineyards owned by celebrities climbing on wine-making bandwagon is modesty that comes from years of accumulated knowledge and realization that some forces are beyond control; photo (M)

snippet: LAW FIRM CHARGED -- The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in...
lead_paragraph: LAW FIRM CHARGED -- The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than 150 class-action lawsuits. [Page A1.]
abstract: LAW FIRM CHARGED -- The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than 150 class-action lawsuits. [Page A1.]    OIL LEASE MEASURE -- In a move to revoke billions of dollars worth of government incentives to oil and gas producers, the House approved 252 to 165 a measure that would order the government to renegotiate more than 1,000 leases with companies that drill in the Gulf of Mexico. [A1.]    AUTO WORKER RETIREES -- For Japanese car companies with manufacturing operations in the United States, the issue of how to treat retirees has mostly been academic so far. But age is creeping up on the American factory workers they started hiring in the mid-1980's. [C1.]    APPLE STORE OPENING -- Apple Computer is opening a showcase store in Manhattan that will burnish a reputation for clever design. [C1.]    DELL TO USE A.M.D. CHIPS -- Dell, which has used only Intel processors until now, announced it would begin using a chip made by Advanced Micro Devices, as part of a broader plan to improve its flagging sales and market share. Earnings for Dell, the world's largest seller of personal computers, were down 18 percent in the first quarter. ''The competitive environment has been more intense than we had planned for or understood,'' said Kevin Rollins, Dell's chief executive, above. [C1.]    DRUG STUDY DETAILED HEART RISK -- Previously unpublished data from the study that led the drug maker Merck to halt sales of its Vioxx painkiller appear to show that the drug raised the risk of heart attack and stroke within a few months -- not after at least 18 months' use, as Merck has consistently argued. [A21.]    PANEL ENDORSES CANCER VACCINE -- A vaccine produced by Merck that blocks viruses that cause most cervical cancer is safe and effective and should be approved, a federal panel advised. [A21.]    SECOND ENRON TRIAL STARTS -- As a jury spent its first full day deliberating the fates of the former Enron chief executives, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, a second criminal trial began with prosecutors accusing Mr. Lay of repeatedly lying to banks about how he would use $75 million in loans. [C4.]    LAY'S LAWYER -- When Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, the former Enron chief executive, was forced into surgery two months ago to clear an arterial blockage, it was the beginning of the most challenging personal odyssey of his career and an event that may turn out to play a crucial role in Mr. Lay's case. [C1.]    RETAILERS REPORT -- Sears Holdings reported first-quarter profit that exceeded analysts' estimates. Sears posted net income of $180 million, or $1.14 a share, in contrast to a loss in the first quarter of 2005. But Gap, the clothing chain, said first-quarter profit fell 17 percent as it struggled to revamp merchandise and increase store traffic. [C9.]    TUNE IN NEXT FALL -- As the broadcast television networks get ready for the fall season, they are turning over more of their evening schedules to episodic serialized programming, a genre as old as ''The Perils of Pauline'' and as new as ''Desperate Housewives.'' Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C6.]    FOX AND CW ROLL OUT SCHEDULES -- The Fox network introduced a new lineup of shows that emphasized stability, while the new CW network -- created from two smaller networks, UPN and WB -- emphasized meld-ability. Fox's big announcement was of a new late-night entry. [E23.]    HEALTHSOUTH TO PAY $3 MILLION -- The Justice Department announced that HealthSouth, the chain of outpatient rehabilitation hospitals, would pay $3 million and avoid prosecution over a giant accounting fraud. [C11.]    ECONOMIC GAUGE FALLS -- An important gauge of the nation's future economic activity dipped in April, once again suggesting slower growth in the months ahead. The Conference Board, a private research group, reported that its index of leading economic indicators fell by 0.1 percentage point, to 138.9, last month. [C9.]    ONLINE    A MAC IN BLACK -- Apple's line of laptops that are aimed at consumers took a leap forward when the company released its new MacBook model. A review by J. D. Biersdorfer is at nytimes.com/technology.    TECHNOLOGY UPDATE -- David Pogue reviews the latest in technology in an e-mail-only newsletter at nytimes.com/technology.    ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    THE CAREER EDUCATION CORPORATION, a higher education company, said shareholders had elected all three of its nominees to the board, rejecting a slate offered by a dissident shareholder, Steven Bostic. Mr. Bostic, who owns nearly 1 percent of the company's stock, had been critical of the management. (REUTERS)    SHARES OF BURGER KING'S parent company rose 3 percent from their initial public offering price of $17 each. Burger King shares rose 50 cents, to $17.50. (AP)    THE CURRENT FED CHAIRMAN, Ben S. Bernanke, and the former chairman, Alan Greenspan, offer some thoughts about the cooling housing market. (AP)

headline.main: Tech Briefing
headline.print_headline: Tech Briefing

snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-9    Bombing in Afghanistan Kills Provincial Governor  Muhammad Hakim Taniwal, governor of Paktia Province in Afghanistan and a close friend of President Hamid Karzai, was killed along with two staff members by a suicide bomber as...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9
abstract: INTERNATIONAL A3-9    Bombing in Afghanistan Kills Provincial Governor  Muhammad Hakim Taniwal, governor of Paktia Province in Afghanistan and a close friend of President Hamid Karzai, was killed along with two staff members by a suicide bomber as they drove away from the president's office, government officials said. A1    Shiites Push New Legislation  A dispute in the Iraqi Parliament peaked as a large Shiite faction continued to fight for quick approval of legislation that would give provinces the authority to create autonomous states. Sunni lawmakers and others in opposition refused to attend the session, warning that the plan could undermine the country's unity government.  A8    Progress in Iran Sanction Talks  Representatives of Iran and the European Union said that they had made progress toward a compromise to avert possible United Nations sanctions over Iran's nuclear program and that they would meet again soon. A9    Blair and Abbas Hold Talks  The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, met with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to discuss forming a Palestinian unity government that would seek to win international acceptance and end the isolation of the current Hamas-led government. A9    China Imposes News Limits  Under new rules, the state-run New China News Agency said it would control foreign news reports, photographs and graphics entering China. The agency announced that it would censor content that ''endangers national security.'' A3    Sri Lankan Rebel Line Breached  At least 28 soldiers were killed and more than 100 wounded as the Sri Lankan Army pushed across Tamil Tiger rebel front lines in the north, the military said. Independent verification was not possible; each side routinely plays down casualties. A8    NATIONAL A10-17    Heated Arizona Primary Draws National Attention  Arizona's Eighth Congressional District is a swing district and one of a handful nationwide that Democrats believe they can capture to reclaim the House. Ten candidates are battling to represent the district in Arizona, a fast-growing state that is not as conservative as it used to be.  A10    Medicare Costs to Increase  Higher-income people will have to pay higher Medicare premiums than other beneficiaries next year, as the government takes a step to help the financially ailing program remain viable over the long term.  A10    Immigration Protests Shrink  In Washington, Los Angeles, Phoenix and Batavia, Ill., immigrant demonstrations drew much smaller crowds than expected. Political analysts, policy makers and immigrants alike are questioning the staying power of the immigrant rights movement.  A11    Cheney on the Insurgency  In a television interview, Vice President Dick Cheney backed away from his insistence last year that the insurgency in Iraq was in its ''last throes,'' but said even if he had known in 2003 that his claims that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction were mistaken, ''we'd do exactly the same thing.'' A12    Shuttle Safely in Orbit  The space shuttle Atlantis appears to have made the jump into orbit without any damage to its heat shield, mission officials said. The mission will resume construction of the International Space Station.  A17    Executive's Fate Unresolved  A Hewlett-Packard board meeting ended with no decision on whether the chairwoman of the company would be asked to resign over her role in an investigation.  A17    At the heart of the Hewlett-Packard controversy is a technique called pretexting -- obtaining someone's calling records under a pretext, like pretending to be a customer.  C1    NEW YORK/REGION B1-5    Bush Visits Ground Zero On Eve of Anniversary  Vowing he was ''never going to forget the lessons of that day,'' President Bush paid tribute to the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attack, laying a wreath at ground zero, attending a prayer service at St. Paul's Chapel and making a few other stops with his wife, Laura. The ceremonies ushered in what will be a solemn day of remembrance, here and around the country as the official commemoration of the fifth anniversary of the attacks.  A1    Newark's Financial Crunch  Mayor Cory A. Booker's grand dreams for a safer, cleaner and more prosperous Newark are colliding with the reality of the city's troubled finances. Having won the election with ambitious promises, Mr. Booker is instead being forced to reduce services and raise taxes.  B1    Hope Fades for Democrats  In a year when Democrats hope to take control of the House of Representatives, New York would appear to be fertile ground for toppling Republican incumbents. But that goal now seems increasingly remote.  A1    SPORTSMONDAY D1-9    Federer Wins U.S. Open  Roger Federer defeated Andy Roddick in the championship game of the United States Open. Federer was 27-1 in the four Grand Slam events this season, winning the Australian Open, Wimbledon and now the United States Open, and it was one more measure of his dominance that no man in this tournament was able to win more than one set against him. D1    OBITUARIES B6    King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV  The king of Tonga, a Polynesian archipelago of 150 islands with 100,000 subjects and the last reigning monarch in the Pacific, he was 88. B6    BUSINESS DAY C1-10    OPEC Price Concerns  OPEC ministers are preparing to meet in Vienna, and the question on their minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they might drop. Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel, driving down the retail price of gasoline and providing some relief for consumers.  C1    Apple's Next Campaign  Apple will hold another of Steven P. Jobs's marketing events to unveil what is expected to be his next campaign: to transform the distribution of movies as thoroughly as he has revolutionized the recording industry with iTunes.  C1    Firms Near Deal in Buyout  A consortium of investment firms were near a deal to acquire Freescale Semiconductor, a former unit of Motorola, for more than $16 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. The deal, if completed, would be the largest leveraged buyout in the technology sector, surpassing the $11.3 billion sale of SunGard Data Systems last year. snippet: Keeping Time With the Internet    Q. How do you set the computer's time to an Internet clock?    A. Windows XP and Mac OS X include the ability to synchronize the computer's clock with an Internet time server. In Windows XP, right-click on the clo...
lead_paragraph: Keeping Time With the Internet
abstract: Keeping Time With the Internet    Q. How do you set the computer's time to an Internet clock?    A. Windows XP and Mac OS X include the ability to synchronize the computer's clock with an Internet time server. In Windows XP, right-click on the clock in the taskbar and choose Adjust Date/Time from the menu. In the Date and Time Properties box, click on the Internet Time tab. Check the box to synchronize the PC with an Internet time server and then select a server from the drop-down menu. Click the Update Now button to update your system clock before clicking O.K. to close the box.

headline.main: Keeping Time With the Internet

abstract: Password Protection For Portable Drives    Q. Can the data on a U.S.B. flash drive be password-protected?    A. She installed a 32-ton block of ice in the boiler room of a disused London pumping station, leaving it to melt away over the course of two months.

snippet: THE COLDEST WINTER: A Stringer in Liberated Europe, by Paula Fox. (Picador, $13.) In her acclaimed 1999 memoir, ''Borrowed Finery,'' Fox -- the author of six novels and many children's books -- reflected on her traumatic childhood. This spare, ele...
lead_paragraph: THE COLDEST WINTER: A Stringer in Liberated Europe, by Paula Fox. (Picador, $13.) In her acclaimed 1999 memoir, "Borrowed Finery," Fox -- the author of six novels and many children's books -- reflected on her traumatic childhood. This spare, elegant follow-up encompasses the months she spent as a reporter for a small British news service in post-World War II Europe. Fox zeroes in on evocative details and anecdotes; passing a drunken and weepy Winston Churchill, she notes that the mascara he wore for filmed interviews "was puddling under his eyes before it ran down his plump cheeks." LEGENDS OF MODERNITY: Essays and Letters From Occupied Poland, 1942-1943, by Czeslaw Milosz. Translated by Madeline G. Levine. Introduction by Jaroslaw Anders. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.) As a young man Milosz (1911-2004), a Nobel Prize-winning poet and essayist, lived in Warsaw during the German occupation, writing for Polish underground publications. This volume includes essays from that period as well as exchanges between Milosz and the writer Jerzy Andrzejewski.

lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, nothing seemed less likely than the sale of Pixar to the Walt Disney Co. At the time, it looked as if the two companies wouldn't even be able to agree on the terms of their distribution deal, which gave Disney, then run by Michael Eisner, an unfair stake in Pixar's films, according to Pixar's chief executive, Steven Jobs. Now Eisner is gone, and on Tuesday Disney's board approved an offer of $7.4 billion, about $59 a share, to acquire Pixar, whose major shareholder is Jobs. The deal now goes to the Pixar board.

lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, nothing seemed less likely than the sale of Pixar to the Walt Disney Company. At the time, it looked as if the two companies wouldn't even be able to agree on the terms of their distribution deal, which gave Disney, then run by Michael Eisner, an unfair stake in Pixar's films, according to Pixar's chief executive, Steven Jobs. Now Mr. Eisner is gone, and on Tuesday Disney's board approved an offer of $7.4 billion, about $59 a share, to acquire Pixar, whose major shareholder is Mr. Jobs. The deal now goes to the Pixar board.
abstract: A couple of years ago, nothing seemed less likely than the sale of Pixar to the Walt Disney Company. At the time, it looked as if the two companies wouldn't even be able to agree on the terms of their distribution deal, which gave Disney, then run by Michael Eisner, an unfair stake in Pixar's films, according to Pixar's chief executive, Steven Jobs. Now Mr. Eisner is gone, and on Tuesday Disney's board approved an offer of $7.4 billion, about $59 a share, to acquire Pixar, whose major shareholder is Mr. Jobs. The deal now goes to the Pixar board.     A company like that -- and a figure like Mr. Jobs, notable for his dynamic role at both Apple and Pixar -- doesn't let itself be bought for money alone, though the money is certainly enticing enough. This is really an opportunity to infect, and change, the creative culture of Disney, which, back in its founder's day, used to be one of the most creative places around.

headline.main: Change From Within at Disney
headline.print_headline: Change From Within at Disney

lead_paragraph: Helping A Balky Laptop
abstract: Helping A Balky Laptop    Q. I get an occasional ''insufficient system resources exist to complete the API'' message when I try to put my laptop in hibernation. When I bought this laptop six months ago, I was impressed with its speed in booting and opening programs, but now it has slowed dramatically, even with two gigabytes of RAM. What can I do?    A. In an article in its technical support database, Microsoft has acknowledged a problem with the hibernation function and computers that have more than one gigabyte of memory installed.

snippet: Op-Ed article by Hudson River Valley artisan agricultural spirits distiller Ralph Erenzo Op-Ed article supports bills sponsored by New York State Sen Bill Larkin and Assemblyman Kevin Cahill that would eliminate artificial distinction between alco...
lead_paragraph: GARDINER, N.Y. - SUPPOSE you decide to spend the weekend upstate, looking forward to visiting a favorite bistro or tavern. When the server asks for your drink order, you'll most likely order a glass of wine or a mug of beer. Since holders of wine and beer permits are allowed to serve wine and beer that are up to 24 percent alcohol by volume (or what's known as 48 proof) and, oddly enough, the Korean distilled spirit soju, defined specifically as "imported from Korea," your waiter can easily comply with your request. But if you wanted to order any other distilled spirit, for instance a local fruit brandy made from Hudson Valley apples grown in the orchard down the road, you'd be out of luck. You'd have to go to a bar or a restaurant with a much harder to obtain and costlier full liquor license.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Hudson River Valley artisan agricultural spirits distiller Ralph Erenzo Op-Ed article supports bills sponsored by New York State Sen Bill Larkin and Assemblyman Kevin Cahill that would eliminate artificial distinction between alcohol in distilled spirits like brandy and alcohol in fermented products like wine; holds impact of amendment would greatly help small farmers in state besieged by foreign competition, government regulations and land developers by allowing them to become distillers (M)

lead_paragraph: Gardiner, N.Y. - SUPPOSE you decide to spend the weekend upstate, looking forward to visiting a favorite bistro or tavern. When the server asks for your drink order, you'll most likely order a glass of wine or a mug of beer. Since holders of wine and beer permits are allowed to serve wine and beer that are up to 24 percent alcohol by volume (or what's known as 48 proof) and, oddly enough, the Korean distilled spirit soju, defined specifically as "imported from Korea," your waiter can easily comply with your request. But if you wanted to order any other distilled spirit, for instance a local fruit brandy made from Hudson Valley apples grown in the orchard down the road, you'd be out of luck. You'd have to go to a bar or a restaurant with a much harder to obtain and costlier full liquor license.
abstract: SUPPOSE you decide to spend the weekend upstate, looking forward to visiting a favorite bistro or tavern. When the server asks for your drink order, you'll most likely order a glass of wine or a mug of beer. Since holders of wine and beer permits are allowed to serve wine and beer that are up to 24 percent alcohol by volume (or what's known as 48 proof) and, oddly enough, the Korean distilled spirit soju, defined specifically as ''imported from Korea,'' your waiter can easily comply with your request. But if you wanted to order any other distilled spirit, for instance a local fruit brandy made from Hudson Valley apples grown in the orchard down the road, you'd be out of luck. You'd have to go to a bar or a restaurant with a much harder to obtain and costlier full liquor license.     Two pieces of legislation, one sponsored by Senator Bill Larkin and the other by Assemblyman Kevin Cahill, are making their way through Albany. These bills finally eliminate the artificial distinction between the alcohol in distilled spirits like brandy and the alcohol in fermented products like wine. Their passage would permit licensees to serve any 100 percent New York State distillate that is 48 proof or lower.

snippet: If Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of The Walt Disney Company, and Steven P. Jobs, chief of Pixar Animation, played characters in a movie, it could well be Pixar's own computer-animated ''Toy Story.''      As Buzz Lightyear, a space-age superh...
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Jan, 22 - If Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of The Walt Disney Company, and Steven P. Jobs, chief of Pixar Animation, played characters in a movie, it could well be Pixar's own computer-animated "Toy Story."
abstract: If Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of The Walt Disney Company, and Steven P. Jobs, chief of Pixar Animation, played characters in a movie, it could well be Pixar's own computer-animated ''Toy Story.''      As Buzz Lightyear, a space-age superhero who can seemingly fly, Mr. Jobs is the perfect foil to Mr. Iger, whose smoothly coiffed hair and earnest intentions bring to mind the amiable cowboy Woody. And like the two characters, Mr. Iger and Mr. Jobs, who is also chief executive of Apple Computer, are friendly and sometimes cautious rivals, but that relationship could change substantially.

abstract: FORESTVILLE, in western Sonoma County, Calif., has been a summer destination for San Franciscans since Victorian times, when the train would deposit families to spend several months in cabins along the beaches of the Russian River, about 10 miles from the coast.     ''Forestville was a gathering place for bohemians and writers and artists, circa 1900,'' said Jonah Raskin, an author and journalism professor at Sonoma State University who moved to Forestville from New York in the 1970's. ''Jack London and his friends used to go there.''

snippet: When the iPod Won't Charge    Q. I left my iPod plugged into my computer all night and it didn't get fully charged. Why is this?    A. Several things can affect the iPod's ability to charge its battery while plugged into your PC or Mac. For starte...
lead_paragraph: When the iPod Won't Charge
abstract: When the iPod Won't Charge    Q. I left my iPod plugged into my computer all night and it didn't get fully charged. Why is this?    A. Several things can affect the iPod's ability to charge its battery while plugged into your PC or Mac. For starters, most computers won't charge the iPod if they go to sleep after a period of inactivity, so check your system settings for sleep or hibernation. Low-powered U.S.B. ports, like the kind found on keyboards, may also fail to charge the iPod.

lead_paragraph: What's the best way to share computer files with friends, family and associates? Many files today are too big for floppy disks, and many computers now lack drives for the disks anyway. Some files are too big to e-mail (especially to people with dial-up connections). Burning files to CD's is time-consuming, and most CD's can't be reused. And you hate to send out expensive U.S.B. flash drives.

snippet: Forget blue states and red states. The more important divide is between the blue city and the red country.
lead_paragraph: The problem with all the talk about Americans living in a country divided between red and blue states lies not in the idea of division itself. The problem lies in framing the whole issue around states. We do live in a divided nation, but states are not the organizing principle we should use in thinking about the split. We are divided between the blue city and the red country.
abstract: Forget blue states and red states. The more important divide is between the blue city and the red country.

snippet: FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphre...
lead_paragraph: FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Bernanke will address the Senate Banking Committee; the next day he will testify to the House Financial Services Committee. With Mr. Bernanke still in his rookie year, many on Wall Street can be expected to be parsing his speech for signs of what kind of player he might turn out to be. (Wednesday and Thursday.)

FANNIE AND FREDDIE -- At the New York Yacht Club, a few people with some strong opinions about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the huge government-sponsored mortgage packagers, will be on hand for a panel discussion about how the two should be regulated -- or perhaps punished. Randal K. Quarles, the Treasury under secretary for domestic finance, and James B. Lockhart III, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, both of whom have been outspoken about the management and accounting scandals at the two companies, will be offering their views. (Wednesday.)    A FLURRY OF REPORTS -- So many economic indicators, so little time. There will be updates on inflation with the Producer Price Index for June (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for June (Wednesday). Other reports: industrial production and capacity utilization for June (Monday); June housing starts (Wednesday); and Federal Reserve minutes for June and the Conference Board's leading economic indicators (Thursday).    EARNINGS DRUMBEAT -- Earnings season gets into full swing this week, starting on Monday with Citigroup. Tuesday's roster will include Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, United Technologies and Yahoo. On Wednesday: AMR, Apple Computer, Bank of America, eBay, General Dynamics, Intel, J. P. Morgan Chase, Motorola, Southwest Airlines and UnitedHealth Group. Thursday: Advanced Micro Devices, Ford Motor, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Nokia, Pfizer, SAP, Wachovia and Wyeth. And on Friday: Caterpillar and Eli Lilly.

lead_paragraph: For haute cuisine, the city’s best kroner-to-quality ratio is Copenhagen Food Consulting (Abel Cathrines Gade 7; 45-3313-6060). A haven of minimalist Scandinavian style in the trendy Vesterbro district, the two-year-old upscale restaurant (known by the locals as Cofoco) offers a seasonal three-course menu of modern Danish-French dishes for 225 kroner (about $37, at 6.3 kroner to the dollar). Offerings might include cod with apple and mint or duck with yogurt, beets and horseradish. Its bargains have made Cofoco a popular cult address, so book in advance. Or hit the streets for a hot dog, the sidewalk specialty of Copenhagen. Sold from pushcarts labeled “Polser,” the tube steaks come thick or thin, grilled or boiled, and topped with dried onions, sweet pickles and tangy rémoulade sauce, generally about 20 kroner. — SETH SHERWOODBack to Article

abstract: Last week, the much-anticipated Parallels for Mac OS X finally exited beta-land and became a real, live, shipping piece of software ($50 through July 15).     It lets you run Windows (any version--or Linux, or Solaris...) on any Intel-based Macintosh. In a window, no less, so you don't even have to restart the computer when you need to duck into a Windows program. It runs in a window of its own, as though the entire Windows world were just another one of your Mac programs. And it's fast, although not fast enough for 3-D games.

snippet: FOOD AND BEVERAGES    The News -- Coca-Cola and Pepsi sought to overturn partial bans on their soft drinks in many parts of India.    Behind the News -- The bans were instituted after an advocacy group announced the results of studies showing the ...
lead_paragraph: FOOD AND BEVERAGES
abstract: FOOD AND BEVERAGES    The News -- Coca-Cola and Pepsi sought to overturn partial bans on their soft drinks in many parts of India.    Behind the News -- The bans were instituted after an advocacy group announced the results of studies showing the beverages contained on average more than 24 times the safe limits of pesticides. Coca-Cola and Pepsi say their products are safe. But the companies are generally perceived as having bungled their response to the crisis, misjudging how quickly politicians would latch on to the advocacy group's report, playing to widespread wariness of multinationals.    HEALTH CARE PRODUCTS    The News -- Federal researchers concluded that only a contact-lens solution made by Bausch & Lomb contributed to an outbreak of fungal eye infections earlier this year.    Behind the News -- The company had argued that customers who failed to clean their lenses properly were largely at fault. But the report pointed the finger at Bausch & Lomb's ReNu With MoistureLoc. A total recall of the product last spring has been effective; the number of new infections is near zero. But the recall has affected the company's bottom line: it announced profits would be down 78 percent this year.    COMPUTERS    The News -- A top executive of AOL resigned after the disclosure that the company had released information about Web searches by 650,000 customers.    Behind the News -- The chief technology officer, Maureen Govern, was deemed ultimately responsible for the release; two employees under her were fired. The company said it would tighten data-privacy rules and retrain employees. But online privacy advocates said AOL's moves weren't enough, and warned that the problems of keeping data confidential were endemic to the search-engine industry.    ONLINE SERVICES    The News -- Apple said it was recalling nearly two million laptop batteries, saying they posed a fire hazard.    Behind the News -- The announcement came just a week after Dell said it would recall about four million batteries for the same reason. Together they constitute by far the largest recall in the consumer electronics industry. For Sony, which made the batteries involved in both recalls, it was more bad news. The company's reputation for innovative design has suffered in recent years; now its reputation for quality has taken a hit, too.    MOVIES    The News -- Paramount ended its 14-year relationship with Tom Cruise, saying the actor's recent conduct had been unacceptable.    Behind the News -- Mr. Cruise's people insisted he had not been fired but had quit. The dispute quickly escalated, with many agents, producers and other impresarios choosing sides. While Mr. Cruise's behavior -- which included remarks against psychiatry and in favor of Scientology -- was at issue, this being Hollywood, so was money. The weak opening take of his latest film convinced many Paramount executives that Mr. Cruise was becoming an albatross.

lead_paragraph: Prominent Money Manager Loses a Ruling In a Lawsuit Accusing Him of Cheating Backers Mario J. Gabelli's first investor won a crucial round in a long-running legal battle over whether Mr. Gabelli, the money manager, bilked him and another backer out of more than $100 million. A judge filed a summary judgment against Mr. Gabelli, determining that he unfairly prevented the two investors from selling their shares in his private company. [Page C1.]
abstract: Prominent Money Manager Loses a Ruling In a Lawsuit Accusing Him of Cheating Backers  Mario J. Gabelli's first investor won a crucial round in a long-running legal battle over whether Mr. Gabelli, the money manager, bilked him and another backer out of more than $100 million. A judge filed a summary judgment against Mr. Gabelli, determining that he unfairly prevented the two investors from selling their shares in his private company. [Page C1.]    Pension Proposal May Unmask More Corporate Debt  The board that writes accounting rules for American business is proposing a new method of reporting pension obligations that is likely to show that many companies have a lot more debt than was obvious before. [C1.]    Investor Bids for Aztar to Create Casino Empire  Colony Capital Acquisitions, a privately held real estate investment firm controlled by Thomas J. Barrack Jr., offered to buy Aztar for about $1.4 billion to create what would become the country's third-largest casino company. The offer values Aztar at about $41 a share, slightly more than a $38 a share bid that another casino operator, Pinnacle Entertainment, made on March 13. [C4.]    Big Insurers Have an Opportunity in New Medicare Plan  For many big insurers, the new Medicare program is shaping up as a great opportunity. And prescription drugs may be only a starting point. [C1.]    In Pursuit of Making Clothes That Actually Fit  A company has developed a technology for making clothes that consumers can buy off the rack, but, by creating three different shapes for each size, clothes that actually fit. Retailers say they are undecided about whether they like the system. [C1.]    Nasdaq Withdraws Bid for London Stock Exchange  The Nasdaq Stock Market withdrew its $4.1 billion preliminary bid for the London Stock Exchange, less than a month after expressing an interest. [C5.]    Judge Questions Prosecution of Accounting Partners  A federal judge questioned the prosecution of 16 former employees of KPMG, the accounting company, over aggressive tax shelters, and criticized prosecutors for what he called murky definitions of fraud and evasion. [C4.]    Web Concerns Have Provided Data to Investigators  Google was not the first company to provide information for pornography-related investigations of Internet searches. America Online, Comcast, Verizon, Earthlink and Symantec are among companies that provided data to investigators a year ago. [C7.]    Two Companies Clone a Horse for Competition  ViaGen and Encore Genetics said they have cloned horses in what they call the start of commercial horse cloning. Royal Blue Boon Too, left, was cloned from Royal Blue Boon, at right, a champion in a sport in which a horse and rider separate a single calf from a herd and keep the calf from returning. Royal Blue Boon won $380,000 in the sport before she was retired. [C4.]    U.S. Asks European Authorities to Treat Microsoft Fairly  The United States government has intervened in Microsoft's antitrust dispute with the European Commission, urging it and the 25 national governments in the European Union to be fair to the company, American diplomats and European officials said. [C5.]    U.S. and Europe File W.T.O. Complaint Against China  The United States and the European Union filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization accusing China of imposing discriminatory tariffs on foreign suppliers of auto parts. [C5.]    Apple Computer Lawyer Denounces Trademark Dispute  A lawyer for Apple Computer dismissed as ridiculous a long-running trademark infringement claim by another cultural icon, the Apple Corps recording label of the Beatles. [C5.]    French Council Upholds Labor Law, Extending Crisis  France's Constitutional Council upheld a fiercely contested new labor law, dealing a blow to opposition Socialists who had asked the council to strike it down but extending the crisis now facing the government. [A4.]    Lone Star Investigated Over Deal in South Korea  Prosecutors investigating accusations of tax evasion and embezzlement conducted a raid on the Seoul office of an American investment company, Lone Star Funds, which has a controlling stake in a Korean bank. [C5.]    Stocks Fall as New Economic Data Raises Rate Concerns  Blue-chip stocks ended lower after economic data created new concerns about inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 65 points, to 11,150.70; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.64 points, to 1,300.25; and the Nasdaq rose 3.04 points, to 2,340.82. [C6.]

snippet: CHIP CHANGE    The News -- Apple's Chairman, Steve Jobs, and Intel's chief executive, Paul S. Otellini, introduced Apple's first Macintosh computers that use processing chips from Intel.    Behind the News -- The shift came several months ahead of...
lead_paragraph: CHIP CHANGE
abstract: CHIP CHANGE    The News -- Apple's Chairman, Steve Jobs, and Intel's chief executive, Paul S. Otellini, introduced Apple's first Macintosh computers that use processing chips from Intel.    Behind the News -- The shift came several months ahead of schedule, and surprised analysts. It was only last spring that Apple said it would stop using I.B.M. processors, a decision that shook up the semiconductor industry. The move to Intel chips was also something of a shock, since Intel has long been an ally of Apple's rival, Microsoft.    CHANGE OF AIR    The News -- After more than two decades on terrestrial radio, the shock jock Howard Stern began broadcasting by satellite.    Behind the News -- The switch is a gamble for Sirius Satellite Radio, which is paying Mr. Stern hundreds of millions of dollars in hopes of attracting more listeners willing to pay a monthly subscription fee. It's also something of a gamble for Mr. Stern, who earned his bad-boy reputation by pushing up against Federal Communications Commission standards on indecency. The new show featured plenty of foul language since, as a satellite show, it falls outside the F.C.C.'s purview. He no longer has the agency to kick around.    FACE CHANGE    The News -- The United States Mint introduced a new version of the nickel, with the portrait of Thomas Jefferson facing front.    Behind the News -- The Treasury has been making a lot of changes lately, particularly in paper money, emphasizing new anticounterfeiting technologies. The changes to the nickel have little to do with technology but may upset purists just the same. In the 97 years that presidents have been stamped on coins, never has one been shown in anything other than profile. Purists had better get used to the new look, however: no further changes to the nickel are in the works.    CHANGING SCENERY    The News -- Mehmet Ali Agca, a Turk who shot Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square in 1981, was released from prison in Istanbul.    Behind the News -- The release was strongly criticized by Turkey's justice minister, who said it offended the ''public conscience'' and ordered a review. Mr. Agca, 48, had been convicted not only of shooting the pope but of killing a Turkish journalist. He will remain free while the appeal is heard. But he is also obligated to fulfill his mandatory military service, which he missed while in prison.    CHANGE OF HEART    The News -- The skier Bode Miller apologized for statements he made that suggested he had raced while under the influence of alcohol.    Behind the News -- Miller, the best all-around skier the United States has ever produced, had been under pressure from American and international ski officials to apologize after his remarks on ''60 Minutes.'' While he apologized, he neither admitted nor denied that he had raced after drinking, and he spoke for little more than two minutes without taking questions. All of which should add to his reputation as an iconoclastic free spirit as he heads to the Olympics next month.
