snippet: Keeping conservation in mind, residents in Fishkill, N.Y., are keeping an eye on development.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT halfway through his 75-minute commute home from Scarsdale to Fishkill, Gary Lockwood, a financial salesman, says he rolls down the car window and drinks in the fresh air, pleased that the houses are set farther apart and the landscape is less congested. Once home in Dutchess County, Mr. Lockwood opens the windows of the town house that he and his wife, Alexis, moved into last spring, and listens to the sounds of crickets, instead of cars drag-racing along a nearby highway, as he used to in the family’s apartment in central Westchester.
abstract: Keeping conservation in mind, residents in Fishkill, N.Y., are keeping an eye on development.

snippet: Summer’s slapdash freedom is replaced by rules and measurements, and tender lettuce leaves are now weighted down with much more stuff: fruits, nuts, cheese.
lead_paragraph: LIKE everything else in my life, salads grow more complicated in the fall. In June and July, I like lettuce plain, with olive oil and vinegar splashed on straight from the bottle, plus salt and pepper. It is one of the skills I am secretly exceptionally proud of, this ability to dress a salad in the bowl without mixing up the dressing on the side first. I am convinced that salad tastes better this way, though I can’t figure out why. And I enjoy doing it — I feel more in tune with the greens, and also more picturesque (which, by the way, is a vast and unexplored category of human satisfaction).
abstract: Summer’s slapdash freedom is replaced by rules and measurements, and tender lettuce leaves are now weighted down with much more stuff: fruits, nuts, cheese.

snippet: Maggie Dietz's collection of poems looks candidly at the familiar.
lead_paragraph: North of Boston” was Robert Frost’s first book of poems to be published in the United States (“A Boy’s Will” had appeared in England two years earlier) and contains “The Death of the Hired Man,” “After Apple-Picking” and “Mending Wall,” poems now inscribed permanently in the American canon. So for Maggie Dietz to call a poem in her first book “North of Boston” is like an unknown jumping into the ring with the heavyweight champ; you worry not about who’s going to win but whether the newcomer will end up on the canvas or in the cheap seats.
abstract: Maggie Dietz's collection of poems looks candidly at the familiar.

snippet: A Security Feature May Need Tinkering    Q. My Web browser often gives me a message that says ''Your current security settings prohibit running ActiveX controls on this page.'' What is ActiveX?    A. ActiveX controls are little programs that work ...
lead_paragraph: A Security Feature May Need Tinkering
abstract: A Security Feature May Need Tinkering    Q. My Web browser often gives me a message that says ''Your current security settings prohibit running ActiveX controls on this page.'' What is ActiveX?    A. ActiveX controls are little programs that work within a Web browser to provide things like interactivity and animation to Web pages. They can be helpful tools that let you do calculations in a browser window or upload pictures to a photo-sharing site. But there are also rogue ActiveX controls that secretly install software on your computer or do other malicious deeds.

lead_paragraph: FREEHOLD - IT is lunchtime, the sun is slanting through the windows of the Main Street Bistro here, and my friends are discussing ways to kill people. It is quite a juxtaposition: an interesting menu, a friendly waiter and death.
abstract: IT is lunchtime, the sun is slanting through the windows of the Main Street Bistro here, and my friends are discussing ways to kill people. It is quite a juxtaposition: an interesting menu, a friendly waiter and death.      One friend's eyes sparkle, and I'm not sure whether it's the menu or imagining the intricacies of asphyxiation. Then, she speaks of the stuffed pork loin, and I'm relieved. The notion of apples, dried cranberries and spinach wrapped in ribbons of pork is more appetizing than the dish of murder that these mystery writers serve up cold.

We also know that an extraordinary lineup of former military and intelligence leaders, including Colin Powell, have spoken out against the Bush plan, warning that it would further damage America's faltering moral standing, and end up endangering U.S. troops.

snippet: THE BASICS -- There's a hand-lettered sign in the office of the Wickwood Inn that reads, ''Nobody but nobody gets in to see the Wizard, not nobody, not no how.'' It's a quote about Oz, but it fits the Wizard of Wickwood, Julee Rosso. Ms. Rosso was...
lead_paragraph: THE BASICS -- There's a hand-lettered sign in the office of the Wickwood Inn that reads, "Nobody but nobody gets in to see the Wizard, not nobody, not no how." It's a quote about Oz, but it fits the Wizard of Wickwood, Julee Rosso. Ms. Rosso was part of a legendary cookbook writing team with Sheila Lukins; their Silver Palate books sold millions of copies before they parted ways. Ms. Rosso moved to Saugatuck, a quaint town on the east side of Lake Michigan, and, with her husband, Bill Miller, bought Wickwood, where her spirit hovers. "Julee suggests you drizzle the frittata with just a bit of white truffle oil," Luann Raimondo, one of Wickwood's employees -- who were uniformly kind and polite -- said during breakfast at the inn. But on the two mornings I asked if Ms. Rosso was around, I was told with the same cheerfully vague wording, "She's around, but she's not here right now." It would have been nice to meet her.
abstract: THE BASICS -- There's a hand-lettered sign in the office of the Wickwood Inn that reads, ''Nobody but nobody gets in to see the Wizard, not nobody, not no how.'' It's a quote about Oz, but it fits the Wizard of Wickwood, Julee Rosso. Ms. Rosso was part of a legendary cookbook writing team with Sheila Lukins; their Silver Palate books sold millions of copies before they parted ways. Ms. Rosso moved to Saugatuck, a quaint town on the east side of Lake Michigan, and, with her husband, Bill Miller, bought Wickwood, where her spirit hovers. ''Julee suggests you drizzle the frittata with just a bit of white truffle oil,'' Luann Raimondo, one of Wickwood's employees -- who were uniformly kind and polite -- said during breakfast at the inn. But on the two mornings I asked if Ms. Rosso was around, I was told with the same cheerfully vague wording, ''She's around, but she's not here right now.'' It would have been nice to meet her.    THE LOCATION -- Wickwood sits in a beautiful and fragrant garden in the center of the town, which is due west of Detroit. The chain ferry, a hand-cranked boat across the Kalamazoo River ($1), is a block away. Marro's, a terrific Italian restaurant, is also within easy walking distance.    THE SCENE -- The 11 rooms, with names like Kyoto and Summer in Santorini, are perfect for romantic getaways; when I was there, guests were young, old, black, white, gay, straight, and all (apparently) in love.    AMENITIES -- Thanks to Ms. Rosso, life at Wickwood revolves around food. Each day began with a lush breakfast (one morning, I had apple bread pudding and cappuccino mousse; another morning, a fabulous frittata). At 6 p.m., the same buffet table was piled with a variety of superb hors d'oeuvres; some guests fill up and don't bother with dinner. Before bedtime, there were more treats, which included brownies and brandy (one as silky as the other). The refrigerator, available to guests 24/7, was stocked with ginger tea, lemonade and fruit juices from heaven. Chocolate-dipped strawberries and a fancy trail-mix were set out in my bedroom.    THE ROOMS -- My room, named Uptown, was decorated with silver-framed photos of New York. And the opulently outfitted bed was stacked with so many pillows it was a chore to take them off. Rooms lack individual temperature controls -- at one point, on a unseasonably warm evening, it was too hot to sleep, and I didn't feel comfortable bothering the staff to adjust the air-conditioning in the middle of the night. Luckily, there was a stack of interesting books next to the bed.    THE BATHROOM -- Small and forgettable. The shower didn't have a lot of pressure. But Wickwood is really about public spaces; the living room, the game room, the porch and the patio couldn't be nicer.    THE BOTTOM LINE -- Rooms are $185 to $365, with a two-night minimum on weekends. But I got a nasty surprise at checkout. When I received my bill, I learned that the $269.50 room rate I had been quoted (and which had been repeated to me after I checked in) was no longer valid; I was being charged $313.50. When I asked how this could be, I was shown a copy of Wickwood's reservation confirmation letter. One sentence had already been highlighted for my convenience: ''Please note that Room Rates and Room Assignment are subject to change without prior notification, and balances are subject to those changes.'' (After returning home, I explained the situation to Ms. Rosso in an e-mail message, without identifying myself as a reporter. A week later, I received a note saying I was being credited $66, a happy if belated resolution.)      Wickwood Inn, 510 Butler Street, Saugatuck, Mich.; (800) 385-1174; www.wickwoodinn.com.   FRED A. BERNSTEIN

abstract: WITH today's iPods and MP3 players, travelers don't have to drag around piles of CD's to listen to music, so why should they have to carry DVD's if they want to watch movies or videos while traveling?     Perhaps soon you won't have to. Even now, portable (or personal) media players and personal video players like Apple's iPod -- all often called PMP's -- are expanding options and making it easier than ever to take everything from episodes of favorite TV shows to movies to home videos with you on the road.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - Consumers should avoid eating fresh bagged spinach after an outbreak of E. coli in eight states killed one person and sickened at least 49, federal health officials announced Thursday night.
abstract: Consumers should avoid eating fresh bagged spinach after an outbreak of E. coli in eight states killed one person and sickened at least 49, federal health officials announced Thursday night.      The outbreak involves a virulent strain of E. coli known as 0157:H7, which produces a toxin that can lead to bloody diarrhea, kidney failure and, in rare cases, death.

Times are good for the industry. Sales of consumer electronics -- including cellphones, digital cameras and plasma-screen televisions -- climbed to $126 billion last year in the United States alone.

snippet: The Hard Life Of a Hard Drive    Q. In a recent conversation, a tech person said that hard drives can get ''tired or aged.'' Is this really so?    A. Hard drives spend their waking hours spinning constantly and contain several moving parts. And as...
lead_paragraph: The Hard Life Of a Hard Drive
abstract: The Hard Life Of a Hard Drive    Q. In a recent conversation, a tech person said that hard drives can get ''tired or aged.'' Is this really so?    A. Hard drives spend their waking hours spinning constantly and contain several moving parts. And as with most motorized mechanical devices, the moving parts can wear out or break down, causing the drive's performance to decline. There is an adage to the effect that ''all hard drives will fail eventually,'' but depending on how long you use the drive, ''eventually'' may be long after you have upgraded and moved on to a new drive.

snippet: Corrections: For the Record
lead_paragraph: Because of a transcription error, an article on Wednesday about a speech by Pope Benedict XVI in Germany, in which he addressed the concept of Muslim holy war, rendered incorrectly a phrase from a quotation by a 14th-century Byzantine emperor, Manuel II Paleologus. The correct quotation reads, “Show me just what Muhammad brought that was new, and there you will find things only evil and inhuman, such as his command to spread by the sword the faith he preached.” — not “to spread the sword by the faith he preached.” (Go to Article)

snippet: In Disney's Interest in Buying Pixar, A Sign of Chief's Technological Focus  Disney's board is expected to consider today whether to buy Pixar Animation for roughly $6.8 billion in stock and give Steven P. Jobs of Apple a seat on Disney's board. W...
lead_paragraph: In Disney's Interest in Buying Pixar, A Sign of Chief's Technological Focus Disney's board is expected to consider today whether to buy Pixar Animation for roughly $6.8 billion in stock and give Steven P. Jobs of Apple a seat on Disney's board. Whatever the board decides, the aggressive pursuit of a deal by Robert Iger, Disney's chief executive, speaks volumes about his own ambitions and how he perceives his company's future. [Page C1.]
abstract: In Disney's Interest in Buying Pixar, A Sign of Chief's Technological Focus  Disney's board is expected to consider today whether to buy Pixar Animation for roughly $6.8 billion in stock and give Steven P. Jobs of Apple a seat on Disney's board. Whatever the board decides, the aggressive pursuit of a deal by Robert Iger, Disney's chief executive, speaks volumes about his own ambitions and how he perceives his company's future. [Page C1.]    The calculus of Disney in seeking to acquire Pixar is simple: big media conglomerate plus vaunted computer animation studio plus closer ties with Steven P. Jobs, the maverick Pixar founder, equals potential powerhouse. But because Mr. Jobs's other job is chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer, a deal also raises the possibility of a warmer relationship between Disney and Apple if Mr. Jobs plays an active role at the company. [C1.]    Albertsons Is Said to Be Close to a Deal  Albertsons Inc., the giant supermarket chain, was close to a reaching an agreement to be acquired by a group of companies and investment firms for about $9.7 billion in cash and stock, people involved in the talks said. [C1.]    When Feedback Turns Angry, Blogs Can Go Haywire  As shown by an onslaught of negative comments on the Web site of The Washington Post from people angry at its ombudsman, when people can say anything on blogs, they frequently do. David Carr. [C1.]    New Health Site Aims to Challenge WebMD  A new Web site owned by Healthline Networks acts as a medical search engine, finding articles on ailments and remedies from some 66,000 Web sites it has identified as providing medical content. In doing so, Healthline says it offers consumers a broader choice of information than WebMD, which is by far the most popular single medical resource online, and a more refined choice than general search engines like Google. Healthline's chairman and chief executive, West Shell III, above, said several factors argued in favor of the company's success this time around, after a similar venture was unsuccessful. Consumers remain deeply interested in online health information, he said, and pharmaceutical and other medical advertisers are starting to open their wallets more generously to the Web. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C4.]    The Risks and Rewards of Web Recommendations  Web technology capable of compiling vast amounts of customer data makes it possible for online stores to recommend items tailored to a specific shopper's interests. Companies are finding that getting those personalized recommendations right -- or even close -- can mean significantly higher sales. But spewing out recommendations is not entirely without risk. [C1.]    Films to Appear at Same Time in Theaters and on Cable  Hollywood inched further toward making movies simultaneously available in theaters, on DVD and on television screens as IFC Entertainment unveiled a plan to release 24 films in theaters and on cable at the same time this year. [C3.]    Web Offered Early Clues on 'A Million Little Pieces'  Right after James Frey's ''A Million Little Pieces,'' billed as a memoir, was released in April 2003, readers with addiction histories of their own indicated on the Internet that something was wrong -- long before an exposé on the Smoking Gun Web site this month. Tom Zeller Jr.: Link by Link. [C3.]    Conference Extols Word-of-Mouth Marketing  A conference in Orlando, Fla., called ''Word-of-Mouth Basic Training'' sought to teach participants how to tap into the power of word of mouth, an ancient form of communication that many marketers have updated by using blogs, podcasting and online message boards. Advertising. [C7.]    Traditional Radio Pursues Digital Strategy  Traditional broadcast radio, the last bastion of analog entertainment technology, sees a bright future for itself. Its strategy for success is to become more like one of its main competitors -- subscription satellite radio -- by offering digital side channels. [C4.]    From Disney, a Magazine for New Parents  Disney, through its Disney Worldwide Publishing division, will join the crowded but profitable parenting magazine category next month. The new magazine, Wondertime, is aimed at anxious parents of the very, very young. [C5.]

snippet: Choosing A Backup Buddy    Q. Which is better for backing up the computer on the road -- a flash-memory drive or a portable hard drive?    A. Finding the right type of drive for backups on the go depends on a few factors, like how much data you in...
lead_paragraph: Choosing A Backup Buddy
abstract: Choosing A Backup Buddy    Q. Which is better for backing up the computer on the road -- a flash-memory drive or a portable hard drive?    A. Finding the right type of drive for backups on the go depends on a few factors, like how much data you intend to back up, how much gear you want to haul and how much you want to spend.      Flash-memory drives (those handy lightweight devices about the size of a disposable lighter) have no moving parts and plug right into the computer's U.S.B. drive. The physical size and durability of the average flash drive makes it a good choice for travel if you don't need to run a full backup of your system on the road.

lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
abstract: IN New York City, the second baseball season -- the budget-friendly, tourist-friendly and kid-friendly game of minor league baseball -- starts Tuesday and will last all summer. Think of it as the Off Broadway version of hardball.     For the money it costs to buy a family of four decent seats to take in the Bronx Bombers, about $200, the same family could buy the best tickets in KeySpan Park, the Brooklyn Cyclones' charming Coney Island home. And there would be enough money left over to ride the roller coaster the team is named for, gorge on Nathan's Famous hot dogs, visit the New York Aquarium and grapple with candied apples on the storied boardwalk -- oh, and buy the best seats in the house to see the Staten Island Yankees play the next day.

snippet: ELIOT FELD has been having a good season. It started with his spectacular ''Sir Isaac's Apples'' at the Juilliard School and continued with a Diamond Project premiere and two all-Feld programs at New York City Ballet. Now comes the annual stint of...
lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
abstract: ELIOT FELD has been having a good season. It started with his spectacular ''Sir Isaac's Apples'' at the Juilliard School and continued with a Diamond Project premiere and two all-Feld programs at New York City Ballet. Now comes the annual stint of his BALLET TECH at the Joyce Theater, with the Mandance Project. The repertory will include two of the ballets seen at City Ballet, along with ''Mr. XYZ,'' with MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV in all performances during the first week. Wednesday through Saturday at 8 p.m., next Sunday at 7:30 p.m. and June 6-11, along with Kidsdance, next Sunday and June 10 at 2 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or joyce.org; $42; Kidsdance, $30 for adults, $20 for children; for Wednesday gala tickets, call (212) 777-7710, ext. 316.    Coincidence or competition? In the midst of American Ballet Theater's ''All Star Stravinsky'' program at the Metropolitan Opera House, the NEW YORK CITY BALLET has slipped its very own ''All Stravinsky'' program into the repertory at the New York State Theater. There is no overlap of scores or choreography, but the two programs should still make for a piquant comparison. Today at 3 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570 or nycballet.org, $30 to $86, $15 for student rush tickets.    DANCEMOPOLITAN -- or dancemOpolitan, as they write it down at Joe's Pub -- has established itself as one of the livelier, more unusual dance showcases in town. On the club's vest-pocket stage, with a different curator for each program, you can enjoy a dizzying revue of 10 or more dancers and dance companies. Friday and Saturday offer the ''Thrash and Rock Show,'' with a live band and, as hosts, THE NICOLES, who are Nicole Berger and Nicole Wolcott. Friday and Saturday at 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 239-6200 or telecharge .com; $15 in advance, $20 at the door; dinner reservations at (212) 539-8778.

snippet: Renzo Rosso, founder of fashion house Diesel, is trying his hand at wine; while elitist oenophiles may sniff at his project as example of another celebrity plastering his name on bottles, Rosso is taking modest approach to vineyard venture; his ag...
lead_paragraph: From the hilltop of his 2,500-acre farm in Marostica, Italy, the Diesel founder and president Renzo Rosso can take in the many fruits of his labor. You can see in the distance the company's headquarters in Molvena, where 500 employees churn out everything from denim to luggage to watches; there's a new manufacturing plant that will produce all the bags and shoes worldwide; and then there is Rosso's home in nearby Bassano del Grappa, where he has raised his six children, whose ages range from 4 to 29. Besides the gigantic chessboard in Piazza Castello, where a chess tournament using live pieces is held every two years, the only buzz in this sleepy medieval town, an hour and a half's drive north of Venice, comes from Rosso and Diesel.

snippet: Assessment of pinot grigio wines, including tasting report; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: PINOT GRIGIO has come a long way in the last 20 years. Just as an especially popular piece of classical music or literature will be rejected by a contingent of connoisseurs simply because of its popularity, pinot grigio from Italy, the most popular category of imported white wine in the United States, has largely been dismissed by serious wine drinkers as bland and insipid, the harmless, gulpable equivalent of a lawn mower beer.

lead_paragraph: Sony's video game unit said yesterday that Ken Kutaragi, the father of the PlayStation game console, would no longer run its day-to-day affairs. lead_paragraph: Design is the new art. O.K., not really. But design, once the territory of the rarefied specialist, is now the darling of contemporary art collectors, who are, to a great extent, driving prices for Modernist and contemporary furniture to levels formerly reserved for blue-chip painting. Making this market even hotter is the rise of limited-edition works by superstar designers.

snippet: One of the industrial designer Yves Behar’s favorite objects is a children’s puzzle designed in solid oak in 1960 called the The Enzo Mari zoo-nigma.
lead_paragraph: WHEN you think about it, isn’t the vaunted search for meaning a bit overrated? Heaven knows, there is plenty around. To a child, for example, a stop sign means little more than a pretty red octagon to admire. To an adult, it has layers of meaning: warning, direction, authority, history, memory, impatience. Even a stop sign comes with baggage.

abstract: The meatloaf at Clementine Café, a new takeout shop in Chelsea, is definitely not Mom's, unless Mom liked her meatloaf on the spicy side and with a dense texture that makes it good to slice and serve cold, like pâté.     The shop also has salads ($4.25 to $6.25 for a generous portion), including beet and onion; well-seasoned Israeli couscous with pine nuts and peppers; and cucumber and feta. Hot and cold sandwiches are $6.95 to $7.25.

snippet: President Vicente Fox was not the only Mexican citizen traveling to Washington State on Wednesday.      As an orange sun rose over the desert here, José Ángel Huerta, 36, a silversmith down on his luck, waited under a shrub pine with several other...
lead_paragraph: SAN LUIS RIO COLORADO, Mexico, May 24 - President Vicente Fox was not the only Mexican citizen traveling to Washington State on Wednesday.
abstract: President Vicente Fox was not the only Mexican citizen traveling to Washington State on Wednesday.      As an orange sun rose over the desert here, José Ángel Huerta, 36, a silversmith down on his luck, waited under a shrub pine with several other migrants, watching for a chance to scurry across the border and make the 20-mile hike to Yuma, Ariz. It would be his second try. Two days earlier, the Border Patrol had picked him up and returned him to Mexico.

headline.main: On a Paper Border, Mexico's Poor Hide, Scramble and Hope

snippet: HomeI was profoundly moved by Scott Anderson's article (May 28). I'm against the war in Iraq, and his article only strengthened my resolve in this. However, the profiles of the men who served (the psychologically and physically wounded and those w...
lead_paragraph: Bringing It All Back Home
abstract: HomeI was profoundly moved by Scott Anderson's article (May 28). I'm against the war in Iraq, and his article only strengthened my resolve in this. However, the profiles of the men who served (the psychologically and physically wounded and those who died) reminded me that they are not the enemy and that they deserve my support and compassion,despite my feelingsabout the war itself. This article made the cost for the soldiers and their families painfully real. I appreciate their willingness to share these difficult experienceswith readers like me, and I thank Scott Anderson for listening so well and writing it all down.

snippet: The story of Inlet Seafood in Montauk reads like the recipe for a perfect restaurant.
lead_paragraph: IT reads like the recipe for a perfect restaurant. Six Montauk fishing boat captains open a place serving the freshest catch and hire Montauk’s most acclaimed chef, John Yashinowsky, to head the kitchen. Mr. Yashinowsky was the chef and owner of Caswell’s, Montauk’s first upscale restaurant, which had a nine-year run before closing in 2002, to be followed briefly by Gianni’s in the same location.

snippet: Odd Characters In E-Mail    Q. Why is it that in some e-mail messages, certain letters or punctuation marks are often replaced by question marks in the message body?    A. Question marks usually appear in a message's text if your e-mail program do...
lead_paragraph: Odd Characters In E-Mail
abstract: Odd Characters In E-Mail    Q. Why is it that in some e-mail messages, certain letters or punctuation marks are often replaced by question marks in the message body?    A. Question marks usually appear in a message's text if your e-mail program does not know how to display the typographical character used by the sender. Certain types of quotation marks, apostrophes and foreign accents are among the characters that may be rendered incorrectly.     In the United States, message text composed in plain Ascii (pronounced AS-kee, for American Standard Code for Information Interchange) translates the most widely between the various computer systems and mail programs. Ascii is limited to 128 characters, and many are nonprinting control characters like tabs.

headline.main: Odd Characters in E-Mail

snippet: Former American Horticultural Society pres George Ball Op-Ed article disputes contention of some environmentalists that exotic plants are invading American gardens, and our ecosystem will collapse under their rampant suffocating growth; drawing (M...
lead_paragraph: Warminster, Pa. - THE horticultural world is having its own debate over immigration, with some environmentalists warning about the dangers of so-called exotic plants from other countries and continents "invading" American gardens. These botanical xenophobes say that a pristine natural state exists in our yards and that to disturb it is both sinful and calamitous. In their view, exotic plants will swallow your garden, your neighbors' gardens and your neighbors' neighbors' gardens until the ecosystem collapses under their rampant suffocating growth.

snippet: From TV puppets to foldable wireless keyboards - what a difference a decade makes.
lead_paragraph: From TV puppets to foldable wireless keyboards - what a difference a decade makes. The fabric that made the puppets, which last appeared on a satirical British television hit a decade or so ago, is so lightweight and flexible that it is the foundation of a new qwerty keyboard - the most commonly used English- language keyboard - that allows smart-phone and PDA owners to input text wirelessly, roll it up and stow it in their pockets.

snippet: Compressed audio formats like MP3 files, and the devices that play them, allow people to take huge music collections virtually anywhere. But the very portability of an MP3 player can be its undoing -- too often, the pocket-size gadgets are dropped...
lead_paragraph: Compressed audio formats like MP3 files, and the devices that play them, allow people to take huge music collections virtually anywhere. But the very portability of an MP3 player can be its undoing -- too often, the pocket-size gadgets are dropped, scratched, drowned, or exposed to extreme temperatures.
abstract: Compressed audio formats like MP3 files, and the devices that play them, allow people to take huge music collections virtually anywhere. But the very portability of an MP3 player can be its undoing -- too often, the pocket-size gadgets are dropped, scratched, drowned, or exposed to extreme temperatures.     ''I've dropped my cellphone a dozen times, but if you drop your iPod once, you've got to send it in for repair,'' says Ryan Arter, whose company iPodResQ (ipodresq.com) receives around 1,200 iPods for repair every week.

headline.main: Protecting Your MP3 Player, and What to Do When You Don't

snippet: Roberta Smith reviews photographs by John Szarkowski at Museum of Modern Art; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: John Szarkowski became part of the history of 20th-century photography by helping to define it, through his writing and a series of groundbreaking exhibitions that he organized during his 29-year tenure as director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art. The photographs he shot for much of his life don't have the same historical weight, partly because they haven't been exhibited much. But they have a similar decisive clarity and suggest a man who, whatever his involvement with the medium, has always been something of a natural.

lead_paragraph: The actor and director Emilio Estevez is engaged to marry his girlfriend of two years, Estevez has told People magazine. Estevez, 44, the eldest son of the actor Martin Sheen and brother of the television actor Charlie Sheen, said that he and his fiancée, the writer Sonja Magdevski, had not yet set a wedding date. "Don't know yet. Gotta get through this," he told the magazine Tuesday while attending the Venice Film Festival for the premiere of "Bobby," a film about the 1968 assassination of Robert F. Kennedy, which Estevez wrote, directed and stars in alongside Lindsay Lohan, Christian Slater, Anthony Hopkins, Helen Hunt and William H. Macy. Estevez was married for two years to the singer Paula Abdul; they divorced in 1994. He and the model Carey Salley have two grown children from a relationship in the 1980s. (Reuters)
abstract: The actor and director Emilio Estevez is engaged to marry his girlfriend of two years, Estevez has told People magazine. Estevez, 44, the eldest son of the actor Martin Sheen and brother of the television actor Charlie Sheen, said that he and his fiancée, the writer Sonja Magdevski, had not yet set a wedding date. "Don't know yet. Gotta get through this," he told the magazine Tuesday while attending the Venice Film Festival for the premiere of "Bobby," a film about the 1968 assassination of Robert F. Kennedy, which Estevez wrote, directed and stars in alongside Lindsay Lohan, Christian Slater, Anthony Hopkins, Helen Hunt and William H. Macy. Estevez was married for two years to the singer Paula Abdul; they divorced in 1994. He and the model Carey Salley have two grown children from a relationship in the 1980s. (Reuters)

lead_paragraph: Moths vs. Bats
abstract: James H Fullard of University of Toronto, Mississauga, leads study on moths, which are nocturnal and use acoustic startle response to avoid predatory bats; research, which is published in journal Biology Letters, finds that startle response is still present even in moths that live in area without bats; notes that reaction is diminished in such cases; Christian Zorb of Federal Research Center for Nutrition and Food leads study comparing nutritional value of organic and traditionally grown wheat; research, which is published in Journal of Agriculture and Food Chemistry and uses carefully controlled field trials, finds that there is no difference in nutritional value of wheat; Space Telescope Science Institute reports that Hubble Space Telescope's highest-resolution camera is working again after three-week hiatus caused by electrical malfunction; Dr Dan Haydon of Edinburgh University and colleagues from Oxford University's wildlife conservation research unit, conduct research on disease control efforts to help preserve endangered Ethiopian wolves; findings, which are published in journal Nature, suggest that vaccinating as few as 25 percent of wolves at start of outbreak could halt spread of disease such as rabies or distemper, which could wipe out remaining 500 wolves in Ethiopia; drawing (M)

snippet: This documentary, airing Monday on PBS, renders the sparkling, high-res story of Ireland’s comeback in monochrome.
lead_paragraph: When the producers of “Mixed Blessings: The Transformation of Ireland” set out to investigate the current boom time of the Celtic Tiger, they must have thought something interesting would happen. Maybe a priest would be mugged by a software designer. But nothing happened, and they ended up with a wimpy elegy for the Ireland of two decades ago. “Mixed Blessings,” which appears tonight on PBS, is a presentation of “Wide Angle, which often puts its name on more polemical documentaries; the argument of this one is something like “times change.” It’s hard to argue with that.

snippet: FORD TO OFFER BUYOUTS -- In the latest sign that Detroit has decided it needs to shrink to survive, the Ford Motor Company agreed to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to all its 75,000 hourly workers in the United S...
lead_paragraph: FORD TO OFFER BUYOUTS -- In the latest sign that Detroit has decided it needs to shrink to survive, the Ford Motor Company agreed to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to all its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs. [Page A1.]
abstract: FORD TO OFFER BUYOUTS -- In the latest sign that Detroit has decided it needs to shrink to survive, the Ford Motor Company agreed to offer buyouts and other incentives worth as much as $140,000 each to all its 75,000 hourly workers in the United States to persuade them to leave their jobs. [Page A1.]    HEDGE FUND MAY GO PUBLIC -- A hedge fund named Fortress Investment Group is considering an initial public offering for later this fall in a deal that could value the company in the range of $5 billion to $7 billion, according to people who have been briefed on the plans. [C1.]    RUSSIAN REGULATOR IS KILLED -- Andre Kozlov, below, a top Russian bank regulator who had been engaged in an effort to reform Russia's corrupt and risk-laden banking system, died yesterday after being shot on the street the night before. Mr. Kozlov, 41, the first deputy chairman of Russia's central bank, had been leading a drive to combat money laundering and to bring stability to Russia's rapidly expanding banking sector. Among many programs in his portfolio, he had been closing disreputable banks by withdrawing their licenses, a practice his colleagues said had made him enemies in criminal circles. [A3.]    SETBACK FOR U.S. ON SHELTERS -- A 2004 Internal Revenue Service document indicates that KPMG did not have to register certain questionable tax shelters with the agency, undermining a major claim in the government's case against 18 former tax professionals. [C1.]    TALKS TO SELL DIRECTV -- Rupert Murdoch, who spent more than two decades coveting the satellite broadcaster DirecTV before acquiring control of it three years ago, is now in talks to sell it to the financer John C. Malone, people close to the talks said last night. [C1.]    UTILITY MERGER ABANDONED -- The Public Service Enterprise Group of Newark, the parent company of New Jersey's largest utility, and Exelon of Chicago called off their merger, saying that their differences with New Jersey regulators were ''insurmountable.'' [B5.]    CHINA AND NEWS SERVICES -- Chinese officials promised that new rules restricting the sale of reports by foreign news agencies would not have an effect on press freedoms. But the officials also strongly defended efforts to control the distribution of financial and economic news inside the country. [A10.]    CALIFORNIA'S EMISSIONS FIGHT -- California is betting that it can succeed in reducing greenhouse gas emissions without wrecking its economy, and therefore inspire other states -- and countries -- to follow its example on slowing climate change. [A1.]    AOL EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE POST -- Ted Leonsis, who has been a top leader of AOL for 13 years, will give up his jobs as president of what AOL calls its audience business, which creates Web sites and sells advertising on them. He will remain vice chairman of the company. [C4.]    MICROSOFT'S MUSIC PLAYER -- Hoping to upstage the Apple iPod, Microsoft said that its Zune player, which it plans to release in time for the holiday season, will include wireless technology to allow Zune owners to easily share their favorite songs and playlists with one another. [C3.]    MEXICO SECURITIES SETTLEMENT -- The billionaire investor Ricardo Salinas Pliego and the United States Securities and Exchange Commission reached a settlement in the first case against a foreign company under the corporate governance rules of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. [C3.]    BATTLE OVER JOB CUTS AT PAPER -- The editor of The Los Angeles Times appears to be in a showdown with the paper's owners at the Tribune Company over newsroom job cuts. [C3.]    RESHAPING RADIO -- Woes in the radio industry have spurred a new wave of deal-making. Clear Channel Communications, the nation's largest radio operator, is considering selling some of its 1,200 stations in smaller markets, according to industry analysts. The CBS Corporation did the same thing recently and now says it is looking at further station sales. Walt Disney recently struck a deal to get out of the radio business altogether, and Susquehanna Broadcasting has been sold to another broadcaster. [C1.]    INDIA'S CELLPHONE GROWTH  -- India has become the fastest-growing cellular market in the world, adding a net 5.9 million cellular subscribers in August, the Cellular Operators Association of India said. The gain outstripped China's increase of 5.19 million subscribers. [C4.]    SMALL RISE IN RETAIL SALES -- Retail sales rose 0.2 percent in August after a surge of 1.4 percent in July. Another report showed that weekly first-time claims for jobless benefits fell. [C4.]    STOCKS END THE DAY MIXED -- Wall Street closed mixed, with blue chips falling and technology stocks managing a slight gain. [C8.]

snippet: Israeli troops moved back into Gaza on Saturday night, setting up tank positions on the outskirts of Beit Hanun, a crowded town of 35,000 people in the small territory's northeastern corner. Children gathered on the street corners on Sunday, peeri...
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops moved back into Gaza on Saturday night, setting up tank positions on the outskirts of Beit Hanun, a crowded town of 35,000 people in the small territory's northeastern corner. Children gathered on the street corners on Sunday, peering around corners for a glimpse of gun-toting militants who darted from building to building as Israeli snipers tried to pick them off.
abstract: Israeli troops moved back into Gaza on Saturday night, setting up tank positions on the outskirts of Beit Hanun, a crowded town of 35,000 people in the small territory's northeastern corner. Children gathered on the street corners on Sunday, peering around corners for a glimpse of gun-toting militants who darted from building to building as Israeli snipers tried to pick them off.     The rattle of automatic weapons fire echoed through the otherwise empty streets, sometimes sharp and close, sometimes muffled and far away. All over northern Gaza, there was the steady thump and thunder of artillery fire as Israel shelled the fields of Beit Hanun from the southeast, raising great clouds of dust. Ambulances patrolled slowly, picking up occasional casualties.

headline.main: New Dangers to Add To the Old Ones

lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York has endorsed Shakira, the Latin pop singer-songwriter, to win the Video of the Year award at the annual MTV Video Music Awards on Thursday at Radio City Music Hall. "As mayor of New York, this really is a tough one," a lighthearted Bloomberg said Tuesday, surrounded by a flock of young assistants, in a taped segment broadcast on MTV. "I could go with Christina; she was born in New York," he mused. An assistant confirmed that Christina Aguilera was from Staten Island. "Staten Island?" the mayor said, "Really!" He continued: "I could go with Madonna. She made it big here in New York." Finally, he decided. "I think I'm going to have to go with Shakira," he said. "Those hips don't lie." "Hips Don't Lie," by Shakira, with Wyclef Jean, is one of the songs nominated for Video of the Year. In addition to songs by Aguilera and Madonna, the other nominees are songs by Panic! at the Disco and the Red Hot Chili Peppers. (NYT)

lead_paragraph: The third rail in the transportation business is the electrified conduit that supplies power to a railway. Pension reform, so the saying goes, is the third rail of politics: Grab it and you die. The need to adapt state-financed retirement systems to changing demographics is acute, but so are the vested interests at all points on the political spectrum - which is one reason elected governments from Washington to Warsaw have resisted tackling the issue. So the announcement this week that the British government was proposing to overhaul its pension system was an illustration of just how bleak the future of social security systems has become, and how change can no longer be postponed. It also represents a significant political compromise between Prime Minister Tony Blair and his chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, over how to swell the coffers of the British pension system, which has one of the lowest payouts in Europe. That Blair, who faces serious political troubles over Iraq, should now be willing to grab the third rail is not too surprising: As one of the characters in "The West Wing," a television show about the inner workings of a fictional White House, put it, that is where the power is.

lead_paragraph: JEWELS. Everyone who cans vegetables or fruits exclaims over those jewel-like jars lining their pantry shelves, or standing in gleaming rows down in the cellar. The fantasy is that I will have put up so many jars of tomatoes and plums that they will sustain me through the winter season.

snippet: RUSSIA AS ENVIRONMENTALIST -- Now that the Russian government is seeking to stall huge oil projects in eastern Siberia by Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, it has suddenly discovered its inner environmentalist. [Page C1.]    OPEC MAY CUT OUTPUT -...
lead_paragraph: RUSSIA AS ENVIRONMENTALIST -- Now that the Russian government is seeking to stall huge oil projects in eastern Siberia by Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, it has suddenly discovered its inner environmentalist. [Page C1.]
abstract: RUSSIA AS ENVIRONMENTALIST -- Now that the Russian government is seeking to stall huge oil projects in eastern Siberia by Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, it has suddenly discovered its inner environmentalist. [Page C1.]    OPEC MAY CUT OUTPUT -- The OPEC oil cartel sent energy markets on a roller coaster, saying it was considering cutting output. Some of the group's members indicated they were worried about slumping prices. [C10.]    DEAL FOR CANADIAN OIL SANDS -- ConocoPhillips said it would combine ownership of two of its refineries in Texas with Canadian oil sands properties controlled by the oil and gas producer EnCana. [C10.]    RYANAIR MAKES HOSTILE BID -- Ryanair, the low-fare airline based in Ireland, started a hostile bid for a rival, Aer Lingus, in a move that could bring the budget carrier American cities served by Aer Lingus. Ryanair's chief, Michael O'Leary, left, has been contemptuous of Aer Lingus's management. [C7.]    HEDGE FUND AS CAMPAIGN CHEST -- Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo, a candidate for attorney general of New York, put $750,000 -- more than half of his campaign treasury -- into a hedge fund. The investment turned out to be all upside, with one-year returns of nearly 20 percent. [A1.]    A CAT FOR PEOPLE WITH ALLERGIES -- Allerca, a California biotech company says it is ready to deliver the Holy Grail of the $35 billion pet industry: a hypoallergenic cat. The first kittens will be delivered early next year, at a cost of $4,000 each. [A14.]    A LAND DEAL TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE -- Federal investigators are trying to sort out the suspicious purchase and resale of 184 homes in a down-and-out neighborhood in Indianapolis. The company that bought the mortgages says it was the victim of a fraud. [C1.]    PUBLISHER IS FORCED OUT -- Jeffrey M. Johnson, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, was forced out after refusing to make job cuts demanded by his corporate bosses at the Tribune Company. Dean Baquet, the paper's editor, who had also refused to make the job cuts, kept his job. [C1.]    FORD LOSING INTEREST IN ALLIANCE -- Carlos Ghosn, who heads Nissan of Japan and Renault of France, has made it clear that he wants a North American alliance. But in the aftermath of failed talks with G.M., his time may be past. [C3.]    AVOIDING THE CROWDED FLIGHTS -- If you want an empty seat beside you on your next flight, just schedule a trip to someplace like Kingman, Ariz.; Brookings, S.D.; or Pueblo, Colo. [A1.]    FORMER CHAIRWOMAN IN COURT -- Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, appeared in court in San Jose, Calif., after being charged in connection with a corporate spying operation. She was booked on four felony charges and agreed to return to court for an arraignment hearing. [C3.]    NEW BOOK ON H.P. -- Carleton S. Fiorina, the chairwoman of Hewlett Packard before she was fired in 2005, deserves plenty of credit for H.P.'s recent recovery. Or so she says, in her new book, ''Tough Choices.'' [C3.]    NO ACTION AGAINST PEQUOT -- The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission will not recommend an enforcement action against Pequot Capital Management or its employees relating to an insider trading investigation, according to a letter from the fund to its clients. [C1.]    RETAIL SALES UP -- Sales at retailers rose more in September than analysts estimated because of falling gas prices, brightening prospects for the holiday season. But Wal-Mart trailed rivals like Federated, J. C. Penney, Gap and Target. [C2.]    STOCKS GAIN AGAIN -- Stocks rose for a third day, extending the Dow Jones industrial average's record-breaking rally, helped by a rebound in energy and commodity companies. [C8.]    EUROPEAN BANK LIFTS RATES -- The European Central Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.25 percent, citing a risk of higher inflation. It was the fifth increase since last December. [C4.]    COMPARING BLINDNESS DRUGS -- The National Institutes of Health said that it would sponsor a clinical trial comparing two Genentech drugs that have sharply different costs as a treatment for the leading cause of blindness in the elderly. [C3.]    ONLINE    SMALL BUSINESS -- The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies. A special report is at nytimes.com/business.    BUSINESS TRAVEL -- The new reality of business travel includes more unexpected destinations. A special report is at nytimes.com/business.    NETWORKING -- A special report exploring the proliferation of VoIP technology and other new wireless innovations is at nytimes.com/technology.    Business Briefing     Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Wal-Mart said that it would expand a program offering generic drugs for $4 a prescription throughout Florida and that it might bring the program to other states before the end of the year. (REUTERS)    Some 15,000 members of the United Steelworkers union went on strike on Thursday at 16 plants owned by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. (REUTERS)    Starbucks said that it had set a new long-term goal to have 40,000 coffee stores worldwide, 10,000 more than its previous target and more than triple the current number. Starbucks also announced a deal to feature the music it sells in its stores on the Apple Computer iTunes Store.     The company said it expected to have more than 14,000 stores worldwide by the fall of 2007. There are currently about 12,000 Starbucks stores around the world. (AP)

snippet: CBS Plans Subscription Service That Sends News and Entertainment to Cellphones  The CBS Corporation is expected to announce the first subscription services that send news and entertainment alerts, including video clips, to mobile phones. The servi...
lead_paragraph: CBS Plans Subscription Service That Sends News and Entertainment to Cellphones The CBS Corporation is expected to announce the first subscription services that send news and entertainment alerts, including video clips, to mobile phones. The services are part of a broad new strategy to sell wireless media products directly to consumers. [C1.]
abstract: CBS Plans Subscription Service That Sends News and Entertainment to Cellphones  The CBS Corporation is expected to announce the first subscription services that send news and entertainment alerts, including video clips, to mobile phones. The services are part of a broad new strategy to sell wireless media products directly to consumers. [C1.]    In what is the boldest venture yet by an established media company to insinuate itself into millions of cellphones, the News Corporation has created a mobile entertainment store called Mobizzo and a production studio to focus exclusively on developing cellphone entertainment in much the same way that 20th Century Fox creates movies and television. [Page C1.]    Before Harvard President's Ouster, an Influential Article  Two years ago, when David McClintick, left, agreed to write an exposé on Harvard's effort on behalf of the United States government to help Russia privatize its economy in the 1990's, he had little inkling the article would play a part in forcing the ouster of Harvard's president, Lawrence Summers. ''How Harvard Lost Russia'' was published in the January issue of Institutional Investor magazine, a subscription-only publication, about a month and a half before Dr. Summers's resignation, which he announced last Tuesday. The move came just two weeks after a heated Feb. 7 meeting at which Dr. Summers was challenged on several issues, including his reaction to the events described in Mr. McClintick's provocative article. [C3.]    Working to Make Computer Power More Portable  When Samsung decided to mount a serious challenge to Apple Computer's iPod music player early last year, it turned to a Silicon Valley start-up and a small team of programmers led by Paul Mercer, 38, a veteran Apple Macintosh software designer. For Mr. Mercer, the Samsung project is the culmination of more than two decades of focus on extending personal computer technologies into the realm of portable devices. [C1.]    Tense Ties Between White House and Press  By its nature, the relationship between the White House and the press has historically held an inherent tension. And many say the relationship has been eroding since the Vietnam War and Watergate, when reporters had reason to distrust most everything the White House said and made a scandalous ''gate'' out of every murky act. But today, those on both sides say, the relationship has deteriorated further, exacerbated by live White House briefings. [C1.]    Gauging the Marketing Magnetism of the Oscars  Since the nominations for the 78th annual Academy Awards were announced, sponsors have shrugged off skeptics who questioned whether the ceremony, to be broadcast on Sunday by ABC, would draw a sizable audience. None of the five nominees for best picture are box-office blockbusters, the skeptics point out, and few of the nominees for acting awards are household names. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.]    If you drill down into this year's best picture nominees, you will find that they are guerrilla insurgencies backed by superpowers. David Carr. [C1.]    Web Companies Turn to 'Pay-Per-Call' Services  Businesses like Ingenio, based in San Francisco, are helping Internet companies move into ''pay-per-call'' services, where consumers on the Web click on an icon to have someone call them or simply dial a number in an ad. Judson Brady, left, the owner of Broad Street Flowers, an Atlanta-based floral service, pays Ingenio around $4.15 for each call from a prospect -- most of whom see his ads on AOL, which introduced its pay-per-call service last year. More than a third of the callers place an order, Mr. Brady said, making it more effective than his ''pay-per-click'' advertising. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C7.]    Test Scores Not Lowered by TV, Study Finds  A new study by two economists from the University of Chicago taps into a trove of data from the 1960's to argue that when it comes to academic test scores, parents can let children watch TV without fear of future harm. [C6.]

snippet: Revealing Fraud In E-Mail Addresses    Q. I get a ton of e-mail messages purporting to be from banks and Web sites that are obviously not from those institutions even though the return address looks real. Is there a way to find out where these mes...
lead_paragraph: Revealing Fraud In E-Mail Addresses
abstract: Revealing Fraud In E-Mail Addresses    Q. I get a ton of e-mail messages purporting to be from banks and Web sites that are obviously not from those institutions even though the return address looks real. Is there a way to find out where these messages actually came from?    A. Although you probably won't be able to trace the fraudulent message directly back to its human sender, you can usually poke around inside the message's full header field to see where it might have come from electronically. Check your particular e-mail program's settings for displaying ''full'' or ''long'' message headers -- in Outlook Express, for example, you can see the full header by right-clicking on a message in your mailbox window, selecting Properties and clicking the Details button.

abstract: In their struggle for dominance, neither Microsoft nor Google wants to give an inch. It's called a search box, and it is just one battleground in a much larger conflict between two premier high-tech companies.     Microsoft recently released a ''beta'' or test version of its latest Internet Explorer Web browser. Other browsers, like Firefox or Apple's Safari, already have search boxes. They allow users to enter search terms without first going to the trouble of entering the Web address for a search engine.

snippet: The Scottish-born singer KT Tunstall has a strong voice that in the same chorus can rasp like a blues mama and giggle like a giddy kid. This multi-instrumentalist pop songwriter's breakout single, ''Black Horse and the Cherry Tree,'' with its jump...
lead_paragraph: The Scottish-born singer KT Tunstall has a strong voice that in the same chorus can rasp like a blues mama and giggle like a giddy kid. This multi-instrumentalist pop songwriter's breakout single, "Black Horse and the Cherry Tree," with its jump-rope clack rhythms and forceful, dark minor-chord acoustic guitar strumming, offers a fresh twist on old folkie blues. Though the rest of her music may not break much new ground, Ms. Tunstall's debut album, "Eye to the Telescope," is happily occupied with grown-up concerns. Having paid her dues in bands in the United States, Ms. Tunstall has just won a Brit Award for best British female solo artist. There is lots of promise to her album, with some songs suggesting a bouncier Fiona Apple and others, less interestingly, conjuring a pricklier Dido or Nellie Furtado. Ms. Tunstall is touring here now amid buzz generated by the rainbow suspenders she sports over a sparkling shirt on her album's cover shot, interpreted by some fans as a lesbian symbol. Ms. Tunstall has said that she didn't know of the connection, but for a rising star, at this point, you assume any chatter is welcome chatter. (KT Tunstall plays a sold-out show Thursday night at 8 at the Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; $15.)

snippet: “May I speak candidly, fleshling, one rational creature to another, myself a book and you a reader?”
lead_paragraph: May I speak candidly, fleshling, one rational creature to another, myself a book and you a reader? Even if the literature of confession leaves you cold, even if you are among those who wish that Rousseau had never bared his soul and Augustine never mislaid his shame, you would do well to lend me a fraction of your life. I am Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy, after all - in my native tongue, PhilosophiÃ¦ Naturalis Principia Mathematica, the Principia for short - not some tenth-grade algebra text or guide to improving your golf swing. Attend my adventures and you may, Dame Fortune willing, begin to look upon the world anew.

snippet: Amy Wilentz, a lifelong Easterner, explores her newly adopted state, California.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Amy Wilentz’s husband got a job offer from The Los Angeles Times and she agreed, ambivalently, to move from the Upper West Side of Manhattan to the West Coast with their three sons and dog. Raised in gritty Perth Amboy, N.J., Wilentz is an accomplished journalist who has corresponded from Jerusalem for The New Yorker and written a book about Haiti. But judging from her new memoir, she was not sufficiently braced by these adventures for the foreignness and violence of Los Angeles, which she likens to “another planet,” with herself an “alien observer.”

snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Killings in Iraq Spawn Search for Missing Funds  Following the killings of Fern Holland, a human rights worker, and Robert Zangas, a press officer, in 2004 in Iraq, federal investigators are grappling with a second mystery...
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14
abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Killings in Iraq Spawn Search for Missing Funds  Following the killings of Fern Holland, a human rights worker, and Robert Zangas, a press officer, in 2004 in Iraq, federal investigators are grappling with a second mystery: what happened to hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash issued by American government authorities to Mr. Zangas and Ms. Holland in the days before their deaths.   A1    The Pentagon announced that it was delaying indefinitely the deployment of an armored brigade to Iraq, in a sign that senior commanders in Iraq may shortly announce cuts in overall troop levels.   A12    Angry Refugees Riot in Darfur  An African Union interpreter was hacked to death in a camp by a mob of angry demonstrators within hours of a visit to a refugee camp from the top United Nations aid official. The chaos raised questions about the ability of the African Union force to oversee this critical period between the signing of the peace agreement and the arrival of a much larger United Nations force.   A10    President Bush pressed the United Nations to speed up the sending of peacekeeping troops to Darfur. The Security Council agreed in February to plan the deployment, to replace African Union forces, but the planning process appeared to stop after Sudan refused to grant visas to an assessment team.   A10    Liberian girls as young as 8 are being sexually exploited by United Nations peacekeepers, aid workers and teachers, according to a new report from Save the Children U.K., based on interviews with over 300 people in camps for the displaced.   A8    U.S. Addresses Inmate Abuse  More than 100 American soldiers and intelligence officers, nearly twice the number cited by human rights groups, have been disciplined for abusing detainees, the United States told an international panel investigating the its treatment of prisoners in its fight against terrorism.   A17    NATIONAL   A16-22    Bush Tries to Quiet Opposition to Nominee  The White House tried to quell resistance from Republicans in Congress over the president's selection of Gen. Michael V. Hayden as the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Some Republican leaders in the Senate have been critical of the general's role in creating and defending the government's secret eavesdropping program.   A1    Aide Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy  Neil G. Volz, a former top aide to Representative Bob Ney, pleaded guilty to conspiring with the lobbyist Jack Abramoff to corrupt public officials, indicating that Mr. Ney, a Republican who is seeking re-election in Ohio, is still a central focus of the Justice Department's investigation.   A24    Report Faults Duke Reaction  Duke University officials failed to grasp the seriousness of a charge that white lacrosse players had raped a black woman at a party in March, and they did not respond quickly enough, according to an outside report on the case.   A18    Compromise in Puerto Rico  The governor of Puerto Rico, Aníbal Acevedo-Vilá, announced that a compromise had been reached to resolve the island's weeklong fiscal crisis, which had forced the governor to furlough 95,000 government employees and led to a week of rallies and vigils.   A18    Malpractice Plan Fails in Senate  For the fourth time in three years, the Senate rebuffed a Republican attempt to limit jury awards in medical malpractice cases.   A25    Newspaper Subpoenaed  In the latest effort by the government to learn the identities of reporters' sources, the United States attorney in Los Angeles issued grand jury subpoenas to The San Francisco Chronicle and two of its reporters, who reported on steroid use in baseball. The paper editor said it would fight the subpoenas.   A23    NEW YORK/REGION   B1-6    Rent Guidelines Board Proposes Increase  The board that sets rents for the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City proposed tentative increases last night of 3 percent to 6.5 percent on one-year leases and 5 percent to 8.5 percent on two-year leases, setting the stage for increases likely to be larger than last year's when the board holds a final vote next month.   B1    Fire Dept. Seeks Diversity  The New York Fire Department, seeking a more diverse crop of recruits to take the forthcoming firefighter exam, has decided to do a little rebranding with the help of a SoHo marketing agency. It is using kindler, gentler images to promote the benefits and flexibility of a firefighter's lifestyle.   B3    Shift in Tunnel Monitoring  The New York Police Department has changed the way it protects subway tunnels that cross under rivers, taking some officers away from fixed posts near tunnel entrances and putting them on trains, officials said.   B5    SCIENCE TIMES   F1-10    Hope for a Rare Disorder  Researchers announced that they have identified the genetic mutation that leads to fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva, or F.O.P., a rare condition in which muscle tissue morphs into bone and for which there is no cure or good treatment. The discovery may lead to treatment for F.O.P. as well as other bone conditions, like osteoporosis.   F5    Health & Fitness   F5    OBITUARIES   B7    Karel Appel  An internationally renowned Dutch painter, he was 85.   B7    BUSINESS DAY   C1-11    Warning From Dell  Dell warned that its quarterly earnings would be lower than expected, a result of price cutting aimed at stemming the decline in its market share for personal computers.   C1    Home Buyers May Gain Edge  As higher interest rates dampen demand for homes in cities and suburbs that only a year ago were battlegrounds for fierce bidding wars among numerous buyers, sellers are grudgingly lowering their prices to drum up interest.   C1    Wachovia's stock fell after it announced plans to buy Golden West Financial Corporation, a giant in the California mortgage business, because of concerns that the state's hot housing market is poised to cool down.   C1    The Silent Enron Managers  Some of the most important witnesses in the Enron case may be those who never appeared before the jury. More than half a dozen high-ranking Enron managers who could have clarified what really happened in some critical meetings at issue in the 15-week trial declined to testify.   C1    Business Digest   C2    EDITORIAL   A26-27    Editorials: Shuffling spies around; Cheney as pot, Putin as kettle; the pretenders; Apple versus Apple.    Columns: Nicholas D. Kristof. lead_paragraph: On his Asian trip last month, President Bush urged Americans not to fear the rise toward prosperity of emerging economies like India. Education, Mr. Bush said, was the best response to globalization, climbing further up the ladder of skills to "fill the jobs of the 21st century."
abstract: On his Asian trip last month, President Bush urged Americans not to fear the rise toward prosperity of emerging economies like India. Education, Mr. Bush said, was the best response to globalization, climbing further up the ladder of skills to ''fill the jobs of the 21st century.''     But a ladder to where? That is, where are educated young Americans likely to find good jobs that will not be shipped off to India or China?

snippet: S S Fair column on ice wines; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: There was a huge controversy several years ago in the science world when an endocrinologist discovered that exposure to a common weedkiller, atrazine, caused male frogs to develop female sex organs. Men who want to explore the rarefied milieu of ice wines, those richly textured, frozen-on-the-vine nectars, take heart: your sex organs won't budge merely by drinking wines associated with the gentler gender -- women and non-soccer-playing Britons. Ice wines are for anyone well connected enough to find them, well heeled enough to afford them and savvy enough to appreciate that they're not just dessert wines; they're dessert. Made from grapes harvested and quickly pressed while frozen (producing an incredibly sweet and concentrated elixir), they provide men with a golden opportunity to practice their sipping skills; guzzling is frowned upon by most everyone with ovaries.

lead_paragraph: The ultimate "Sideways" trip for New World wine lovers is Mendoza, Argentina, just west of Buenos Aires. A new hotel, Cavas Wine Lodge, has opened in time for this season's harvest Â between early March and April. Situated on 35 acres of vineyards overlooking the Andes, Cavas is only a short drive from the award-winning producers of malbec and torrontes varietals. Hedonism is encouraged. Cavas's wine cellar carries a substantial selection of South American wines, and deluxe cabanas Â sleek adobe huts with plunge pools, interior stone walls, claw-foot tubs and outdoor showers Â practically sit amid the grapes. But there is more to do than drink wine: a special spa package includes a crushed-malbec scrub. Cavas Wine Lodge, Costaflores s/n, Alto Agrelo; 011 54 261 410 6651; www.cavaswinelodge.com; doubles start at $310. -- Gisela Williams

lead_paragraph: LIGHT-CIGARETTE SMOKERS CAN SUE -- In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit. [Page A1.]
abstract: LIGHT-CIGARETTE SMOKERS CAN SUE -- In a legal blow to the tobacco industry, a federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that people who smoked light cigarettes that were often promoted as a safer alternative to regular cigarettes can press their fraud claim as a class-action suit. [Page A1.]    VIACOM HEAD RESTRUCTURES PAY -- In another effort to restore investor confidence, Viacom said its chairman and controlling shareholder, Sumner M. Redstone, left, was restructuring his pay to more clearly align it with shareholder interest and to base it on the company's financial performance. [C1.]    HOME MARKET COOLS -- After inching up slowly for most of the summer, the national median price of a previously owned home finally dipped into the red in August, to $225,000. It was the first time that prices of existing homes had fallen on a year-over-year basis in more than a decade. [C1.]    INSURANCE COSTS SOAR -- Among the reasons that real estate is cooling in some of the hottest markets is the soaring cost of insurance. Along the coast from Texas to Maine, owners of apartments and houses are facing huge premium increases. [C1.]    THE NEXT WAVE -- Companies like Samsung, Intel and NTT DoCoMo of Japan are spending heavily in a race to control crucial aspects of an evolving new technology known as fourth-generation wireless and to promote it as the next wave in Internet access. But its future is far from certain. [C1.]    DOUBTS ABOUT AUTO ALLIANCE -- General Motors has raised doubts in talks with Renault of France and Nissan of Japan that a three-way alliance would yield the benefits that Renault and Nissan insist would result. The sides agreed to explore an alliance in discussions that began in July. Renault and Nissan say an alliance could cover operations as varied as purchasing, manufacturing and product development. [C1.]    LIQUIDS BAN RELAXED -- Aviation officials eased the ban on carry-on liquids for airline passengers, after testing to determine how much liquid explosive would cause catastrophic damage to a plane. [A14.]    OIL IN RETREAT -- Crude oil prices dropped below $60 a barrel for the first time in six months before rebounding a bit, as nervous speculators retreated from the commodity markets. [C3.]    OIL AND RATES LIFT STOCKS -- Stocks surged, with the Nasdaq rising more than 1 percent, as oil prices and interest rates hit multimonth lows, improving the outlook for corporate profits. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 30.14 points to 2,249.07, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.71 points to 11,575.81. [C11.]    COMPUTER POWER -- Google engineers will present a plan calling on the computer industry to create a simpler and more efficient power supply standard that they say will save billions of kilowatt-hours a year. [C3.]    PATENT POLICY -- I.B.M. plans to publish its patent filings on the Web for public review as part of a policy that, if widely adopted, could help curb patent disputes and litigation. [C5.]    PROGRESS ON A TINY SCALE -- A lengthy assessment for Congress says the United States continues to lead the world in research into nanotechnology -- manipulation of atoms and small clusters of molecules -- but the impact of the government's investment in the field may take decades to become apparent. [C6.]    PANEL ADVISES HEALTH CARE ACTION -- A federal advisory panel, the Citizens' Health Care Working Group, said that Congress should take immediate steps to guarantee that all Americans have access to affordable health care by 2012. [A17.]    HOUSE CALLS H.P. FIGURES -- Two Hewlett-Packard employees who directed the company's spying operations have been subpoenaed to appear before the House Energy and Commerce Committee after refusing invitations to testify. [C2.]    ENERGY LEASE SALE BLOCKED -- The Interior Department's plan to sell oil and natural gas leases in northern Alaska was blocked by a federal judge who ruled that the department had failed to do a sufficiently broad analysis of the plan's environmental impact. [A15.]    EUROPEAN UNION EXPANSION -- Romania and Bulgaria will receive qualified endorsement to join the European Union on Jan. 1, but the bloc will warn that expansion must then halt until the organization makes needed changes, the European Commission president said. [A5.]    WALGREEN PROFIT RISES -- The Walgreen Company, the drugstore chain, posted a 25 percent increase in quarterly profit, driven by strong sales of prescription medications. Walgreen shares declined, however, as earnings before unusual items fell short of expectations. [C2.]    ACQUITTAL IN WIRETAPPING CASE -- A former telephone company worker accused of lying to a grand jury in Los Angeles that is investigating the Anthony Pellicano wiretapping scandal was acquitted of most of the charges against her, dealing a sharp setback to federal prosecutors. [C8.]    WACHOVIA TO PAY EX-BROKER -- Wachovia was ordered by a NASD arbitration panel to pay $3.8 million to a broker it fired in 2003 in connection with an investigation of improper trades. [C9.]    SENTENCE IN FRAUD CASE -- The former chief executive of a paper manufacturer, American Tissue, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for organizing a fraud that cost banks and investors almost $300 million when the company collapsed. [C8.]    WAVING THE FLAG -- Chevrolet, the brand that likened itself to baseball, hot dogs and apple pie in commercials in the 1970's, now hopes to kindle the same feelings by positioning the Silverado as America's truck, in ads that will begin running this weekend. Advertising. [C3.]

lead_paragraph: In the pianist Hank Jones, as with a number of older jazz musicians, you get the sense that ideas and technique are one: his thinking has become shaped to fit his hands and body. But what's even more special about Mr. Jones is his war against mannerism: cuteness, thundering, whispering, hammering, over-earthy vamping, over-whimsical cadenzas and fantasias, spending too much time in the low end of the keyboard or the high end.

snippet: More than 2,000 companies appear to have used backdated stock options to sweeten their top executives' pay packages, according to a new study that suggests the practice is far more widespread than previously disclosed.      The new statistical ana...
lead_paragraph: More than 2,000 companies appear to have used backdated stock options to sweeten their top executives' pay packages, according to a new study that suggests the practice is far more widespread than previously disclosed.
abstract: More than 2,000 companies appear to have used backdated stock options to sweeten their top executives' pay packages, according to a new study that suggests the practice is far more widespread than previously disclosed.      The new statistical analysis, which comes amid a broadening federal inquiry of the practice of timing options to the stock market, estimates that 29.2 percent of companies have used backdated options and 13.6 percent of options granted to top executives from 1996 to 2005 were backdated or otherwise manipulated.

snippet: IT'S the kind of thing that can make bargain hunters rejoice: merchants that follow consumers to competing stores and show them a better deal just as they are about to check out. In the mall, that would be considered stalking. Online, it's an idea...
lead_paragraph: IT'S the kind of thing that can make bargain hunters rejoice: merchants that follow consumers to competing stores and show them a better deal just as they are about to check out. In the mall, that would be considered stalking. Online, it's an idea that has been around for several years but has failed to catch on.
abstract: IT'S the kind of thing that can make bargain hunters rejoice: merchants that follow consumers to competing stores and show them a better deal just as they are about to check out. In the mall, that would be considered stalking. Online, it's an idea that has been around for several years but has failed to catch on.      Now Barry Diller's company, IAC/InterActiveCorp, among several others, is giving this kind of shopping software a revival. The company recently introduced Pronto, a software application that a user downloads at Pronto.com. Once a user clicks on one of the 50,000 merchants in its database, Pronto silently monitors all of a user's activity on a product page, then shows deals from other merchants on the same items, or similar ones, until it finds a better deal. Then it sends a message prompting the user to click away.
