lead_paragraph: YAHOO BIDS FOR FACEBOOK -- To woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the social networking Web site Facebook, Yahoo has offered about $900 million for the company and said it would keep Mr. Zuckerberg in charge. [Page C1.]
abstract: YAHOO BIDS FOR FACEBOOK -- To woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the social networking Web site Facebook, Yahoo has offered about $900 million for the company and said it would keep Mr. Zuckerberg in charge. [Page C1.]    PRESSURE ON CHIEF OF H.P. Pressure is mounting on Mark V. Hurd, Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, to explain what appears to have been his greater role in the company's spying operation than was initially indicated. Yesterday, after his name figured in documents newly surfacing in the investigation, Hewlett-Packard's stock fell significantly for the first time since the revelations began early this month, closing down 5.19 percent. [C1.]    BILLIONS TO FIGHT GLOBAL WARMING -- Sir Richard Branson, the British magnate, said that his personal profits from airlines and a rail company that he controls -- a sum he estimated at $3 billion over the next 10 years -- would be invested in developing energy sources that do not contribute to global warming. [C1.]    LIKE MEDICARE, BUT PRIVATE -- A type of private insurance plan is gaining ground that looks little different from the basic coverage long available to anyone with a federally issued Medicare card. [C1.]    MIGRANTS MISSING FROM FARMS -- Stepped-up border enforcement kept many illegal Mexican migrant workers out of California this year, farmers and labor contractors said, putting strains on the state's shrinking seasonal farm labor force. [A1.]    SPINACH GROWERS SWITCH TACTICS -- Amid growing governmental pressure and public concern about an E. coli outbreak caused by contaminated spinach, California farmers promised new procedures for growing, handling and shipping their produce, in hopes of lifting a week-old government warning about the crop. [A15.]    SHARES FALL ON FEAR OF SLOWDOWN -- Stocks fell after a report said factory activity shrank in the Mid-Atlantic region in September for the first time in over three years, prompting worries about a slowdown in the economy and corporate profits. [C8.]    INQUIRY ON HEART IMPLANTS -- Ela Medical, a small producer of implantable heart devices, said it had received a subpoena from federal health care fraud officials seeking information about possible inducements paid by the company to doctors using its products. [C4.]    RULES FOR MILITARY LIFE INSURANCE -- Congress has taken final action to approve a bill to tighten rules governing the marketing of life insurance and high-cost mutual funds to American military personnel. [C4.]    DROPPING OIL ROYALTIES -- A top official at the Interior Department said that she would not try to recover $1.3 billion in royalties that the government has lost as a result of flawed oil and gas leases it signed in the late 1990's. [C2.]    MORE DELAYS FOR A380 -- The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent company of Airbus, confirmed that its troubled A380 would face still more delivery delay. [C7.]    TRIBUNE MAY SELL SOME ASSETS -- The Tribune Company will consider selling some or all of its assets, which include 11 newspapers, 25 television stations and the Chicago Cubs, as a result of an agreement it worked out with its largest shareholder, the Chandler family. Dennis FitzSimons, above, the company's chief, said the agreement had ''eliminated impediments to any transactions we might want to do, and management will explore strategic alternatives.'' [C5.]    MERCK OF GERMANY IN DEAL -- Merck of Germany said it would take control of Serono, a Swiss pharmaceutical maker, for $13.5 billion after failing to secure a merger with Schering, its German competitor. [C7.]    NEXT STEP FOR GOOGLE ADS -- Google is turning to Madison Avenue to help persuade marketers that it can do more than display text. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    ONLINE    POGUE'S POSTS -- Nowadays, Apple is a media darling. But that hasn't always been the case, as David Pogue writes in his blog at pogue.blogs.nytimes.com.    SCREENS -- The Times critic Virginia Heffernan takes a look at the explosion of Web video awards in her blog at screens.blogs.nytimes.com.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    FEDEX said that its quarterly profit rose 40 percent on strong growth in its international, ground and freight segments. (REUTERS)    NIKE said net profit fell 13 percent as stock-based compensation hampered results. The quarter still exceeded estimates. (REUTERS)    RITE AID, the drugstore chain, said that its quarterly loss narrowed as a result of an income tax benefit and increased sales of generic drugs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    PALM said that profit for its fiscal first quarter slipped as it accounted for stock option expenses for the first time and grappled with slow sales growth amid tougher competition. (AP)    CONAGRA FOODS said in a preliminary report that quarterly profit fell 66 percent from a year earlier, when results included a gain from the sale of stock in the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    AN EXECUTIVE with the United States unit of Samsung Electronics of South Korea agreed to plead guilty and serve prison time for taking part in price fixing in the computer memory chip business, the Justice Department. (REUTERS)

snippet: The number of Americans making online purchases of $2 or less is skyrocketing, according to a recent survey. The study found that nearly twice as many people as last year had made such purchases within a year of being surveyed. The survey was comm...
lead_paragraph: The number of Americans making online purchases of $2 or less is skyrocketing, according to a recent survey. The study found that nearly twice as many people as last year had made such purchases within a year of being surveyed. The survey was commissioned by Peppercoin, a maker of software that enables small online transactions, and carried out by Ipsos, a marketing research firm.
abstract: The number of Americans making online purchases of $2 or less is skyrocketing, according to a recent survey. The study found that nearly twice as many people as last year had made such purchases within a year of being surveyed. The survey was commissioned by Peppercoin, a maker of software that enables small online transactions, and carried out by Ipsos, a marketing research firm.     Much of the trade behind this increase is in bits and bytes, rather than tangible goods. Digital music, for example, has been a major factor since Apple's iTunes music store started selling music files for 99 cents apiece.

snippet: WHENEVER I've asked around the shoreline for recommendations for Italian food, Tre Scalini in New Haven's Little Italy is inevitably mentioned with enthusiasm. Given the number of Italian restaurants in Connecticut, I could hardly ignore such cons...
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER I've asked around the shoreline for recommendations for Italian food, Tre Scalini in New Haven's Little Italy is inevitably mentioned with enthusiasm. Given the number of Italian restaurants in Connecticut, I could hardly ignore such consistent endorsement.
abstract: WHENEVER I've asked around the shoreline for recommendations for Italian food, Tre Scalini in New Haven's Little Italy is inevitably mentioned with enthusiasm. Given the number of Italian restaurants in Connecticut, I could hardly ignore such consistent endorsement.      Tre Scalini, which translates as ''three steps'' and refers to the steps that join the main dining floor and small balcony, has been open since June 1995, but it has the feel of a place that might have been around somewhat longer. How to characterize the décor? It's certainly romantic in an old-fashioned way with chandeliers, the balcony, swags of fabric that soften the windows and very pretty French doors that look out onto Wooster Street.

snippet: Books by Will Eisner, Brian Wood, Guy Delisle, George Herriman and Marjane Satrapi.
lead_paragraph: Cartoonists can creatively distort a story’s setting — playing up its salient details, putting an interpretive spin on its lines and contours — until it’s more vivid and imposing than its real-world model. Will Eisner (1917-2005) was both a great distorter and a great observer, and WILL EISNER’S NEW YORK: Life in the Big City (Norton, $29.95) compiles four volumes of his thinly veiled excuses to draw Manhattan and the Bronx. This collection contains the brief sketches of everyday scenes in his books “New York: The Big City” (1981) and “City People Notebook” (1989), and the more story-based “Invisible People” (2000) and “The Building” (1987).
abstract: Books by Will Eisner, Brian Wood, Guy Delisle, George Herriman and Marjane Satrapi.

snippet: Sexy satins, glossy metallics and opalescent materials are inspiring low glare fashions and accessories; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: After several seasons worth of sequins, spangles and Swarovski crystals clinging to clothes like barnacles, the encrustacean era finally seems to be winding down. For spring, retailers are turning down the sparkle and turning up the shine, for a cleaner, more streamlined effect. Using sexy satins, glossy metallics and opalescent materials like mother-of-pearl, designers are keeping their clothes and accessories high gloss and low glare.

snippet: Google's Stock Falls 7% After Disclosure That Technical Limits Restrict Its Growth  Google's shares tumbled 7 percent yesterday after the chief financial officer told investors that the company saw few additional advances in a technology that had ...
lead_paragraph: Google's Stock Falls 7% After Disclosure That Technical Limits Restrict Its Growth Google's shares tumbled 7 percent yesterday after the chief financial officer told investors that the company saw few additional advances in a technology that had brought it a substantial increase in advertising revenue. The financial executive, George Reyes, left, told an investor conference held by Merrill Lynch, that its revenue growth would slow as a result. [Page C1.]
abstract: Google's Stock Falls 7% After Disclosure That Technical Limits Restrict Its Growth  Google's shares tumbled 7 percent yesterday after the chief financial officer told investors that the company saw few additional advances in a technology that had brought it a substantial increase in advertising revenue. The financial executive, George Reyes, left, told an investor conference held by Merrill Lynch, that its revenue growth would slow as a result. [Page C1.]    Supreme Court to Consider Business Tax Incentives  The Supreme Court takes up a major case today about the legality of tens of billions of dollars in tax breaks that states and local governments award businesses each year to build factories, or just to stay put. [C1.]    JetBlue Tries to Revive Its Profit With Higher Fares  JetBlue Airways, the low-cost carrier, is trying to raise fares in a bid to restore profit after surging fuel prices caused it to lose $42.4 million in the fourth quarter. [C1.]    The first 100 or so of thousands of small passenger jets will soon begin flying, the Federal Aviation Administration said, in what some proponents say, could alter the air-travel industry. [C5.]    Restoration of Gulf Oil Production Remains Unfinished  The huge task of fixing the country's most important energy hub is far from over. Six months after Hurricane Katrina battered the gulf with 175-mile-an-hour winds and waves higher than eight-story buildings, more than a quarter of the region's oil output is still shut. [C1.]    The Bush administration is scaling back on audits of energy companies that generate billions of dollars in sales from leases to produce oil and gas on federal property, state officials said. The changes have sparked protests from several oil-producing states and Indian tribes. [C1.]    J. P. Morgan Fills a Gap With a Fidelity Partnership  J. P Morgan announced a partnership with Fidelity Investment's brokerage arm that gives millions of individual investors access to the same new equity and fixed-income offerings its institutional clients have long received, filling a gap in the company's services. [C3.]    Existing Home Sales at Two-Year Low in January  Sales of existing homes dropped to their lowest level in nearly two years in January and the number of unsold homes on the market rose, a trade group reported. [C3.]    Apple Pushes Further Into Home Entertainment  Apple Computer furthered its push into home entertainment on the introduction of a high-fidelity stereo system for the iPod music player, as well as a new version of the Mac Mini computer with features for managing digital music and video. [C2.]    CBS Radio Sues Howard Stern Over His Departure  CBS Radio filed a lawsuit yesterday against Howard Stern charging that its former radio star used his last months on the air at CBS to build up his future employer, Sirius Satellite Radio, and gained significant financial advantages that damaged CBS Radio. Mr. Stern countered that the lawsuit was an attempt by CBS to distract attention from its poor quarterly results. [C3.]    Stocks Tumble on Mixed Economic Statistics  Mixed economic statistics caused stocks to tumble. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 104.14 points, to 10,993.41. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 13.46 points, to 1,280.66, and the Nasdaq fell 25.79 points, to 2,281.39. [C10.]    Ports Takeover Opponents Raise New Objections  Lawmakers raised new objections to the proposed takeover of some terminal operations at six United States ports by a Dubai company. [A13.]    A Former Enron Executive Testifies on Contracts  A former Enron executive gave the strongest testimony yet in a five-week-old trial that Jeffrey K. Skilling, the company's former chief executive, signed off on a controversial accounting shift involving troubled trading contracts. [C3.]    Technology Opens Opportunities for the Disabled  Thousands of people with disabilities are finding jobs and becoming independent as a result of technological advances like faster computers and broadband Internet connections that let them work at home. [C7.]    Some Medicare Patients Find Themselves in Two Plans  Tens of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries have found themselves enrolled in two prescription drug plans at the same time as a result of confusion over the new program. [A1.]    House to Vote on Pre-Empting States' Food Safety Rules  The House is expected to vote Thursday on a bill that would pre-empt state food safety regulations that are more stringent than federal standards and set a uniform set of rules across the nation. [A14.]

snippet: AUDIO books have been around for years on tapes and CD's, but new downloadable and digital audio books and players make it more convenient to catch up on ''The DaVinci Code'' in the rental car line or settle down with an Agatha Christie mystery on...
lead_paragraph: AUDIO books have been around for years on tapes and CD's, but new downloadable and digital audio books and players make it more convenient to catch up on "The DaVinci Code" in the rental car line or settle down with an Agatha Christie mystery on a trans-Atlantic flight. Not only do the batteries of digital devices often last longer than those of portable CD players, but most MP3 players hold many more hours of content than a single CD, meaning you don't have to worry about not being able to hear the end of a story because you left the next disk at home.
abstract: AUDIO books have been around for years on tapes and CD's, but new downloadable and digital audio books and players make it more convenient to catch up on ''The DaVinci Code'' in the rental car line or settle down with an Agatha Christie mystery on a trans-Atlantic flight. Not only do the batteries of digital devices often last longer than those of portable CD players, but most MP3 players hold many more hours of content than a single CD, meaning you don't have to worry about not being able to hear the end of a story because you left the next disk at home.      Once you've decided to go digital, it helps to know where to find content. A good place to start is the Audio Publishers Association (www.audiopub.org). The site lists many publishers providing audio or downloadable books, including AudioBooksForFree (www.audiobooksforfree.com), which features many public-domain classic literary works, such as ''Alice in Wonderland,'' in MP3 format, which is free in basic audio quality, or $7 for better quality.

lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR - ON an anonymous, miscellaneous stretch of Bloomfield Avenue that still isn't quite ready for its close-up, Blu is easy to miss. And even when we found it, we felt a little lost.
abstract: ON an anonymous, miscellaneous stretch of Bloomfield Avenue that still isn't quite ready for its close-up, Blu is easy to miss. And even when we found it, we felt a little lost.      Blu, a tiny new restaurant in a narrow storefront that used to be Mango's Reggae Cafe, has the dim, retro-noir look of an early-60's basement rec room. On a ferocious night in early winter, its blue three-letter sign, etched into frosted glass in the front window, was wreathed in vapor. The place looked faintly, pleasurably disreputable, as if we'd been transported from the suburbs to some shady deserted neighborhood under the Brooklyn Bridge.

abstract: As portable audio devices proliferate, from iPods to satellite radios, demand is growing for products that allow listening at home. The Mini system from Zvox Audio has at least one advantage over most standard iPod speaker sets: it creates virtual surround sound and accepts audio input from just about anything, including televisions and game consoles.     The three-pound device, which is available at zvoxaudio.com for $200, is about the size of an average laptop. It does not have a CD player or built-in FM radio, and it lacks a standard iPod dock: it is connected to an MP3 player through a headphone jack with the included cord.

snippet: IT was on the 30-mile-an-hour bicycle descent from the top of Crystal Mountain, to the west, that I got my first panoramic view of Okanagan Lake, which stretches for 70 miles through the valley between the Cascade and Monashee Ranges. Even though ...
lead_paragraph: IT was on the 30-mile-an-hour bicycle descent from the top of Crystal Mountain, to the west, that I got my first panoramic view of Okanagan Lake, which stretches for 70 miles through the valley between the Cascade and Monashee Ranges. Even though I had seen the lake from the shore for two days, as I blew out of the trees now with a group of touring cyclists, it came as a surprise: shimmering and cobalt blue, the hills at its sides covered by grapevines.
abstract: IT was on the 30-mile-an-hour bicycle descent from the top of Crystal Mountain, to the west, that I got my first panoramic view of Okanagan Lake, which stretches for 70 miles through the valley between the Cascade and Monashee Ranges. Even though I had seen the lake from the shore for two days, as I blew out of the trees now with a group of touring cyclists, it came as a surprise: shimmering and cobalt blue, the hills at its sides covered by grapevines.      This was the British Columbia of popular imagination, all steep-walled mountain valleys and spectacular snow-fed lakes, but with a bonus: a wine region aspiring to hold its own with the famous California valleys to the south. Part old-fashioned summer lake resort, part cycling center and traditionally the fruit basket of this part of Canada, the fertile, glacier-formed Okanagan (pronounced oak-a-NOG-in) Valley is changing fast as cherry orchards and nut farms lose ground to the vineyards and as tourism grows along with the grapes. Now, in the heart of the harvest season, days are clear and sunny, the air smells like apples, and grapes hang heavy on the vine.

headline.main: The Okanagan, a Napa of the North
headline.print_headline: The Okanagan, a Napa of the North

snippet: Once known for orchards, British Columbia’s Okanagan Valley is now a burgeoning wine region and recreation area.
lead_paragraph: IT was on the 30-mile-an-hour bicycle descent from the top of Crystal Mountain, to the west, that I got my first panoramic view of Okanagan Lake, which stretches for 70 miles through the valley between the Cascade and Monashee Ranges. Even though I had seen the lake from the shore for two days, as I blew out of the trees now with a group of touring cyclists, it came as a surprise: shimmering and cobalt blue, the hills at its sides covered by grapevines.
abstract: Once known for orchards, British Columbia’s Okanagan Valley is now a burgeoning wine region and recreation area.

lead_paragraph: Emptying the Trash, For Good
abstract: Emptying the Trash, For Good    Q. On a Mac, what is the difference between ''Empty Trash'' and ''Secure Empty Trash''?    A. Choosing the ''Empty Trash'' option under your Mac's Finder menu tells the computer to delete the files you have dumped in the bin, but it still may be possible to retrieve them by using a data-recovery program or hard-disk utility software. The information itself is still lurking on your drive until other data overwrites it.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The homemade poster hanging next to Yana Shikhlyarova's honey stand doesn't just list the half-dozen varieties of honey she has on sale. It also lists the various ailments they cure. Clover honey, it says, is good for the heart. Forest honey, rich in vitamins from the blackberries and wild strawberries of the woods, is good for the eyes.

snippet: TUCKED behind Times Square, the upscale shopping mall that sits just north of the Happy Valley racecourse in Hong Kong, a little-traveled alley is starting to take off in a big way. Yiu Wa Street consists of one long, curved block, but in the past...
lead_paragraph: TUCKED behind Times Square, the upscale shopping mall that sits just north of the Happy Valley racecourse in Hong Kong, a little-traveled alley is starting to take off in a big way. Yiu Wa Street consists of one long, curved block, but in the past year it has become a center for high-end shopping and trendy night life.
abstract: TUCKED behind Times Square, the upscale shopping mall that sits just north of the Happy Valley racecourse in Hong Kong, a little-traveled alley is starting to take off in a big way. Yiu Wa Street consists of one long, curved block, but in the past year it has become a center for high-end shopping and trendy night life.      Among the clutch of boutiques and bars that line either side of the street, a few stand out for their uniqueness or their bargains. One in the former category is Kevin Cheung's H3 workshop, on the second floor of 1A Yiu Wa Street, 852-2573-3321, on the Web at www.kevinscreature.com.

headline.main: Hong Kong's Luxury Alley
